Dago: A nickname given to a person of Spanish (or, by extension, Portuguese or Italian) descent.
Doer: One who does; one who performs or executes; one who is wont and ready to act; an actor; an agent.
Does: The 3d pers. sing. pres. of Do.
Durometer: An instrument for measuring the degree of hardness; especially, an instrument for testing the relative hardness of steel rails and the like.
Diverticle: A turning; a byway; a bypath.
dillenia: any of several evergreen trees or shrubs of the genus Dillenia grown for their foliage and nodding magnolialike flowers which are followed by fruit that is used in curries and jellies and preserves.
drosky: A low, four-wheeled, open carriage, formerly used in Poland and Russia, consisting of a kind of long, narrow bench, on which the passengers ride as on a saddle, with their feet reaching nearly to the ground.  Other kinds of vehicles have been so called, esp. a kind of victoria drawn by one or two horses, and used as a public carriage in German cities.
Deceit: An attempt or disposition to deceive or lead into error; any declaration, artifice, or practice, which misleads another, or causes him to believe what is false; a contrivance to entrap; deception; a wily device; fraud.
digit: To point at or out with the finger.
Defiliation: Abstraction of a child from its parents.
Ducking: n. & a., from Duck, v. t. & i.
Distad: Toward a distal part; on the distal side of; distally.
differentiated: made different (especially in the course of development) or shown to be different; as, the differentiated markings of butterflies; the regionally differentiated results.  Opposite of undifferentiated.
Debellate: To subdue; to conquer in war.
Distal: Remote from the point of attachment or origin; as, the distal end of a bone or muscle
Detort: To turn form the original or plain meaning; to pervert; to wrest.
Decacuminated: Having the point or top cut off.
Detruncate: To shorten by cutting; to cut off; to lop off.
daybed: an armless couch; a seat by day and a bed by night.
Douanier: An officer of the French customs.
Docimacy: The art or practice of applying tests to ascertain the nature, quality, etc., of objects, as of metals or ores, of medicines, or of facts pertaining to physiology.
Demiquaver: A note of half the length of the quaver; a semiquaver.
Diagometer: A sort of electroscope, invented by Rousseau, in which the dry pile is employed to measure the amount of electricity transmitted by different bodies, or to determine their conducting power.
dog-ear: a corner of a page turned down to mark a place.
Dosage: The administration of medicine in doses; specif., a scheme or system of grading doses of medicine according to age, etc.
dork: a person who is stupid, socially inept, or ridiculous; -- always used disparagingly.
doldrums: A part of the ocean near the equator, abounding in calms, squalls, and light, baffling winds, which sometimes prevent all progress for weeks; -- so called by sailors.
Dominique: an American breed of chicken having barred gray plumage raised for meat and brown eggs.
Downfall: A sudden fall; a body of things falling.
Doucepere: One of the twelve peers of France, companions of Charlemagne in war.
Discandy: To melt; to dissolve; to thaw.
Decahedron: A solid figure or body inclosed by ten plane surfaces.
Dexter: One of a breed of small hardy cattle originating from the Kerry breed of Ireland, valuable both for beef and milk. They are usually chiefly black, sometimes red, and somewhat resemble a small shorthorn in build. Called also Dexter Kerry.
Disloyal: Not loyal; not true to a sovereign or lawful superior, or to the government under which one lives; false where allegiance is due; faithless; as, a subject disloyal to the king; a husband disloyal to his wife.
Digitation: A division into fingers or fingerlike processes; also, a fingerlike process.
Detector: One who, or that which, detects; a detecter.
Dogate: The office or dignity of a doge.
ducky: a special loved one; a darling; -- used as a term of endearment.
detribalization: the act of causing tribal people to abandon their customs and adopt urban ways of living.
Deglutinate: To loosen or separate by dissolving the glue which unties; to unglue.
Debilitant: Diminishing the energy of organs; reducing excitement; as, a debilitant drug.
desalt: to remove the salt from (a solution of salt).
Devocalize: To make toneless; to deprive of vowel quality.
Dumps: a gloomy mental state; same as 2nd dump{1}; -- used mostly in the phrase “in the dumps”.
day lily: any plant of a genus of plants (Hemerocallis) closely resembling true lilies, but having tuberous rootstocks instead of bulbs. The common species have long narrow leaves and either yellow or tawny-orange flowers, which often bloom for only one day.
Delay: To move slowly; to stop for a time; to linger; to tarry.
Ditty-bag: A sailor's small bag to hold thread, needles, tape, etc.; -- also called sailor's housewife.
Depatriate: To withdraw, or cause to withdraw, from one's country; to banish.
Dereplication: the process of testing samples of mixtures which are active in a screening process, so as to recognize and eliminate from consideration those active substances already studied; -- a stage subsequent to the preliminary screening in the process of discovery of new pharmacologically active substances in mixtures of natural products; -- also called counterscreening.  See screening.
Disenroll: To erase from a roll or list.
Detritus: A mass of substances worn off from solid bodies by attrition, and reduced to small portions; as, diluvial detritus.
Daze: The state of being dazed; as, he was in a daze.
Deposer: One who deposes or degrades from office.
Dogs-ear: The corner of a leaf, in a book, turned down like the ear of a dog.
Decandria: A Linnæan class of plants characterized by having ten stamens.
Diplograph: An instrument used for double writing, as one for producing embossed writing for the blind and ordinary writing at the same time.
Disinheritance: The act of disinheriting, or the condition of being; disinherited; disherison.
Dibasicity: The property or condition of being dibasic.
Dactylology: The art of communicating ideas by certain movements and positions of the fingers; -- a method of conversing practiced by the deaf and dumb.
Direct-acting: Acting directly, as one part upon another, without the intervention of other working parts.
Disboscation: Converting forest land into cleared or arable land; removal of a forest.
Delicacy: The state or condition of being delicate; agreeableness to the senses; delightfulness; as, delicacy of flavor, of odor, and the like.
Donation: The act of giving or bestowing; a grant.
Disown: To refuse to own or acknowledge as belonging to one's self; to disavow or deny, as connected with one's self personally; as, a parent can hardly disown his child; an author will sometimes disown his writings.
Dequantitate: To diminish the quantity of; to disquantity.
Dizz: To make dizzy; to astonish; to puzzle.
Degarnishment: The act of depriving, as of furniture, apparatus, or a garrison.
Durio: A fruit tree (Durio zibethinus, the only species known) of the Indian Archipelago.  It bears the durian.
Decerption: The act of plucking off; a cropping.
Domanial: Of or relating to a domain or to domains.
dry-cleaned: cleaned without the use of water; -- usually by immersing in an organic solvent to remove grease.
Depiction: A painting or depicting; a representation.
Dutchman: A native, or one of the people, of Holland.
Disauthorize: To deprive of credit or authority; to discredit.
Deers-tongue: A plant (Liatris odoratissima) whose fleshy leaves give out a fragrance compared to vanilla.
Digastric: Having two bellies; biventral; -- applied to muscles which are fleshy at each end and have a tendon in the middle, and esp. to the muscle which pulls down the lower jaw.
Dominant: The fifth tone of the scale; thus G is the dominant of C, A of D, and so on.
Disenshrouded: Freed from a shroudlike covering; unveiled.
Depauperize: To free from paupers; to rescue from poverty.
Discharge: The act of discharging; the act of relieving of a charge or load; removal of a load or burden; unloading; as, the discharge of a ship; discharge of a cargo.
Dedicator: One who dedicates; more especially, one who inscribes a book to the favor of a patron, or to one whom he desires to compliment.
Distinction: A marking off by visible signs; separation into parts; division.
Deictically: In a manner to show or point out; directly; absolutely; definitely.
Dehortatory: Fitted or designed to dehort or dissuade.
Disgrace: To put out of favor; to dismiss with dishonor.
Debauch: Excess in eating or drinking; intemperance; drunkenness; lewdness; debauchery.
Damp off: To decay and perish through excessive moisture.
Driveway: A passage or way along or through which a carriage may be driven.
Dun: Of a dark color; of a color partaking of a brown and black; of a dull brown color; swarthy.
Duo: A composition for two performers; a duet.
disfigured: having the appearance spoiled; as, a disfigured face; strip mining left a disfigured landscape.
Deicide: The act of killing a being of a divine nature; particularly, the putting to death of Jesus Christ.
Dup: To open; as, to dup the door.
Dur: Major; in the major mode; as, C dur, that is, C major.
Distention: The act of distending; the act of stretching in breadth or in all directions; the state of being Distended; as, the distention of the lungs.
Disutilize: To deprive of utility; to render useless.
dislodgement: forced removal from a position of advantage.
Discontinuer: One who discontinues, or breaks off or away from; an absentee.
Distill: To let fall or send down in drops.
Diplopoda: An order of myriapods having two pairs of legs on each segment; the Chilognatha.
Discontinuee: One whose possession of an estate is broken off, or discontinued; one whose estate is subject to discontinuance.
Disentitle: To deprive of title or claim.
Dairywoman: A woman who attends to a dairy.
Dove: A pigeon of the genus Columba and various related genera. The species are numerous.
Dreissena: A genus of bivalve shells of which one species (Dreissena polymorpha) is often so abundant as to be very troublesome in the fresh waters of Europe.
Duotone: Any picture printed in two shades of the same color, as duotypes and duographs are usually printed.
Decistere: The tenth part of the stere or cubic meter, equal to 3.531 cubic feet. See Stere.
Dephlegmate: To deprive of superabundant water, as by evaporation or distillation; to clear of aqueous matter; to rectify; -- used of spirits and acids.
densitometer: an instrument for determining optical or photographic density.  A variety capable of measuring optical density of a sample at a number of different wavelengths, is called a spectrophotometer.
D\u00e9jeuner: A breakfast; sometimes, also, a lunch or collation.
draftsperson: a skilled worker who draws plans of buildings or machines.
Doggedly: In a dogged manner; sullenly; with obstinate resolution.
Distinctly: With distinctness; not confusedly; without the blending of one part or thing another; clearly; plainly; as, to see distinctly.
Drastic: Acting rapidly and violently; efficacious; powerful; -- opposed to bland; as, drastic purgatives.
drop forge: a device for making large forgings, in which a heavy hammer drops onto the metalwork to be forged, pressing it into a form or anvil underneath, or between dies.
Dooly: A kind of litter suspended from men's shoulders, for carrying persons or things; a palanquin.
Drawgloves: An old game, played by holding up the fingers.
Devotionally: In a devotional manner; toward devotion.
Draughtboard: A checkered board on which draughts are played. See Checkerboard.
Digitaria: a genus of plants including the crab grass (Digitaria sanguinalis); finger grass.
Diabase: A basic, dark-colored, holocrystalline, igneous rock, consisting essentially of a triclinic feldspar and pyroxene with magnetic iron; -- often limited to rocks pretertiary in age. It includes part of what was early called greenstone.
Desophisticate: To clear from sophism or error.
departing: leaving a starting or stopping point on a journey; as, Departing flights were delayed by the snowstorm.  Opposite of arriving.
droppings: fecal matter of animals; plural of dropping{2}.
Deridingly: By way of derision or mockery.
Diastasis: A forcible separation of bones without fracture.
Dentil: A small square block or projection in cornices, a number of which are ranged in an ornamental band; -- used particularly in the Ionic, Corinthian, and Composite orders.
Deep-laid: Laid deeply; formed with cunning and sagacity; secretly and carefully planned; as, deep-laid plans.
Dysluite: A variety of the zinc spinel or gahnite.
Damnify: To cause loss or damage to; to injure; to impair.
Declinate: Bent downward or aside; (Bot.) bending downward in a curve; declined.
Dowered: Furnished with, or as with, dower or a marriage portion.
Diastasic: Pertaining to, or consisting of, diastase; as, diastasic ferment.
Delineable: Capable of being, or liable to be, delineated.
Disfurnishment: The act of disfurnishing, or the state of being disfurnished.
Dancer: One who dances or who practices dancing.
Discountenancer: One who discountenances; one who disfavors.
Doge: The chief magistrate in the republics of Venice and Genoa.
Decastich: A poem consisting of ten lines.
Dimensionless: Without dimensions; having no appreciable or noteworthy extent.
Delphinoidea: The division of Cetacea which comprises the dolphins, porpoises, and related forms.
Dwarf: To become small; to diminish in size.
Dexedrine: an isomer of amphetamine used as a central nervous system stimulant (Dexedrine is a trademark).
Discomfiture: The act of discomfiting, or the state of being discomfited; rout; overthrow; defeat; frustration; confusion and dejection.
Dewar: A double-walled glass vessel for holding liquid air, liquid nitrogen, etc., having the space between the walls exhausted so as to prevent conduction of heat, and sometimes having the glass silvered to prevent absorption of radiant heat; -- called also, according to the particular shape, Dewar bulb, Dewar tube, etc.
Dicing: An ornamenting in squares or cubes.
Distressedness: A state of being distressed or greatly pained.
Dactylic: A line consisting chiefly or wholly of dactyls; as, these lines are dactylics.
Duffel bag: A sack to hold miscellaneous articles, as tools, supplies, or the like.
dock-walloper: a laborer who loads and unloads vessels in a port.
Dilleniaceae: a natural family of chiefly tropical shrubs and trees and climbers having leathery leaves or flattened leaflike stems, including the genera Dillenia and Hibbertia.
Dromond: In the Middle Ages, a large, fast-sailing galley, or cutter; a large, swift war vessel.
Declaration of Independence: The document promugated, July 4, 1776, by the leaders of the thirteen British Colonies in America that they have formed an independent country.  See note below.
Dependent: One who depends; one who is sustained by another, or who relies on another for financial support or favor; a hanger-on; a retainer; as, a numerous train of dependents.
Deploration: The act of deploring or lamenting; lamentation.
Damageable: Capable of being injured or impaired; liable to, or susceptible of, damage; as, a damageable cargo.
Deadwood: A mass of timbers built into the bow and stern of a vessel to give solidity.
Disrudder: To deprive of the rudder, as a ship.
Doubletree: The bar, or crosspiece, of a carriage, to which the singletrees are attached.
Derail: To cause to run off from the rails of a railroad, as a locomotive.
Disquietly: In a disquiet manner; uneasily; as, he rested disquietly that night.
Dumbness: The quality or state of being dumb; muteness; silence; inability to speak.
doormat: a mat placed outside and exterior door for wiping the shoes before entering.
dependability: the trait of being dependable or reliable.
doorman: someone who guards the entrance to a building.
darkie: a black person; an African-American; -- an older term now considered offensive.
damaged: changed so as to reduce value, function, or other desirable trait; -- usually not used of persons.  Opposite of undamaged.
doofus: a person who is stupid or inept; -- used contemptuously.
Direct primary: A primary by which direct nominations of candidates for office are made.
damages: a sum of money paid in compensation for an injury or wrong.
Dustbrush: A brush of feathers, bristles, or hair, for removing dust from furniture.
Dulcification: The act of dulcifying or sweetening.
Dissertate: To deal in dissertation; to write dissertations; to discourse.
Dragantine: A mucilage obtained from, or containing, gum tragacanth.
Decorative: Suited to decorate or embellish; adorning.
disseminated: Occurring in small portions scattered through some other substance; scattered widely.
D\u00e9butant: A person who makes his (or her) first appearance before the public.
Deliberate: To take counsel with one's self; to weigh the arguments for and against a proposed course of action; to reflect; to consider; to hesitate in deciding; -- sometimes with on, upon, about, concerning.
Desirous: Feeling desire; eagerly wishing; solicitous; eager to obtain; covetous.
Destination: The act of destining or appointing.
Delibation: Act of tasting; a slight trial.
Domite: A grayish variety of trachyte; -- so called from the Puy-de-Dôme in Auvergne, France, where it is found.
Dentine: The dense calcified substance of which teeth are largely composed. It contains less animal matter than bone, and in the teeth of man is situated beneath the enamel.
Dough-baked: Imperfectly baked; hence, not brought to perfection; unfinished; also, of weak or dull understanding.
Dramaturgy: The art of dramatic composition and representation.
Derotremata: The tribe of aquatic Amphibia which includes Amphiuma, Menopoma, etc. They have permanent gill openings, but no external gills; -- called also Cryptobranchiata.
Dogskin: The skin of a dog, or leather made of the skin. Also used adjectively.
desensitize: to rendered insensitive or less sensitive.  Opposite of sensitize.
Demoralize: To corrupt or undermine in morals; to destroy or lessen the effect of moral principles on; to render corrupt or untrustworthy in morals, in discipline, in courage, spirit, etc.; to weaken in spirit or efficiency.
Denominationalist: One imbued with a denominational spirit.
disheartened: made less hopeful or enthusiastic; as, their lack of interest disheartened the instructor.
Duressor: One who subjects another to duress
Denominationalism: A denominational or class spirit or policy; devotion to the interests of a sect or denomination.
Demarch: A chief or ruler of a deme or district in Greece.
Direct current: A current flowing in one direction only; -- distinguished from alternating current. When steady and not pulsating a direct current is often called a continuous current.
Dispute: Verbal controversy; contest by opposing argument or expression of opposing views or claims; controversial discussion; altercation; debate.
Downy: Covered with down, or with pubescence or soft hairs.
Damnation: The state of being damned; condemnation; openly expressed disapprobation.
dental: Of or pertaining to the teeth or to dentistry; as, dental surgery.
Downhaul: A rope to haul down, or to assist in hauling down, a sail; as, a staysail downhaul; a trysail downhaul.
Dispensable: Capable of being dispensed or administered.
diploid: having a number of chromosomes corresponding to two copies of each chromosome; having double the basic number of chromosomes, as seen in a haploid cell.  Contrasted to haploid and polyploid.
digitalize: to record digitally, e. g. on digital tape or compact disks.
Double-faced: Having two faces designed for use; as, a double-faced hammer.
Dentilingual: Produced by applying the tongue to the teeth or to the gums; or representing a sound so formed.
DNA polymerase: an enzyme that catalyzes the formation of DNA from deoxyribonucleoside triphosphates.  Cells contain several types of DNA polymerase, some of which are required for replication of DNA, and are indispensable for multipliation and division of cells.
Dipsas: A serpent whose bite was fabled to produce intense thirst.
Deuterogenic: Of secondary origin; -- said of certain rocks whose material has been derived from older rocks.
disqualified: rendered ineligible by law or rule or provision; as, disqualified from voting.
Devastation: The act of devastating, or the state of being devastated; a laying waste.
Depict: To form a colored likeness of; to represent by a picture; to paint; to portray.
Decil: An aspect or position of two planets, when they are distant from each other a tenth part of the zodiac, or 36°.
disentangled: freed from an entanglement; -- of people or agents.
dynamic RAM: a type of random access memory using circuits that require periodic refresh cycles in order to retain the stored information.  Contrasted to static ram, which maintains the memory state as long as the power is still applied.
datable: That may be dated; having a known or ascertainable date.
Device: That which is devised, or formed by design; a contrivance; an invention; a project; a scheme; often, a scheme to deceive; a stratagem; an artifice.
Denominative: A denominative name or term; denominative verb.
Disestablish: To unsettle; to break up (anything established); to deprive, as a church, of its connection with the state.
Deodand: A personal chattel which had caused the death of a person, and for that reason was given to God, that is, forfeited to the crown, to be applied to pious uses, and distributed in alms by the high almoner. Thus, if a cart ran over a man and killed him, it was forfeited as a deodand.
Disally: To part, as an alliance; to sunder.
Dissettlement: The act of unsettling, or the state of being unsettled.
Depauperate: Falling short of the natural size, from being impoverished or starved.
Differ: To cause to be different or unlike; to set at variance.
Develop: To go through a process of natural evolution or growth, by successive changes from a less perfect to a more perfect or more highly organized state; to advance from a simpler form of existence to one more complex either in structure or function; as, a blossom develops from a bud; the seed develops into a plant; the embryo develops into a well-formed animal; the mind develops year by year.
Dixiecrats: a former political party in the US; formed in 1948 by Southern Democrats opposed to the candidacy of Harry S. Truman.
Dithyrambic: Pertaining to, or resembling, a dithyramb; wild and boisterous.
Disavowal: The act of disavowing, disclaiming, or disowning; rejection and denial.
Drawbar: An openmouthed bar at the end of a car, which receives a coupling link and pin by which the car is drawn. It is usually provided with a spring to give elasticity to the connection between the cars of a train.
deaf-aid: an electronic device which amplifies sound and is worn to compensate for poor hearing.
Deceive: To lead into error; to cause to believe what is false, or disbelieve what is true; to impose upon; to mislead; to cheat; to disappoint; to delude; to insnare.
Disaffirmance: The act of disaffirming; denial; negation.
deformational: of or pertaining to deformation (in all senses).
Distaste: To be distasteful; to taste ill or disagreeable.
Didelphic: Having the uterus double; of or pertaining to the Didelphia.
Didelphia: The subclass of Mammalia which includes the marsupials. See Marsupialia.
Dovecot: A small house or box, raised to a considerable height above the ground, and having compartments, in which domestic pigeons breed; a dove house.
Decimosexto: Having sixteen leaves to a sheet; as, a decimosexto form, book, leaf, size.
double-shade: To double the natural darkness of (a place).
Diaphoretic: A medicine or agent which promotes perspiration.
Detract: To take away a part or something, especially from one's credit; to lessen reputation; to derogate; to defame; -- often with from.
dustman: One whose employment is to remove dirt and refuse; a garbage man.
Dauphiness: The title of the wife of the dauphin.
Diplogenic: Partaking of the nature of two bodies; producing two substances.
Distrustful: Not confident; diffident; wanting confidence or thrust; modest; as, distrustful of ourselves, of one's powers.
Disallowable: Not allowable; not to be suffered.
Discursive: Passing from one thing to another; ranging over a wide field; roving; digressive; desultory.
Dichromate: A salt of chromic acid containing two equivalents of the acid radical to one of the base; -- called also bichromate.
Debauchery: Corruption of fidelity; seduction from virtue, duty, or allegiance.
Desilverization: The act or the process of freeing from silver; also, the condition resulting from the removal of silver.
Declare: To make a declaration, or an open and explicit avowal; to proclaim one's self; -- often with for or against; as, victory declares against the allies.
Dingey: a small boat propelled by oars or sails, used in the East Indies, in sheltered waters.
Dispirit: To deprive of cheerful spirits; to depress the spirits of; to dishearten; to discourage.
Definiteness: The state of being definite; determinateness; precision; certainty.
Deficit: Deficiency in amount or quality; a falling short; lack; as, a deficit in taxes, revenue, etc.
Drunkard: One who habitually drinks strong liquors immoderately; one whose habit it is to get drunk; a toper; a sot.
Dewy: Pertaining to dew; resembling, consisting of, or moist with, dew.
Dactylotheca: The scaly covering of the toes, as in birds.
Dayflower: A genus consisting mostly of tropical perennial herbs (Commelina), having ephemeral flowers.
Dichroscopic: Pertaining to the dichroscope, or to observations with it.
deadening: The act of making something futile and useless (as by routine).
digitalization: the administration of digitalis for the treatment of certain heart disorders.
dementedness: mental deterioration of organic or functional origin.
Divineness: The quality of being divine; superhuman or supreme excellence.
Doxological: Pertaining to doxology; giving praise to God.
dwindling: the act or process of becoming gradually less until little remains; as, there is no greater sadness that the dwindling away of a family.
Deathbird: Tengmalm's or Richardson's owl (Nyctale Tengmalmi); -- so called from a superstition of the North American Indians that its note presages death.
dusty: Filled, covered, or sprinkled with dust; clouded with dust; as, a dusty table;  a dusty attic; also, reducing to dust.
Desirable: Worthy of desire or longing; fitted to excite desire or a wish to possess; pleasing; agreeable.
Disembodied: Divested of a body; ceased to be corporal; incorporeal.
Displayer: One who, or that which, displays.
Dueling: The act or practice of fighting in single combat. Also adj.
Dissyllabize: To form into two syllables; to dissyllabify.
Defend: To ward or fend off; to drive back or away; to repel.
Dace: A small European cyprinoid fish (Leuciscus leuciscus, formerly Squalius leuciscus or Leuciscus vulgaris); -- called also dare.
deep-water: having waters of great depth; as, a deep-water port.
digital computer: a computer that represents information by numerical digits with a fixed number of values; -- most commonly each piece of information is internally represented in binary code, as an array of bits, which are information units each of which can take only two values.  The possible values of each bit are conventionally represented as the numbers 1 or 0.
Designate: To mark out and make known; to point out; to name; to indicate; to show; to distinguish by marks or description; to specify; as, to designate the boundaries of a country; to designate the rioters who are to be arrested.
Diagonal: A right line drawn from one angle to another not adjacent, of a figure of four or more sides, and dividing it into two parts.
Delayer: One who delays; one who lingers.
Didine: Like or pertaining to the genus Didus, or the dodo.
Deads: The substances which inclose the ore on every side.
Dragbar: Same as Drawbar (b). Called also draglink, and drawlink.
Doubler: One who, or that which, doubles.
Decompose: To become resolved or returned from existing combinations; to undergo dissolution; to decay; to rot.
deserved: properly earned; warranted; merited.  Opposite of undeserved.
Dagda: in Irish legend, chief god of the Tuatha De Danann; father of Angus Og and Brigit.
Doughface: A contemptuous nickname for a timid, yielding politician, or one who is easily molded.
Dister: To banish or drive from a country.
Deplumate: Destitute or deprived of features; deplumed.
defusing: The act of deactivating or making ineffective (as a bomb).
Despotat: The station or government of a despot; also, the domain of a despot.
Duck-legged: Having short legs, like a waddling duck; short-legged.
Darwinism: The theory or doctrines put forth by Darwin. See above.
Dowitcher: The red-breasted or gray snipe (Macrorhamphus griseus); -- called also brownback, and grayback.
Drain: The act of draining, or of drawing off; gradual and continuous outflow or withdrawal; as, the drain of specie from a country; the project is a drain on resources.
Ducally: In the manner of a duke, or in a manner becoming the rank of a duke.
Dualist: One who believes in dualism; a ditheist.
Discusser: One who discusses; one who sifts or examines.
Deracination: The act of pulling up by the roots; eradication.
Degenerate: To be or grow worse than one's kind, or than one was originally; hence, to be inferior; to grow poorer, meaner, or more vicious; to decline in good qualities; to deteriorate.
Diffidence: The state of being diffident; distrust; want of confidence; doubt of the power, ability, or disposition of others.
Disturbance: An interruption of a state of peace or quiet; derangement of the regular course of things; disquiet; disorder; as, a disturbance of religious exercises; a disturbance of the galvanic current.
Decarbonization: The action or process of depriving a substance of carbon.
Divulgation: The act of divulging or publishing.
Draughtsman: One who draws pleadings or other writings.
Dipleidoscope: An instrument for determining the time of apparent noon. It consists of two mirrors and a plane glass disposed in the form of a prism, so that, by the reflections of the sun's rays from their surfaces, two images are presented to the eye, moving in opposite directions, and coinciding at the instant the sun's center is on the meridian.
Drongo: A passerine bird of the family Dicruridæ. They are usually black with a deeply forked tail. They are natives of Asia, Africa, and Australia; -- called also drongo shrikes.
Docetic: Pertaining to, held by, or like, the Docetæ.
Dinnerless: Having no dinner; as, the naughty child was sent to bed dinnerless.
Debauchee: One who is given to intemperance or bacchanalian excesses; a man habitually lewd; a libertine.
Direction: The act of directing, of aiming, regulating, guiding, or ordering; guidance; management; superintendence; administration; as, the direction o&unr_; public affairs or of a bank.
Dogmatism: The manner or character of a dogmatist; arrogance or positiveness in stating opinion.
Dochmiac: Pertaining to, or containing, the dochmius.
Debaucher: One who debauches or corrupts others; especially, a seducer to lewdness.
Diarthrosis: A form of articulation which admits of considerable motion; a complete joint; abarticulation. See Articulation.
decreased: made less in size or amount or degree.  Opposite of increased.
Dogmatist: One who dogmatizes; one who speaks dogmatically; a bold and arrogant advancer of principles.
downsizing: the reduction of expeditures and personnel in order to become financial stable; -- of businesses.
Discifloral: Bearing the stamens on a discoid outgrowth of the receptacle; -- said of a subclass of plants.  Cf. Calycifloral.
Diversiform: Of a different form; of varied forms.
Dodecane: Any one of a group of thick oily hydrocarbons, C12H26, of the paraffin series.
Dambose: A crystalline variety of fruit sugar obtained from dambonite.
Disacryl: A white amorphous substance obtained as a polymeric modification of acrolein.
D\u00e9bris: Broken and detached fragments, taken collectively; especially, fragments detached from a rock or mountain, and piled up at the base.
Divination: The act of divining; a foreseeing or foretelling of future events; the pretended art discovering secret or future by preternatural means.
Duykerbok: A small South African antelope (Cephalous mergens); -- called also impoon, and deloo.
Disincorporation: Deprivation of the rights and privileges of a corporation.
Diamagnetically: In the manner of, or according to, diamagnetism.
defenestration: the act of throwing (something or someone) out of a window.
Dentalium: A genus of marine mollusks belonging to the Scaphopoda, having a tubular conical shell.
Digamist: One who marries a second time; a deuterogamist.
Divisor: The number by which the dividend is divided.
Dicksonia: A genus of tree ferns of temperate Australasia having bipinnatifid or tripinnatifid fronds and usually marginal sori; in some classification systems it is placed in the family Cyatheaceae.
Disembellish: To deprive of embellishment; to disadorn.
Dextrose: A sirupy, or white crystalline, variety of sugar, C6H12O6 (so called from turning the plane of polarization to the right), occurring in many ripe fruits, and also called glucose. Dextrose and levulose are obtained by the inversion of cane sugar or sucrose, and hence the mixture is called called invert sugar. Dextrose is chiefly obtained by the action of heat and acids on starch, and hence called also starch sugar. It is also formed from starchy food by the action of the amylolytic ferments of saliva and pancreatic juice.
Druidism: The system of religion, philosophy, and instruction, received and taught by the Druids; the rites and ceremonies of the Druids.
Dissentiate: To throw into a state of dissent.
Dangleberry: A dark blue, edible berry with a white bloom, and its shrub (Gaylussacia frondosa) closely allied to the common huckleberry. The bush is also called blue tangle, and is found from New England to Kentucky, and southward.
Deficiency: The state of being deficient; inadequacy; want; failure; imperfection; shortcoming; defect.
Devitation: An avoiding or escaping; also, a warning.
Dachshund: One of a breed of small dogs with short crooked legs, and long body; -- called also badger dog. There are two kinds, the rough-haired and the smooth-haired.
Demonomagy: Magic in which the aid of demons is invoked; black or infernal magic.
Dissection: The act of dissecting an animal or plant; as, dissection of the human body was held sacrilege till the time of Francis I.
desynchronization: a process causing an absence of synchronization; the relation that exists when things occur at unrelated times; as, the stimulus produced a desynchronizing of the brain waves.
Decadal: Pertaining to ten; consisting of tens.
dissipate: To scatter completely; to disperse and cause to disappear; -- used esp. of the dispersion of things that can never again be collected or restored.
Daymare: A kind of incubus which occurs during wakefulness, attended by the peculiar pressure on the chest which characterizes nightmare.
drugstore: a retail shop where medicine and other articles are sold.
Dertrotheca: The horny covering of the end of the bill of birds.
donkeys tail: a Mexican plant (Sedum morganianum) bearing small rose-colored flowers; called also burro's tail, horse's tail, and lamb's tail.
Dilation: The act of dilating, or the state of being dilated; expansion; dilatation.
Dermobranchiata: A group of nudibranch mollusks without special gills.
Discompose: To disarrange; to interfere with; to disturb; to disorder; to unsettle; to break up.
Dermobranchiate: Having the skin modified to serve as a gill.
dilly: something remarkable, highly unusual, or exceptionally effective; as, a dilly of a movie; when I make a mistake, it's a dilly.
Demiwolf: A half wolf; a mongrel dog, between a dog and a wolf.
Dapple: To variegate with spots; to spot.
Disencumbrance: Freedom or deliverance from encumbrance, or anything burdensome or troublesome.
Daisied: Full of daisies; adorned with daisies.
Demur: Stop; pause; hesitation as to proceeding; suspense of decision or action; scruple.
Dermopteran: An insect which has the anterior pair of wings coriaceous, and does not use them in flight, as the earwig.
Depository: A place where anything is deposited for sale or keeping; as, warehouse is a depository for goods; a clerk's office is a depository for records.
deep fat: Hot liquified fat used to deep-fry food.  See deep-fry.
Disseminator: One who, or that which, disseminates, spreads, or propagates; as, disseminators of disease.
Denote: To mark out plainly; to signify by a visible sign; to serve as the sign or name of; to indicate; to point out; as, the hands of the clock denote the hour.
Danseuse: A professional female dancer; a woman who dances at a public exhibition as in a ballet.
Determent: The act of deterring; also, that which deters.
Dentile: A small tooth, like that of a saw.
Discordable: That may produce discord; disagreeing; discordant.
Demisable: Capable of being leased; as, a demisable estate.
Distillment: Distillation; the substance obtained by distillation.
dosimeter badge: a dosimeter cosisting of a radiation-sensitive material, such as film, worn in a small package on a person's clothing, to record the accumulated radiation exposure of the person over a period of time; -- used to monitor the exposure of individuals, such as workers in a nuclear power plant, to ionizing radiation.
dalton: a unit of mass, approximately 1.66 x 10-24 grams; -- it is approximately equal to the mass of one hydrogen atom, but the exact value differs slightly as used in physics and chemistry. It is used mostly to describe the size of proteins and nucleic acids in biochemistry.
Droughty: Characterized by drought; wanting rain; arid; adust.
Destitution: The state of being deprived of anything; the state or condition of being destitute, needy, or without resources; deficiency; lack; extreme poverty; utter want; as, the inundation caused general destitution.
Drupe: A fruit consisting of pulpy, coriaceous, or fibrous exocarp, without valves, containing a nut or stone with a kernel. The exocarp is succulent in the plum, cherry, apricot, peach, etc.; dry and subcoriaceous in the almond; and fibrous in the cocoanut.
Dartars: A kind of scab or ulceration on the skin of lambs.
digitize: To finger; as, to digitize a pen.
Depilation: Act of pulling out or removing the hair; unhairing.
Diabolism: Character, action, or principles appropriate to the devil.
Dysphoria: Impatience under affliction; morbid restlessness; dissatisfaction; the fidgets.
Distress: To cause pain or anguish to; to pain; to oppress with calamity; to afflict; to harass; to make miserable.
Diapophysis: The dorsal transverse, or tubercular, process of a vertebra. See Vertebra.
Deprovincialize: To divest of provincial quality or characteristics.
Doves-foot: A small annual species of Geranium, native in England; -- so called from the shape of the leaf.
Diluter: One who, or that which, dilutes or makes thin, more liquid, or weaker.
Desultoriness: The quality of being desultory or without order or method; unconnectedness.
Dynamiting: Destroying by dynamite, for political ends.
Despoil: To strip, as of clothing; to divest or unclothe.
Deadener: One who, or that which, deadens or checks.
dark-brown: of a color similar to that of wood or earth.
Deglaze: To remove the glaze from, as pottery or porcelain, so as to give a dull finish.
Demonic: Of or pertaining to a demon or to demons; demoniac.
Directory: A collection or body of directions, rules, or ordinances; esp., a book of directions for the conduct of worship; as, the Directory used by the nonconformists instead of the Prayer Book.
D\u0153glic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, the dœgling; as, dœglic acid (Chem.), an oily substance resembling oleic acid.
Dipterous: Having two wings, as certain insects; belonging to the order Diptera.
Dashism: The character of making ostentatious or blustering parade or show.
dethronement: Deposal from a throne; deposition from regal power.
Dorsiventral: Having distinct upper and lower surfaces, as most common leaves. The leaves of the iris are not dorsiventral.
Demosthenes: a famous Grecian orator, born circa 385 BC, died circa 322 BC.
deprecable: That may or should be deprecated.
Dyslogistic: Unfavorable; not commendatory; -- opposed to eulogistic.
Delaware: one of the thirteen original states of the United States of America.
Drakestone: A flat stone so thrown along the surface of water as to skip from point to point before it sinks; also, the sport of so throwing stones; -- sometimes called ducks and drakes.
Dryly: In a dry manner; not succulently; without interest; without sympathy; coldly.
Detecter: One who, or that which, detects or brings to light; one who finds out what another attempts to conceal; a detector.
Deism: The doctrine or creed of a deist; the belief or system of those who acknowledge the existence of one God, but deny revelation.
Diagnosticate: To make a diagnosis of; to recognize by its symptoms, as a disease.
Debasement: The act of debasing or the state of being debased.
Deminatured: Having half the nature of another.
Deist: One who believes in the existence of a God, but denies revealed religion; a freethinker.
Devilwood: A kind of tree (Osmanthus Americanus), allied to the European olive.
Detent: That which locks or unlocks a movement; a catch, pawl, or dog; especially, in clockwork, the catch which locks and unlocks the wheelwork in striking.
Dermoneural: Pertaining to, or in relation with, both dermal and neural structures; as, the dermoneural spines or dorsal fin rays of fishes.
Dominion: Sovereign or supreme authority; the power of governing and controlling; independent right of possession, use, and control; sovereignty; supremacy.
Davenport: A kind of small writing table, generally somewhat ornamental, and forming a piece of furniture for the parlor or boudoir.
Distasteful: Unpleasant or disgusting to the taste; nauseous; loathsome.
Diskless: Having no disk; appearing as a point and not expanded into a disk, as the image of a faint star in a telescope.
Doorsill: The sill or threshold of a door.
Deoxidizer: That which removes oxygen; hence, a reducing agent; as, nascent hydrogen is a deoxidizer.
Diglyph: A projecting face like the triglyph, but having only two channels or grooves sunk in it.
defeatism: acceptance of the inevitability of defeat.
death-roll: a list of persons killed in a war or other disaster.
Disappear: To cease to appear or to be perceived; to pass from view, gradually or suddenly; to vanish; to be no longer seen; as, darkness disappears at the approach of light; a ship disappears as she sails from port.
davallia: any fern of the genus Davallia; they have scaly creeping rhizomes.
Dimity: A cotton fabric employed for hangings and furniture coverings, and formerly used for women's under-garments. It is of many patterns, both plain and twilled, and occasionally is printed in colors.
Dies non: A day on which courts are not held, as Sunday or any legal holiday.
Dennet: A light, open, two-wheeled carriage for one horse; a kind of gig.
Dogmaticalness: The quality of being dogmatical; positiveness.
Descendible: Admitting descent; capable of being descended.
Disinfect: To free from infectious or contagious matter; to destroy putrefaction; to purify; to make innocuous.
Disk clutch: A friction clutch in which the gripping surfaces are disks or more or less resemble disks.
Descendant: One who descends, as offspring, however remotely; -- correlative to ancestor or ascendant.
deflate: To reduce from an inflated condition; used literally and metaphorically; as, to deflate a tire; to deflate expectations.
Dal segno: A direction to go back to the sign &unr_; and repeat from thence to the close. See Segno.
Diagnostics: That part of medicine which has to do with ascertaining the nature of diseases by means of their symptoms or signs.
Deleble: Capable of being blotted out or erased.
Disordered: Thrown into disorder; deranged; as, a disordered house, judgment.
Displacement: The act of displacing, or the state of being displaced; a putting out of place.
Dissepiment: A separating tissue; a partition; a septum.
Dabster: One who is skilled; a master of his business; a proficient; an adept.
Dirtiness: The state of being dirty; filthiness; foulness; nastiness; baseness; sordidness.
Denticulation: The state of being set with small notches or teeth.
Discriminate: To make a difference or distinction; to distinguish accurately; as, in judging of evidence, we should be careful to discriminate between probability and slight presumption.
Depredatory: Tending or designed to depredate; characterized by depredation; plundering; as, a depredatory incursion.
Department store: A store keeping a great variety of goods which are arranged in several departments.
Diesel: A type of internal-combustion engine in which the air drawn in by the suction stroke is so highly compressed that the heat generated ignites the fuel (usually a heavy oil), the fuel being automatically sprayed into the cylinder under pressure. The Diesel engine has a very high thermal efficiency.
Daniel: A Hebrew prophet distinguished for sagacity and ripeness of judgment in youth; hence, a sagacious and upright judge.
Derange: To put out of place, order, or rank; to disturb the proper arrangement or order of; to throw into disorder, confusion, or embarrassment; to disorder; to disarrange; as, to derange the plans of a commander, or the affairs of a nation.
Disacquaint: To render unacquainted; to make unfamiliar.
Decagynia: A Linnæan order of plants characterized by having ten styles.
Decarbonize: To deprive of carbon; as, to decarbonize steel; to decarbonize the blood.
Divorce: To dissolve the marriage contract of, either wholly or partially; to separate by divorce.
Detector bar: A bar, connected with a switch, longer than the distance between any two consecutive wheels of a train (45 to 50 feet), laid inside a rail and operated by the wheels so that the switch cannot be thrown until all the train is past the switch.
Delftware: Pottery made at the city of Delft in Holland; hence:
Delver: One who digs, as with a spade.
Debater: One who debates; one given to argument; a disputant; a controvertist.
Drake: Wild oats, brome grass, or darnel grass; -- called also drawk, dravick, and drank.
draggled: limp and soiled as if dragged in the mud.
Degrease: To remove grease or fatty matter from, as wool or silk.
Deerberry: A shrub of the blueberry group (Vaccinium stamineum); also, its bitter, greenish white berry; -- called also squaw huckleberry.
Deskwork: Work done at a desk, as by a clerk or writer.
Disoccident: To turn away from the west; to throw out of reckoning as to longitude.
Dhaulagiri: a mountain in Nepal, 26,810 feet high.
do-it-yourselfer: a person who often makes objects typically made by professionals, or performs repairs typically performed by professionals, though not having professional training in the relevant art.  The term is used mostly to refer to activities related to maintaining a home.
Dilator: One who, or that which, widens or expands.
Disposer: One who, or that which, disposes; a regulator; a director; a bestower.
Damiana: A Mexican drug, used as an aphrodisiac.
Desirefulness: The state of being desireful; eagerness to obtain and possess.
Danubian: Pertaining to, or bordering on, the river Danube.
Dissolver: One who, or that which, has power to dissolve or dissipate.
Drinkable: Capable of being drunk; suitable for drink; potable. Macaulay. Also used substantively, esp. in the plural.
dyers broom: small Eurasian shrub (Genista tinctoria) having clusters of yellow flowers that yield a dye; common as weed in England and U.S.; sometimes grown as an ornamental.
disparaging: expressing a low opinion of; same as derogatory; as, disparaging remarks about the new house.
Dimorph: Either one of the two forms of a dimorphous substance; as, calcite and aragonite are dimorphs.
dibs: A sweet preparation or treacle of grape juice, much used in the East.
Dermatography: An anatomical description of, or treatise on, the skin.
Diorite: An igneous, crystalline in structure, consisting essentially of a triclinic feldspar and hornblende. It includes part of what was called greenstone.
Daggle: To run, go, or trail one's self through water, mud, or slush; to draggle.
Djiboutian: A native or inhabitant of Djibouti.
Decorum: Propriety of manner or conduct; grace arising from suitableness of speech and behavior to one's own character, or to the place and occasion; decency of conduct; seemliness; that which is seemly or suitable.
Duplicate: To double; to fold; to render double.
Diffusivity: Tendency to become diffused; tendency, as of heat, to become equalized by spreading through a conducting medium.
Dugway: A way or road dug through a hill, or sunk below the surface of the land.
Diselenide: A selenide containing two atoms of selenium in each molecule.
Drawfiling: The process of smooth filing by working the file sidewise instead of lengthwise.
Dentalism: The quality of being formed by the aid of the teeth.
Disapparel: To disrobe; to strip of apparel; to make naked.
Durbar: An audience hall; the court of a native prince; a state levee; a formal reception of native princes, given by the governor general of India.
Determinist: One who believes in determinism. Also adj.; as, determinist theories.
defrost: To become free of frost or ice; as, it took four hours for the refrigerator to defrost.
Dative: The dative case. See Dative, a., 1.
Debacle: A breaking or bursting forth; a violent rush or flood of waters which breaks down opposing barriers, and hurls forward and disperses blocks of stone and other débris.
Determinism: The doctrine that the will is not free, but is inevitably and invincibly determined by motives, preceding events, and natural laws.
Disarrangement: The act of disarranging, or the state of being disarranged; confusion; disorder.
Dueler: One who engages in a duel.
Donator: One who makes a gift; a donor; a giver.
detailed: Developed or executed with care and in minute detail; as, a detailed plan.
Disquietness: Disturbance of quiet in body or mind; restlessness; uneasiness.
Divinity calf: Calf stained dark brown and worked without gilding, often used for theological books.
Despiser: One who despises; a contemner; a scorner.
Dishevel: To be spread in disorder or hang negligently, as the hair.
Denunciator: One who denounces, publishes, or proclaims, especially intended or coming evil; one who threatens or accuses.
Dasymeter: An instrument for testing the density of gases, consisting of a thin glass globe, which is weighed in the gas or gases, and then in an atmosphere of known density.
Dite: To prepare for action or use; to make ready; to dight.
Diversion: The act of turning aside from any course, occupation, or object; as, the diversion of a stream from its channel; diversion of the mind from business.
Dalesman: One living in a dale; -- a term applied particularly to the inhabitants of the valleys in the north of England, Norway, etc.
Discovery: The action of discovering; exposure to view; laying open; showing; as, the discovery of a plot.
Driftpiece: An upright or curved piece of timber connecting the plank sheer with the gunwale; also, a scroll terminating a rail.
Diaphonics: The doctrine of refracted sound; diacoustics.
Debouch: To march out from a wood, defile, or other confined spot, into open ground; to issue.
Dissolve: To waste away; to be dissipated; to be decomposed or broken up.
Dispositioned: Having (such) a disposition; -- used in compounds; as, well-dispositioned.
Direct: A character, thus [&unr_;], placed at the end of a staff on the line or space of the first note of the next staff, to apprise the performer of its situation.
Dipsey: A sinker attached to a fishing line; also, a line having several branches, each with such a sinker, used in deep-sea fishing.
Denitration: A disengaging, or removal, of nitric acid.
Desilver: To deprive of silver; as, to desilver lead.
Disembark: To go ashore out of a ship or boat; to leave a ship; to debark.
Driftless: Having no drift or direction; without aim; purposeless.
Dantean: Relating to, emanating from or resembling, the poet Dante or his writings.
Disobedience: Neglect or refusal to obey; violation of a command or prohibition.
Duces tecum: A judicial process commanding a person to appear in court and bring with him some piece of evidence or other thing to be produced to the court.
Diphygenic: Having two modes of embryonic development.
Dockage: A charge for the use of a dock.
Damnableness: The state or quality of deserving damnation; execrableness.
Degradement: Deprivation of rank or office; degradation.
Deadhead: One who receives free tickets for theaters, public conveyances, etc.
dolma: a dish composed of well-seasoned rice (with nuts or currants of minced lamb) simmered or braised in stock, stuffed into tomatoes or green peppers, or wrapped in grape leaves; -- popular in the near east.
dodger: One who dodges or evades; one who plays fast and loose, or uses tricky devices.
Distraint: The act or proceeding of seizing personal property by distress.
Debar: To cut off from entrance, as if by a bar or barrier; to preclude; to hinder from approach, entry, or enjoyment; to shut out or exclude; to deny or refuse; -- with from, and sometimes with of.
dorky: stupid, socially inept, unfashionable, or ridiculous; -- always used disparagingly.
Discontinuor: One who deprives another of the possession of an estate by discontinuance. See Discontinuance, 2.
desegregation: the action of incorporating a racial or religious group into a community; the elimination of laws, regulations, or customs which prohibit members of a specific racial or national group from using certain locations, organizations, or facilities.
Dyeing: The process or art of fixing coloring matters permanently and uniformly in the fibers of wool, cotton, etc.
Dermal: Pertaining to the integument or skin of animals; dermic; as, the dermal secretions.
Delapsion: A falling down, or out of place; prolapsion.
Diplomacy: The art and practice of conducting negotiations between nations (particularly in securing treaties), including the methods and forms usually employed.
Definable: Capable of being defined, limited, or explained; determinable; describable by definition; ascertainable; as, definable limits; definable distinctions or regulations; definable words.
Draglink: A link connecting the cranks of two shafts.
Drawing knife: A woodworker`s and joiner's tool having a blade with a handle at each end, used to shave off surfaces, by drawing it toward one; a shave; -- called also drawshave, and drawing shave.
Delusive: Apt or fitted to delude; tending to mislead the mind; deceptive; beguiling; delusory; as, delusive arts; a delusive dream.
Digenea: A division of Trematoda in which alternate generations occur, the immediate young not resembling their parents.
Dynamiter: One who uses dynamite; esp., one who uses it for the destruction of life and property.
Diaphoresis: Perspiration, or an increase of perspiration.
Descry: Discovery or view, as of an army seen at a distance.
Dirigible: Capable of being directed; steerable; as, a dirigible balloon.
Depressed: Pressed or forced down; lowed; sunk; dejected; dispirited; sad; humbled.
doyley: a small round piece of linen place under a dish or bowl; same as doily.
diningroom: a room used for dining.  In a residence, it usually contains a dining table and some furniture, such as a buffet or sideboard, for storing tableware and dining utensils.
Dwelling: Habitation; place or house in which a person lives; abode; domicile.
Dextrorsal: Turning from the left to the right, in the ascending line, as in the spiral inclination of the stem of the common morning-glory; as, dextrorse vines.
Dvergr: A dwarf supposed to dwell in rocks and hills and to be skillful in working metals.
Da\u00efra: Any of several valuable estates of the Egyptian khedive or his family. The most important are the Da"i*ra Sa"ni*eh (sä"n&ibreve_;*&ebreve_;), or Da"i*ra Sa"ni*yeh, and the Da"i*ra Khas"sa, administered by the khedive's European bondholders, and known collectively as the Daira, or the Daira estates.
Decade: A group or division of ten; esp., a period of ten years; a decennium; as, a decade of years or days; a decade of soldiers; the second decade of Livy.
dilly-dally: To loiter or trifle; to waste time.
Depurgatory: Serving to purge; tending to cleanse or purify.
Downstream: Down the stream; as, floating downstream.
Decrescendo: With decreasing volume of sound; -- a direction to performers, either written upon the staff (abbreviated Dec., or Decresc.), or indicated by the sign.
Diametric: Of or pertaining to a diameter.
Dow-Jones Index: an index of certain stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange, computed by the Dow Jones publishing company as a weighted average of the prices of specific stocks in certain categories.  Three indices are maintained, the Industrials, the Transportations, and the Utilities.  When used without qualification, the term usually refers to the Dow Jones Industrial Average.
Dissentious: Marked by dissensions; apt to breed discord; quarrelsome; contentious; factious.
dyed-in-the-wool: thoroughly imbued; thoroughgoing; uncompromising; complete; unmitigated; through-and-through.
Disfurnish: To deprive of that with which anything is furnished (furniture, equipments, etc.); to strip; to render destitute; to divest.
Delignate: To clear or strip of wood (by cutting down trees).
Dermoptera: The division of insects which includes the earwigs (Forticulidæ).
Disclaimer: One who disclaims, disowns, or renounces.
Designedly: By design; purposely; intentionally; -- opposed to accidentally, ignorantly, or inadvertently.
Dobson: The aquatic larva of a large neuropterous insect (Corydalus cornutus), used as bait in angling. See Hellgamite.
Dobby: An apparatus resembling a Jacquard for weaving small figures (usually about 12 - 16 threads, seldom more than 36 - 40 threads).
deafening: extremely loud; so loud as to cause deafness; as, a disco with rock music played at a deafening volume.
Dedans: A division, at one end of a tennis court, for spectators.
Dermatopathic: Of or pertaining to skin diseases, or their cure.
Dandie: One of a breed of small terriers; -- called also Dandie Dinmont.
Dispose: Disposal; ordering; management; power or right of control.
Dispost: To eject from a post; to displace.
deeds: performance of moral or religious acts; salvation is not by deeds, but by faith; to do good deeds.
Decurrent: Extending downward; -- said of a leaf whose base extends downward and forms a wing along the stem.
Desecate: To cut, as with a scythe; to mow.
Dissimilarly: In a dissimilar manner; in a varied style.
Dulcamara: A plant (Solanum Dulcamara). See Bittersweet, n., 3 (a).
Dermestes: A genus of coleopterous insects, the larvæ of which feed animal substances. They are very destructive to dries meats, skins, woolens, and furs. The most common species is Dermestes lardarius, known as the bacon beetle.
Dudder: A peddler or hawker, especially of cheap and flashy goods pretended to be smuggled; a duffer.
Dux: The scholastic name for the theme or subject of a fugue, the answer being called the comes, or companion.
Demogorgon: A mysterious, terrible, and evil divinity, regarded by some as the author of creation, by others as a great magician who was supposed to command the spirits of the lower world. See Gorgon.
Disarm: To deprive of arms; to take away the weapons of; to deprive of the means of attack or defense; to render defenseless.
Distensibility: The quality or capacity of being distensible.
Double-entendre: A word or expression admitting of a double interpretation, one of which is often obscure or indelicate.
Demissionary: Pertaining to transfer or conveyance; as, a demissionary deed.
Desmodont: A member of a group of South American blood-sucking bats, of the genera Desmodus and Diphylla. See Vampire.
digitoxin: A steroid glycoside, one of the cardiotonic chemical substances which is extracted from the foxglove.  It is a white, crystalline substance (C41H64O13), and is a 3-substituted triglucoside of a steroid, related structurally to digitalin and digoxin.  It is used as a cardiotonic for treatment of certain heart conditions, such as congestive heart failure.  Chemically it is (3β,5β)-3-[(O-2,6-Dideoxy-β-D-ribo-hexopyranosyl-(1→4)-O-2,6-dideoxy-β-D-ribo-hexopyranosyl-(1→4)-2,6-dideoxy-β-D-ribo-hexopyranosyl)oxy]-14-hydroxy-card-20(22)-enolide.  The related compounds digitalin and digoxin are also extracted from the foxglove (Digitalis lanata and Digitalis purpurea).  The class of steroid glycosides having cardiotonic properties are refered to as the cardiac glycoside group.
Dramatic: Of or pertaining to the drama; as, dramatic arts.
Drosera: A genus of low perennial or biennial plants, the leaves of which are beset with gland-tipped bristles. See Sundew.
darling: Dearly beloved; regarded with especial kindness and tenderness; favorite.
Disnaturalize: To make alien; to deprive of the privileges of birth.
Di\u0153cian: Having the sexes in two separate individuals; -- applied to plants in which the female flowers occur on one individual and the male flowers on another of the same species, and to animals in which the ovum is produced by one individual and the sperm cell by another; -- opposed to monœcious.
Disaffection: State of being disaffected; alienation or want of affection or good will, esp. toward those in authority; unfriendliness; dislike.
Deduction: Act or process of deducing or inferring.
Dispraise: The act of dispraising; detraction; blame censure; reproach; disparagement.
Dodecagynia: A Linnæan order of plants having twelve styles.
Dragons blood: See Dragon's blood, Dragon's head, etc., under Dragon.
Defrauder: One who defrauds; a cheat; an embezzler; a peculator.
Decillion: According to the English notation, a million involved to the tenth power, or a unit with sixty ciphers annexed; according to the French and American notation, a thousand involved to the eleventh power, or a unit with thirty-three ciphers annexed. [See the Note under Numeration.]
Drooper: One who, or that which, droops.
Defrayal: The act of defraying; payment; as, the defrayal of necessary costs.
Dipyre: A mineral of the scapolite group; -- so called from the double effect of fire upon it, in fusing it, and rendering it phosphorescent.
Deterrence: That which deters; a deterrent; a hindrance.
Derivation: A leading or drawing off of water from a stream or source.
discombobulate: to cause to be confused; confuse emotionally.
Delibate: To taste; to take a sip of; to dabble in.
Dugong: An aquatic herbivorous mammal (Halicore dugong), of the order Sirenia, allied to the manatee, but with a bilobed tail. It inhabits the Red Sea, Indian Ocean, East Indies, and Australia.
Dissocial: Unfriendly to society; contracted; selfish; as, dissocial feelings.
Dyscrasite: A mineral consisting of antimony and silver.
Dissent: The act of dissenting; difference of opinion; refusal to adopt something proposed; nonagreement, nonconcurrence, or disagreement.
damselfish: small brilliantly colored tropical marine fishes of coral reefs.
Diagrammatic: Pertaining to, or of the nature of, a diagram; showing by diagram.
Dermestoid: Pertaining to or resembling the genus Dermestes.
death knell: A stroke or tolling of a bell, announcing a death; a knell{1}.
Diswitted: Deprived of wits or understanding; distracted.
Dreadnought: A British battleship, completed in 1906 -- 1907, having an armament consisting of ten 12-inch guns mounted in turrets, and of twenty-four 12-pound quick-fire guns for protection against torpedo boats. This was the first battleship of the type characterized by a main armament of big guns all of the same caliber. She had a displacement of 17,900 tons at load draft, and a speed of 21 knots per hour.
Debrief: to interrogate (a person) who has recently experienced an event, to obtain information about that experience; -- used especially of military pilots or diplomatic agents who have just returned from a mission.
Discredit: To refuse credence to; not to accept as true; to disbelieve; as, the report is discredited.
Dambonite: A white, crystalline, sugary substance obtained from an African caoutchouc.
Discerner: One who, or that which, discerns, distinguishes, perceives, or judges; as, a discerner of truth, of right and wrong.
Dash: Violent striking together of two bodies; collision; crash.
Degenerationist: A believer in the theory of degeneration, or hereditary degradation of type; as, the degenerationists hold that savagery is the result of degeneration from a superior state.
Dialectics: That branch of logic which teaches the rules and modes of reasoning; the application of logical principles to discursive reasoning; the science or art of discriminating truth from error; logical discussion.
Disordination: The state of being in disorder; derangement; confusion.
Diathesis: Bodily condition or constitution, esp. a morbid habit which predisposes to a particular disease, or class of diseases.
Debenture stock: The debt or series of debts, collectively, represented by a series of debentures; a debt secured by a trust deed of property for the benefit of the holders of shares in the debt or of a series of debentures. By the terms of much debenture stock the holders are not entitled to demand payment until the winding up of the company or default in payment; in the case of railway debentures, they cannot demand payment of the principal, and the debtor company cannot redeem the stock, except by authority of an act of Parliament.
dagga: a relatively nontoxic South African herb (Leonotis leonurus) smoked like tobacco.
Drainage: A draining; a gradual flowing off of any liquid; also, that which flows out of a drain.
Discard: The act of discarding; also, the card or cards discarded.
Diamine: A compound containing two amido groups united with one or more basic or positive radicals, -- as contrasted with a diamide.
Decadent: One that is decadent, or deteriorating; esp., one characterized by, or exhibiting, the qualities of those who are degenerating to a lower type; -- specif. applied to a certain school of modern French writers.
Disshiver: To shiver or break in pieces.
decentralizing: causing a dispersion or movement away from the center; -- used especially of power or administrative functions.  Opposite of centralizing.
Denunciate: To denounce; to condemn publicly or solemnly.
Drencher: One who, or that which, west or steeps.
Deprecation: The act of deprecating; a praying against evil; prayer that an evil may be removed or prevented.
Dirt: To make foul of filthy; to dirty.
Dogmatics: The science which treats of Christian doctrinal theology.
Dirl: To thrill; to vibrate; to penetrate.
Dural: Pertaining to the dura, or dura mater.
Dewlap: The pendulous skin under the neck of an ox, which laps or licks the dew in grazing.
Discharger: One who, or that which, discharges. Specifically, in electricity, an instrument for discharging a Leyden jar, or electrical battery, by making a connection between the two surfaces; a discharging rod.
Diseasefulness: The quality of being diseaseful; trouble; trial.
D\u00e9bouch\u00e9: A place for exit; an outlet; hence, a market for goods.
Diarthrodial: Relating to diarthrosis, or movable articulations.
Displume: To strip of, or as of, a plume, or plumes; to deprive of decoration; to dishonor; to degrade.
disparagingly: In a manner to disparage or dishonor; slightingly.
Decoy: Anything intended to lead into a snare; a lure that deceives and misleads into danger, or into the power of an enemy; a bait.
Demarcate: To mark by bounds; to set the limits of; to separate; to discriminate.
deactivate: To make inactive; to render ineffective; as, to deactivate a bomb; to deactivate a machine; to deactivate the alarm.
Disorganize: To destroy the organic structure or regular system of (a government, a society, a party, etc.); to break up (what is organized); to throw into utter disorder; to disarrange.
Deathless: Not subject to death, destruction, or extinction; immortal; undying; imperishable; as, deathless beings; deathless fame.
Demi-rilievo: Half relief; sculpture in relief of which the figures project from the background by one half their full roundness.
Disadvise: To advise against; to dissuade from.
Discouragement: The act of discouraging, or the state of being discouraged; depression or weakening of confidence; dejection.
Disinherit: To cut off from an inheritance or from hereditary succession; to prevent, as an heir, from coming into possession of any property or right, which, by law or custom, would devolve on him in the course of descent.
Diamond-shaped: Shaped like a diamond or rhombus.
Disaggregation: The separation of an aggregate body into its component parts.
dramatization: Act of dramatizing; a dramatic representation.
Discolor: To alter the natural hue or color of; to change to a different color; to stain; to tinge; as, a drop of wine will discolor water; silver is discolored by sea water.
Defecation: The act of separating from impurities, as lees or dregs; purification.
Diner-out: One who often takes his dinner away from home, or in company.
Dentate-ciliate: Having the margin dentate and also ciliate or fringed with hairs.
Defilade: To raise, as a rampart, so as to shelter interior works commanded from some higher point.
Doloroso: Plaintive; pathetic; -- used adverbially as a musical direction.
Dispauperize: To free a state of pauperism, or from paupers.
Dissuasive: Tending to dissuade or divert from a measure or purpose; dehortatory; as, dissuasive advice.
Disconsent: To differ; to disagree; to dissent.
Defilading: The art or act of determining the directions and heights of the lines of rampart with reference to the protection of the interior from exposure to an enemy's fire from any point within range, or from any works which may be erected.
devil: To make like a devil; to invest with the character of a devil.
disowning: the refusal to acknowledge (something or somebody) as one's own.
Damask: To decorate in a way peculiar to Damascus or attributed to Damascus; particularly: (a) with flowers and rich designs, as silk; (b) with inlaid lines of gold, etc., or with a peculiar marking or “water,” as metal. See Damaskeen.
dacoity: The practice of gang robbery in India; robbery committed by dacoits.
Disgusting: That causes disgust; sickening; offensive; revolting.
Dissecting: Dividing or separating the parts of an animal or vegetable body; as, a dissecting aneurism, one which makes its way between or within the coats of an artery.
Duodenal: Of or pertaining to the duodenum; as, duodenal digestion.
Dicrotic: Of or pertaining to dicrotism; as, a dicrotic pulse.
Drupel: A small drupe, as one of the pulpy grains of the blackberry.
dried-out: thoroughly dried; having no moisture remaining.
Doliolidae: a natural family of oceanic tunicates.
Dromatherium: A small extinct triassic mammal from North Carolina, the earliest yet found in America.
decor: the layout, style, and furnishings of a livable interior.
Defibrination: The act or process of depriving of fibrin.
Derogation: The act of derogating, partly repealing, or lessening in value; disparagement; detraction; depreciation; -- followed by of, from, or to.
Detrain: To alight, or to cause to alight, from a railway train.
Dentistic: Pertaining to dentistry or to dentists.
Dicksoniaceae: A family of plants comprising the tree ferns; it includes the genera Dicksonia; Cibotium; Culcita; and Thyrsopteris.
Demosthenic: Pertaining to, or in the style of, Demosthenes, the Grecian orator.
Disbud: To deprive of buds or shoots, as for training, or economizing the vital strength of a tree.
Deplume: To strip or pluck off the feather of; to deprive of of plumage.
Detur: A present of books given to a meritorious undergraduate student as a prize.
Dungy: Full of dung; filthy; vile; low.
Discontinuance: The act of discontinuing, or the state of being discontinued; want of continued connection or continuity; breaking off; cessation; interruption; as, a discontinuance of conversation or intercourse; discontinuance of a highway or of travel.
Deploredness: The state of being deplored or deplorable.
Dephosphorization: The act of freeing from phosphorous.
Detruncation: The act of lopping or cutting off, as the head from the body.
Dextrality: The state of being on the right-hand side; also, the quality of being right-handed; right-handedness.
Duddery: A place where rags are bought and kept for sale.
Descendent: Descending; falling; proceeding from an ancestor or source.
Diorama: A mode of scenic representation, invented by Daguerre and Bouton, in which a painting is seen from a distance through a large opening. By a combination of transparent and opaque painting, and of transmitted and reflected light, and by contrivances such as screens and shutters, much diversity of scenic effect is produced.
Distraction: The act of distracting; a drawing apart; separation.
Disdiapason: An interval of two octaves, or a fifteenth; -- called also bisdiapason.  Compare diapason{1}.
Dodecasyllable: A word consisting of twelve syllables.
Diphtheria: A very dangerous contagious disease in which the air passages, and especially the throat, become coated with a false membrane, produced by the solidification of an inflammatory exudation.  Cf. Group.
distressfulness: the quality of causing mental anguish.
Dermoh\u00e6mal: Pertaining to, or in relation with, both dermal and hæmal structures; as, the dermohæmal spines or ventral fin rays of fishes.
Dyaus-pitar: the Hindu god of the sky; same as Dyaus.
Dacninae: a natural family comprising the honeycreepers.
Dissunder: To separate; to sunder; to destroy.
Doryphora: A genus of plant-eating beetles, including the potato beetle. See Potato beetle.
Damp: To render damp; to moisten; to make humid, or moderately wet; to dampen; as, to damp cloth.
Discriminateness: The state of being discriminated; distinctness.
Dama: a genus of deer including the Eurasian fallow deer, Dama dama.
Dame: A mistress of a family, who is a lady; a woman in authority; especially, a lady.
Disinvolve: To uncover; to unfold or unroll; to disentangle.
Diphthongalize: To make into a diphthong; to pronounce as a diphthong.
Demonstrative: A demonstrative pronoun; as, “this” and “that” are demonstratives.
Dialist: A maker of dials; one skilled in dialing.
Disentomb: To take out from a tomb; a disinter.
Delphinoid: Pertaining to, or resembling, the dolphin.
Diplococcus: A form of micrococcus in which cocci are united in a binary manner. See Micrococcus.
Decampment: Departure from a camp; a marching off.
dolomite: A mineral consisting of the carbonate of lime and magnesia in varying proportions. It occurs in distinct crystals, and in extensive beds as a compact limestone, often crystalline granular, either white or clouded. It includes much of the common white marble. Also called bitter spar.
Double-dyed: Dyed twice; thoroughly or intensely colored; hence; firmly fixed in opinions or habits; as, a double-dyed villain.
dicast: A functionary in ancient Athens resembling closely to the modern juryman.
Dendromecon: a genus having only one species, the bush poppy.
Decreet: The final judgment of the Court of Session, or of an inferior court, by which the question at issue is decided.
Dentifrice: A powder or other substance to be used in cleaning the teeth; tooth powder.
Ducker: One who, or that which, ducks; a plunger; a diver.
Deutoplastic: Pertaining to, or composed of, deutoplasm.
Dispoline: One of several isomeric organic bases of the quinoline series of alkaloids.
Dime: A silver coin of the United States, of the value of ten cents; the tenth of a dollar.
Decretist: One who studies, or professes the knowledge of, the decretals.
Deforciant: One who keeps out of possession the rightful owner of an estate.
demonetize: To deprive of current value; to withdraw from use, as money.
Double-acting: Acting or operating in two directions or with both motions; producing a twofold result; as, a double-acting engine or pump.
Ductilimeter: An instrument for accurately determining the ductility of metals.
Dribber: One who dribs; one who shoots weakly or badly.
Divorcement: Dissolution of the marriage tie; divorce; separation.
Deserter: One who forsakes a duty, a cause or a party, a friend, or any one to whom he owes service; especially, a soldier or a seaman who abandons the service without leave; one guilty of desertion.
Demochelys: the type genus of the Dermochelyidae, consisting of leatherback turtles.
dead beat: a loafer, sponger, or swindler; especially, one who does not pay his debts.  Same as Beat, n., 7.
Disuse: Cessation of use, practice, or exercise; inusitation; desuetude; as, the limbs lose their strength by disuse.
Drogue: See Drag, n., 6, and Drag sail, under Drag, n.
Dixie: A colloquial name for the Southern portion of the United States, esp. during the Civil War.
Deafness: Incapacity of perceiving sounds; the state of the organs which prevents the impression which constitute hearing; want of the sense of hearing.
Dynamically: In accordance with the principles of dynamics or moving forces.
differentiable: possessing a differential coefficient or derivative; -- of a mathematical expression.
dropkick: an act of kicking a football (as for a field goal) in which the football is dropped and kicked as it touches the ground.
Delicatessen: Relishes for the table; dainties; delicacies.
dehumidify: to remove the moisture from (air or another gas); to reduce the humidity of; as, The air conditioner dehumidifies the air in the summer.
discolored: Altered in color; stained; spotted or streaked with foreign matter.
Dakota group: A subdivision at the base of the cretaceous formation in Western North America; -- so named from the region where the strata were first studied.
Disposal: The act of disposing, or disposing of, anything; arrangement; orderly distribution; a putting in order; as, the disposal of the troops in two lines.
Dolichocephalic: Having the cranium, or skull, long to its breadth; long-headed; -- opposed to brachycephalic.
Dewret: To ret or rot by the process called dewretting.
Draining: The art of carrying off surplus water, as from land.
deviate: a person having behavior differing from that which is normal or socially acceptable; -- used especially to characterize persons whose sexual behavior is considered morally unacceptable.
Delimit: To fix the limits of; to demarcate; to bound.
Deformed: Unnatural or distorted in form; having a deformity; misshapen; disfigured; as, a deformed person; a deformed head.
deionizer: an apparatus used to remove ions from a solution; a common variant contains a mixture of cation exchange resin in the acid form and anion exchange resin in the hydroxyl form inside a replaceable cartridge; ions in aqueous solution are exchanged for the elements of water by passing the solution through the mixed resin.
Dotterel: A European bird of the Plover family (Eudromias morinellus, syn. Charadrius morinellus).  It is tame and easily taken, and is popularly believed to imitate the movements of the fowler.
Derby: A race for three-old horses, run annually at Epsom (near London), for the Derby stakes. It was instituted by the 12th Earl of Derby, in 1780.
Dissoluble: Capable of being dissolved; having its parts separable by heat or moisture; convertible into a fluid.
