Disorganization: The act of disorganizing; destruction of system.
Devolvement: The act or process of devolving;; devolution.
Descension: The act of going downward; descent; falling or sinking; declension; degradation.
Diamond anniversary: an anniversary celebrated upon the completion of sixty, or, according to some, seventy-five, years from the beginning of the event commemorated.
dawning: the first light of day; dawn.
Density: The quality of being dense, close, or thick; compactness; -- opposed to rarity.
Disinterest: To divest of interest or interested motives.
Disinteress: To deprive or rid of interest in, or regard for; to disengage.
Disintegrator: A machine for grinding or pulverizing by percussion.
Doubt: A fluctuation of mind arising from defect of knowledge or evidence; uncertainty of judgment or mind; unsettled state of opinion concerning the reality of an event, or the truth of an assertion, etc.; hesitation.
Designer: One who designs, marks out, or plans; a contriver.
Diophantine: Originated or taught by Diophantus, the Greek writer on algebra.
Dermatic: Of or pertaining to the skin.
Discalceation: The act of pulling off the shoes or sandals.
Damnability: The quality of being damnable; damnableness.
dislike: A feeling of positive and usually permanent aversion to something unpleasant, uncongenial, or offensive; disapprobation; repugnance; displeasure; disfavor; -- the opposite of liking or fondness.
Dialing: The art of constructing dials; the science which treats of measuring time by dials.
Ditation: The act of making rich; enrichment.
Deficient: Wanting, to make up completeness; wanting, as regards a requirement; not sufficient; inadequate; defective; imperfect; incomplete; lacking; as, deficient parts; deficient estate; deficient strength; deficient in judgment.
Dihedron: A figure with two sides or surfaces.
Dribblet: A small piece or part; a small sum; a small quantity of money in making up a sum; as, the money was paid in dribblets.
Depuration: The act or process of depurating or freeing from foreign or impure matter, as a liquid or wound.
Demimonde: Persons of doubtful reputation; esp., women who are kept as mistresses, though not public prostitutes; demireps.
Dousing-chock: One of several pieces fayed across the apron and lapped in the knightheads, or inside planking above the upper deck.
Dacrycarpus: a genus of evergreen coniferous shrubs or trees of New Zealand to Malaysia and Philippines.
D-layer: the lowest region of the ionosphere (35 to 50 miles up) that reflects low-frequency radio waves.
Drosophilidae: a natural family of insects including some of those called fruit flies.
Dewretting: Dewrotting; the process of decomposing the gummy matter of flax and hemp and setting the fibrous part, by exposure on a sward to dew, rain, and sunshine.
Directly: In a direct manner; in a straight line or course.
disheveled: Hanging in loose disorder; disarranged; in disarray; not made neat; -- used especially of hair or clothing; as, disheveled hair.
dirigiste: Directed by a central authority; as, a dirigiste economy; with respect to economics, opposed to free-market.  See also dirigisme.
Demirep: A woman of doubtful reputation or suspected character; an adventuress.
Deprave: To speak ill of; to depreciate; to malign; to revile.
Double-tongued: Making contrary declarations on the same subject; deceitful.
Duly: In a due, fit, or becoming manner; as it (anything) ought to be; properly; regularly.
Dislink: To unlink; to disunite; to separate.
Dialectician: One versed in dialectics; a logician; a reasoner.
Descendibility: The quality of being descendible; capability of being transmitted from ancestors; as, the descendibility of an estate.
Desidiousness: The state or quality of being desidiose, or indolent.
Doleful: Full of dole or grief; expressing or exciting sorrow; sorrowful; sad; dismal.
Demivolt: A half vault; one of the seven artificial motions of a horse, in which he raises his fore legs in a particular manner.
Desmognathous: Having the maxillo-palatine bones united; -- applied to a group of carinate birds (Desmognathæ), including various wading and swimming birds, as the ducks and herons, and also raptorial and other kinds.
Decubitus: An attitude assumed in lying down; as, the dorsal decubitus.
ding-a-ling: a stupid or foolish person; -- used in a deprecatory or contemptuous sense.
Deerskin: The skin of a deer, or the leather which is made from it.
Decay: Gradual failure of health, strength, soundness, prosperity, or of any species of excellence or perfection; tendency toward dissolution or extinction; corruption; rottenness; decline; deterioration; as, the decay of the body; the decay of virtue; the decay of the Roman empire; a castle in decay.
Dynamite: An explosive substance consisting of nitroglycerin absorbed by some inert, porous solid, as infusorial earth, sawdust, etc. It is safer than nitroglycerin, being less liable to explosion from moderate shocks, or from spontaneous decomposition.
Devirginate: To deprive of virginity; to deflower.
Diplomatically: According to the rules of diplomacy; in the manner of a diplomatist; artfully.
Distributer: One who, or that which, distributes or deals out anything; a dispenser.
Deflagrate: To cause to burn with sudden and sparkling combustion, as by the action of intense heat; to burn or vaporize suddenly; as, to deflagrate refractory metals in the oxyhydrogen flame.
Dray: A strong low cart or carriage used for heavy burdens.
Drag: The act of dragging; anything which is dragged.
Drab: Of a color between gray and brown.
Dram: To drink drams; to ply with drams.
Delphinus: A genus of Cetacea, including the dolphin. See Dolphin, 1.
Delude: To lead from truth or into error; to mislead the mind or judgment of; to beguile; to impose on; to dupe; to make a fool of.
Defervescence: A subsiding from a state of ebullition; loss of heat; lukewarmness.
Defix: To fix; to fasten; to establish.
disarming: act of reducing or depriving of weapons.
Deca-: A prefix, from Gr. de`ka, signifying ten;
Deliquate: To cause to melt away; to dissolve; to consume; to waste.
delegating: the act or process of authorizing subordinates to make certain decisions.
Damourite: A kind of Muscovite, or potash mica, containing water.
Detestableness: The quality or state of being detestable.
Dog days: A period of from four to six weeks, in the summer, variously placed by almanac makers between the early part of July and the early part of September; canicular days; -- so called in reference to the rising in ancient times of the Dog Star (Sirius) with the sun. Popularly, the sultry, close part of the summer; metaphorically, a period of inactivity.
Dinoceras: A genus of large extinct Eocene mammals from Wyoming; -- called also Uintatherium. See Illustration in Appendix.
Dodman: A snail; also, a snail shell; a hodmandod.
Disproportion: To make unsuitable in quantity, form, or fitness to an end; to violate symmetry in; to mismatch; to join unfitly.
Defatigable: Capable of being wearied or tired out.
Discriminal: In palmistry, applied to the line which marks the separation between the hand and the arm.
Decoherer: A device for restoring a coherer to its normal condition after it has been affected by an electric wave, a process usually accomplished by some method of tapping or shaking, or by rotation of the coherer.
docking: a act of securing an arriving vessel with ropes or anchors.
Dragoon: To harass or reduce to subjection by dragoons; to persecute by abandoning a place to the rage of soldiers.
Disarticulator: One who disarticulates and prepares skeletons.
Depaint: To paint; to picture; hence, to describe; to delineate in words; to depict.
Disease: To deprive of ease; to disquiet; to trouble; to distress.
Decastere: A measure of capacity, equal to ten steres, or ten cubic meters.
Diestock: A stock to hold the dies used for cutting screws.
Denim: A coarse cotton drilling used for overalls, etc.
Dreamily: As if in a dream; softly; slowly; languidly.
Dipyridine: A polymeric form of pyridine, C10H10N2, obtained as a colorless oil by the action of sodium on pyridine.
Despiteous: Feeling or showing despite; malicious; angry to excess; cruel; contemptuous.
Danegeld: An annual tax formerly laid on the English nation to buy off the ravages of Danish invaders, or to maintain forces to oppose them. It afterward became a permanent tax, raised by an assessment, at first of one shilling, afterward of two shillings, upon every hide of land throughout the realm.
degreed: possessing a college degree or degrees.
Designator: An officer who assigned to each his rank and place in public shows and ceremonies.
Demigod: A half god, or an inferior deity; a fabulous hero, the offspring of a deity and a mortal.
Domiciliation: The act of domiciliating; permanent residence; inhabitancy.
densification: an increase in the density of something.
Deductive: Of or pertaining to deduction; capable of being deduced from premises; deducible.
Dower: That with which one is gifted or endowed; endowment; gift.
Discerningly: In a discerning manner; with judgment; judiciously; acutely.
Dowel: To fasten together by dowels; to furnish with dowels; as, a cooper dowels pieces for the head of a cask.
Dispiteous: Full of despite; cruel; spiteful; pitiless.
Destructive: One who destroys; a radical reformer; a destructionist.
Dizzily: In a dizzy manner or state.
Dicyanide: A compound of a binary type containing two cyanogen groups or radicals; -- called also bicyanide.
Doxology: In Christian worship: A hymn expressing praise and honor to God; a form of praise to God designed to be sung or chanted by the choir or the congregation.
Desist: To cease to proceed or act; to stop; to forbear; -- often with from.
Delineator: One who, or that which, delineates; a sketcher.
Double-milled: Twice milled or fulled, to render more compact or fine; -- said of cloth; as, double-milled kerseymere.
Dispassion: Freedom from passion; an undisturbed state; apathy.
Dope-book: A chart of previous performances, etc., of race horses; a racing form.
Dropping: The action of causing to drop or of letting drop; falling.
Dephlegmedness: A state of being freed from water.
Degeneration: The act or state of growing worse, or the state of having become worse; decline; degradation; debasement; degeneracy; deterioration.
Disengaged: Not engaged; free from engagement; at leisure; free from occupation or care; vacant.
Dijudicate: To make a judicial decision; to decide; to determine.
Disgruntle: To dissatisfy; to disaffect; to anger.
Dedecorate: To bring to shame; to disgrace.
Dichlamydeous: Having two coverings, a calyx and a corolla.
Dwang: A piece of wood set between two studs, posts, etc., to stiffen and support them.
Declinometer: An instrument for measuring the declination of the magnetic needle.
Dander: To wander about; to saunter; to talk incoherently.
Debenture: A writing acknowledging a debt; a writing or certificate signed by a public officer, as evidence of a debt due to some person; the sum thus due.
Derider: One who derides, or laughs at, another in contempt; a mocker; a scoffer.
Deerhound: One of a large and fleet breed of hounds used in hunting deer; a staghound.
Decipherable: Capable of being deciphered; as, old writings not decipherable.
Deprehend: To take unawares or by surprise; to seize, as a person commiting an unlawful act; to catch; to apprehend.
Destroyer: One who destroys, ruins, kills, or desolates.
Doitkin: A very small coin; a doit.
Diaphragmatic: Pertaining to a diaphragm; as, diaphragmatic respiration; the diaphragmatic arteries and nerves.
Diacoustics: That branch of natural philosophy which treats of the properties of sound as affected by passing through different mediums; -- called also diaphonics. See the Note under Acoustics.
Dabble: To play in water, as with the hands; to paddle or splash in mud or water.
Diligently: In a diligent manner; not carelessly; not negligently; with industry or assiduity.
Dendrolite: A petrified or fossil shrub, plant, or part of a plant.
Democratic: Pertaining to democracy; favoring democracy, or constructed upon the principle of government by the people.
Daroo: The Egyptian sycamore (Ficus Sycamorus). See Sycamore.
Despotic: Having the character of, or pertaining to, a despot; absolute in power; possessing and abusing unlimited power; evincing despotism; tyrannical; arbitrary.
Dementation: The act of depriving of reason; madness.
Diathermic: Affording a free passage to heat; as, diathermic substances.
Devilism: The state of the devil or of devils; doctrine of the devil or of devils.
directivity: the property of a microphone or antenna of being more sensitive to sounds coming from one direction than from another.
Devilish: Resembling, characteristic of, or pertaining to, the devil; diabolical; wicked in the extreme.
Dika: A kind of food, made from the almondlike seeds of the Irvingia Barteri, much used by natives of the west coast of Africa; -- called also dika bread.
Deperditely: Hopelessly; despairingly; in the manner of one ruined; as, deperditely wicked.
Dike: To work as a ditcher; to dig.
Dishouse: To deprive of house or home.
Diamido-: A prefix or combining form of Diamine.
Destructionist: One who delights in destroying that which is valuable; one whose principles and influence tend to destroy existing institutions; a destructive.
Dittology: A double reading, or twofold interpretation, as of a Scripture text.
Dentiloquy: The habit or practice of speaking through the teeth, or with them closed.
Drowner: One who, or that which, drowns.
Descartes: René Descartes, a French philosopher and mathematician, born 159, died 1650.  See biography, below.
Dissyllabic: Consisting of two syllables only; as, a dissyllabic foot in poetry.
Disbelieve: Not to believe; to refuse belief or credence to; to hold not to be true or actual.
Doree: A European marine fish (Zeus faber), of a yellow color. See Illust. of John Doree.
Dalea: a genus of plants including the indigo bush.
Dos-\u00e0-dos: A sofa, open carriage, or the like, so constructed that the occupants sit back to back.
dissociate: To separate from fellowship or union; to disunite; to disjoin; as, to dissociate the particles of a concrete substance.
Disimpassioned: Free from warmth of passion or feeling.
Denigrate: To blacken thoroughly; to make very black.
Dequeen: To remove the queen from (a hive of bees).
Disdeify: To divest or deprive of deity or of a deific rank or condition.
Dracocephalum: A genus of American herbs and dwarf shrubs of the mind family; the dragonheads.
Dissatisfy: To render unsatisfied or discontented; to excite uneasiness in by frustrating wishes or expectations; to displease by the want of something requisite; as, to be dissatisfied with one's fortune.
Dacapo: From the beginning; a direction to return to, and end with, the first strain; -- indicated by the letters D. C. Also, the strain so repeated.
Donship: The quality or rank of a don, gentleman, or knight.
Dissuasion: The act of dissuading; exhortation against a thing; dehortation.
Dianoialogy: The science of the dianoetic faculties, and their operations.
Decomposable: Capable of being resolved into constituent elements.
Diathetic: Pertaining to, or dependent on, a diathesis or special constitution of the body; as, diathetic disease.
dungeon: A close, dark prison, commonly, under ground, as if the lower apartments of the donjon or keep of a castle, these being used as prisons.
Dyne: The unit of force, in the C. G. S. (Centimeter Gram Second) system of physical units; that is, the force which, acting on a gram for a second, generates a velocity of a centimeter per second.
Dentiphone: An instrument which, placed against the teeth, conveys sound to the auditory nerve; an audiphone.
Diacid: Divalent; -- said of a base or radical as capable of saturating two acid monad radicals or a dibasic acid.  Cf. Dibasic, a., and Biacid.
Dogs-tail grass: A hardy species of British grass (Cynosurus cristatus) which abounds in grass lands, and is well suited for making straw plait; -- called also goldseed.
Definitional: Relating to definition; of the nature of a definition; employed in defining.
derogatory: Tending to derogate, or lessen in value; expressing a  low opinion; expressing derogation; detracting; injurious; -- with from, to, or unto.
Deliquescent: Dissolving; liquefying by contact with the air; capable of attracting moisture from the atmosphere and becoming liquid; as, deliquescent salts.
Delegacy: The act of delegating, or state of being delegated; deputed power.
Domesday: A day of judgment. See Doomsday.
Dinar: A petty money of accounts of Persia; 100 dinars consituted a rial.
dicastery: A court of justice; judgment hall.
Diggers: A degraded tribe of California Indians; -- so called from their practice of digging roots for food.
Didelphian: Of or relating to the Didelphia.
Double-threaded: Consisting of two threads twisted together; using two threads.
Dentately: In a dentate or toothed manner; as, dentately ciliated, etc.
Disfriar: To depose or withdraw from the condition of a friar.
Decastyle: Having ten columns in front; -- said of a portico, temple, etc.
Del credere: An agreement by which an agent or factor, in consideration of an additional premium or commission (called a del credere commission), engages, when he sells goods on credit, to insure, warrant, or guarantee to his principal the solvency of the purchaser, the engagement of the factor being to pay the debt himself if it is not punctually discharged by the buyer when it becomes due.
Decoctible: Capable of being boiled or digested.
Dactyliomancy: Divination by means of finger rings.
Dinosauria: An order of extinct mesozoic reptiles, mostly of large size (whence the name). Notwithstanding their size, they present birdlike characters in the skeleton, esp. in the pelvis and hind limbs. Some walked on their three-toed hind feet, thus producing the large “bird tracks,” so-called, of mesozoic sandstones; others were five-toed and quadrupedal. See Illust. of Compsognathus, also Illustration of Dinosaur in Appendix.
Disdiaclast: One of the dark particles forming the doubly refracting disks of muscle fibers.
Deltohedron: A solid bounded by twelve quadrilateral faces. It is a hemihedral form of the isometric system, allied to the tetrahedron.
Downward: Moving or extending from a higher to a lower place; tending toward the earth or its center, or toward a lower level; declivous.
door-to-door: direct without intermediate changes of vehicle; -- of e.g. journeys or deliveries; as, the limousine offers direct door-to-door service.
Deglutitory: Serving for, or aiding in, deglutition.
Dubb: The Syrian bear. See under Bear.
Dissympathy: Lack of sympathy; want of interest; indifference.
Diathermancy: The property of transmitting radiant heat; the quality of being diathermous.
Demonstrate: To point out; to show; to exhibit; to make evident.
Divarication: A separation into two parts or branches; a forking; a divergence.
Decease: To depart from this life; to die; to pass away.
Discure: To discover; to reveal; to discoure.
dislikeful: Full of dislike; disaffected; malign; disagreeable.
Depurator: One who, or that which, cleanses.
Disgavel: To deprive of that principal quality of gavelkind tenure by which lands descend equally among all the sons of the tenant; -- said of lands.
Dimyarian: Like or pertaining to the Dimya.
Decapitate: To cut off the head of; to behead.
Dubiosity: The state of being doubtful; a doubtful statement or thing.
Douche: A jet or current of water or vapor directed upon some part of the body to benefit it medicinally; a douche bath.
Dodgem: a small low-powered electrically powered vehicle driven on a special platform where there are many others to be dodged.
Diplomatic: A minister, official agent, or envoy to a foreign court; a diplomatist.
Decker: One who, or that which, decks or adorns; a coverer; as, a table decker.
Dimness: The state or quality &unr_; being dim; lack of brightness, clearness, or distinctness; dullness; obscurity.
Duller: One who, or that which, dulls.
Discerp: To tear in pieces; to rend.
disrupted: Not continuous in time or space.  Opposite of continuous.
dollhouse: a house so small that it is likened to a child's dollhouse.  Sometimes used in reference to a small house with especially elaborate exterior decoration.
Dawdler: One who wastes time in trifling employments; an idler; a trifler.
d\u00e9class\u00e9: reduced or fallen in status, social position, class or rank; fallen from a high status or rank to a lower one.
Deplete: To empty or unload, as the vessels of human system, by bloodletting or by medicine.
Discern: To see or understand the difference; to make distinction; as, to discern between good and evil, truth and falsehood.
Devotee: One who is wholly devoted; esp., one given wholly to religion; one who is superstitiously given to religious duties and ceremonies; a bigot.
disherit: To disinherit; to cut off, or detain, from the possession or enjoyment of an inheritance.
Dismast: To deprive of a mast of masts; to break and carry away the masts from; as, a storm dismasted the ship.
Dialogically: In the manner or nature of a dialogue.
Dormitive: Causing sleep; as, the dormitive properties of opium.
Ditrochee: A double trochee; a foot made up of two trochees.
Decagynian: Belonging to the Decagynia; having ten styles.
Demantoid: A yellow-green, transparent variety of garnet found in the Urals. It is valued as a gem because of its brilliancy of luster, whence the name.
Dicrotism: A condition in which there are two beats or waves of the arterial pulse to each beat of the heart.
Dismarry: To free from the bonds of marriage; to divorce.
Deflagrable: Burning with a sudden and sparkling combustion, as niter; hence, slightly explosive; liable to snap and crackle when heated, as salt.
Dactylitis: An inflammatory affection of the fingers.
D\u00e9but: A beginning or first attempt; hence, a first appearance before the public, as of an actor or public speaker.
Discoloration: The act of discoloring, or the state of being discolored; alteration of hue or appearance.
Declinature: The act of declining or refusing; as, the declinature of an office.
daleth: the fourth letter of the Hebrew alphabet.
Deletitious: Of such a nature that anything may be erased from it; -- said of paper.
Depressor: One who, or that which, presses down; an oppressor.
Diapasm: Powdered aromatic herbs, sometimes made into little balls and strung together.
Disapprobation: The act of disapproving; mental condemnation of what is judged wrong, unsuitable, or inexpedient; feeling of censure.
Distillation: The act of falling in drops, or the act of pouring out in drops.
Disclaunder: To injure one's good name; to slander.
Dolabra: A rude ancient ax or hatchet, seen in museums.
D\u00e9cime: A French coin, the tenth part of a franc, equal to about two cents.
Dissilition: The act of bursting or springing apart.
Daddy longlegs: An arachnidan of the genus Phalangium, and allied genera, having a small body and four pairs of long legs; -- called also harvestman, carter, and grandfather longlegs.
Deterration: The uncovering of anything buried or covered with earth; a taking out of the earth or ground.
Donnian: of or pertaining to John Donne.
Disenchantment: The act of disenchanting, or state of being disenchanted.
Disproportional: Not having due proportion to something else; not having proportion or symmetry of parts; unsuitable in form, quantity or value; inadequate; unequal; as, a disproportional limb constitutes deformity in the body; the studies of youth should not be disproportional to their understanding.
Designative: Serving to designate or indicate; pointing out.
Dishonest: To disgrace; to dishonor; as, to dishonest a maid.
Descensive: Tending to descend; tending downwards; descending.
Diana: The daughter of Jupiter and Latona; a virgin goddess who presided over hunting, chastity, and marriage; -- identified with the Greek goddess Artemis.
Discrepance: The state or quality of being discrepant; disagreement; variance; discordance; dissimilarity; contrariety.
Disquietment: State of being disquieted; uneasiness; harassment.
dissemination: The act of disseminating, or the state of being disseminated; diffusion for propagation and permanence; a scattering or spreading abroad, as of ideas, beliefs, etc.
dominicide: The act of killing a master.
Darter: One who darts, or who throw darts; that which darts.
Diphtheritic: Pertaining to, or connected with, diphtheria.
Dendroid: Resembling a shrub or tree in form; treelike; branching.
Disputative: Disposed to dispute; inclined to cavil or to reason in opposition; as, a disputative temper.
DAT: digital audiotape, a digitally encoded tape recording of sound; -- in contrast to the usual analog audio tape.
Daffodil: A plant of the genus Asphodelus.
Dejected: Cast down; afflicted; low-spirited; sad; as, a dejected look or countenance.
Disproportionable: Disproportional; unsuitable in form, size, quantity, or adaptation; disproportionate; inadequate.
Dejecter: One who casts down, or dejects.
Dressmaker: A maker of gowns, or similar garments; a mantuamaker.
Deme: A territorial subdivision of Attica (also of modern Greece), corresponding to a township.
Dunce: One backward in book learning; a child or other person dull or weak in intellect; a dullard; a dolt.
driveshaft: a rotating shaft that transmits power from the engine to the point of application.
Defensory: Tending to defend; defensive; as, defensory preparations.
Discalceate: To pull off shoes or sandals from.
Delirifacient: Producing, or tending to produce, delirium.
deaf and dumb: both deaf and unable to speak; without the sense of hearing or the faculty of speech. Same as Deaf-mute.
Dehisce: To gape; to open by dehiscence.
Devotionalist: One given to devotion, esp. to excessive formal devotion.
Dammar: An oleoresin used in making varnishes; dammar gum; dammara resin. It is obtained from certain resin trees indigenous to the East Indies, esp. Shorea robusta and the dammar pine.
Dromedary: The Arabian camel (Camelus dromedarius), having one hump or protuberance on the back, in distinction from the Bactrian camel, which has two humps.
Dignity: The state of being worthy or honorable; elevation of mind or character; true worth; excellence.
Dyspepsia: A kind of indigestion; a state of the stomach in which its functions are disturbed, without the presence of other diseases, or, if others are present, they are of minor importance. Its symptoms are loss of appetite, nausea, heartburn, acrid or fetid eructations, a sense of weight or fullness in the stomach, etc.
Dejerate: To swear solemnly; to take an oath.
Dail: the lower house of the parliament of the Republic of Ireland; -- also called the Dail Eirann.  From its members is selected the Taoiseach, or prime minister.
Diaphanotype: A colored photograph produced by superimposing a translucent colored positive over a strong uncolored one.
Dose: To proportion properly (a medicine), with reference to the patient or the disease; to form into suitable doses.
Drawloom: A kind of loom used in weaving figured patterns; -- called also drawboy.
Doss: A place to sleep in; a bed; hence, sleep.
Dais: The high or principal table, at the end of a hall, at which the chief guests were seated; also, the chief seat at the high table.
Dynamitard: A political dynamiter. [A form found in some newspapers.]
Dalmania: A genus of trilobites, of many species, common in the Upper Silurian and Devonian rocks.
declassified: having a security classification removed so as to be open to public inspection; -- of documents or information.
deixis: the function or operation of a deictic word; the function of pointing or specifying from the perspective of a participant in an act of speech or writing; aspects of a communication whose interpretation depends on knowledge of the context in which the communication occurs.
Deedful: Full of deeds or exploits; active; stirring.
Dynamist: One who accounts for material phenomena by a theory of dynamics.
dustpan: A shovel-like utensil with a short handle used for conveying away dust brushed from the floor.
Dynamism: The doctrine of Leibnitz, that all substance involves force.
Disorientate: To turn away from the east, or (figuratively) from the right or the truth.
Deforce: To keep from the rightful owner; to withhold wrongfully the possession of, as of lands or a freehold.
Demandable: That may be demanded or claimed.
demythologization: the restatement of a message (as a religious one) in rational terms.
Dumuzi: the Sumerian and Babylonian god of pastures and vegetation; consort of Inanna.
Disaggregate: To destroy the aggregation of; to separate into component parts, as an aggregate mass.
Davalliaceae: one of a number of families into which Polypodiaceae has been subdivided in some classification systems; includes genera Araiostegia; Davallia; Davallodes; Gymnogrammitis; Humata; Leucostegia; Scyphularia; Trogostolon.
Degradation: The act of reducing in rank, character, or reputation, or of abasing; a lowering from one's standing or rank in office or society; diminution; as, the degradation of a peer, a knight, a general, or a bishop.
Disenslave: To free from bondage or slavery; to disenthrall.
dacoit: One of a class of robbers, in India and Burma (Myanmar), who act in gangs and are usually armed.
Dumpy level: A level having a short telescope (hence its name) rigidly fixed to a table capable only of rotatory movement in a horizontal plane. The telescope is usually an inverting one. It is sometimes called the Troughton level, from the name of the inventor, and a variety improved by one Gavatt is known as the Gavatt level.
Dingo: A wild dog found in Australia, but supposed to have introduced at a very early period. It has a wolflike face, bushy tail, and a reddish brown color.
Dipping: The act or process of immersing.
Dingy: Soiled; sullied; of a dark or dusky color; dark brown; dirty.
Disprovable: Capable of being disproved or refuted.
Docket: To make a brief abstract of  (a writing) and indorse it on the back of the paper, or to indorse the title or contents on the back of; to summarize; as, to docket letters and papers.
divorced: having a marriage legally terminated and having not remarried.
Dinmont: A wether sheep between one and two years old.
Dryness: The state of being dry. See Dry.
Dissonance: A mingling of discordant sounds; an inharmonious combination of sounds; discord.
Disembowelment: The act of disemboweling, or state of being disemboweled; evisceration.
Defier: One who dares and defies; a contemner; as, a defier of the laws.
Douceur: Gentleness and sweetness of manner; agreeableness.
Decrepitude: The broken state produced by decay and the infirmities of age; infirm old age.
Dutiful: Performing, or ready to perform, the duties required by one who has the right to claim submission, obedience, or deference; submissive to natural or legal superiors; obedient, as to parents or superiors; as, a dutiful son or daughter; a dutiful ward or servant; a dutiful subject.
Disencumber: To free from encumbrance, or from anything which clogs, impedes, or obstructs; to disburden.
Deceitfulness: The disposition to deceive; as, a man's deceitfulness may be habitual.
Drivepipe: A pipe for forcing into the earth.
Dictum: An authoritative statement; a dogmatic saying; an apothegm.
D\u00e9gras: A semisolid emulsion produced by the treatment of certain skins with oxidized fish oil, which extracts their soluble albuminoids. It was formerly solely a by-product of chamois leather manufacture, but is now made for its own sake, being valuable as a dressing for hides.
Demonism: The belief in demons or false gods.
Delegation: The act of delegating, or investing with authority to act for another; the appointment of a delegate or delegates.
Demonist: A believer in, or worshiper of, demons.
Doorkeeper: One who guards the entrance of a house or apartment; a porter; a janitor.
Denutrition: The opposition of nutrition; the failure of nutrition causing the breaking down of tissue.
Diswont: To deprive of wonted usage; to disaccustom.
Doughtiness: The quality of being doughty; valor; bravery.
Disgust: Repugnance to what is offensive; aversion or displeasure produced by something loathsome; loathing; strong distaste; -- said primarily of the sickening opposition felt for anything which offends the physical organs of taste; now rather of the analogous repugnance excited by anything extremely unpleasant to the moral taste or higher sensibilities of our nature; as, an act of cruelty may excite disgust.
Degenerative: Undergoing or producing degeneration; tending to degenerate.
Disobedient: Neglecting or refusing to obey; omitting to do what is commanded, or doing what is prohibited; refractory; not observant of duty or rules prescribed by authority; -- applied to persons and acts.
Diminution: The act of diminishing, or of making or becoming less; state of being diminished; reduction in size, quantity, or degree; -- opposed to augmentation or increase.
Dibranchiata: An order of cephalopods which includes those with two gills, an apparatus for emitting an inky fluid, and either eight or ten cephalic arms bearing suckers or hooks, as the octopi and squids. See Cephalopoda.
Disciplinableness: The quality of being improvable by discipline.
Ditty: To sing; to warble a little tune.
deicer: a devie that removes ice or frost (as from a windshield or a refrigerator or the wings of an airplane).
dibrach: a foot of two short (unstressed-unstressed) syllables.
Dictatress: A woman who dictates or commands.
Drainpipe: A pipe used for carrying off surplus water.
Dolorous: Full of grief; sad; sorrowful; doleful; dismal; as, a dolorous object; dolorous discourses.
desolated: reduced to a barren and lifeless state.
Dairying: The business of conducting a dairy.
Draughtsmanship: The office, art, or work of a draughtsman.
Discal: Pertaining to, or resembling, a disk; as, discal cells.
Drimys: A genus of magnoliaceous trees. Drimys aromatica furnishes Winter's bark.
Diploblastic: Characterizing the ovum when it has two primary germinal layers.
Dendrologist: One versed in the natural history of trees.
Debatingly: In the manner of a debate.
Dermatology: The science which treats of the skin, its structure, functions, and diseases.
Disembroil: To disentangle; to free from perplexity; to extricate from confusion.
Ducat: A coin, either of gold or silver, of several countries in Europe; originally, one struck in the dominions of a duke.
Discontentment: The state of being discontented; uneasiness; inquietude.
Daturine: Atropine; -- called also daturia and daturina.
daunting: serving to discourage, dishearten, or intimidate; discouraging; disheartening.  Opposite of encouraging.
Decagon: A plane figure having ten sides and ten angles; any figure having ten angles. A regular decagon is one that has all its sides and angles equal.
Deadbeat: Making a beat without recoil; giving indications by a single beat or excursion; -- said of galvanometers and other instruments in which the needle or index moves to the extent of its deflection and stops with little or no further oscillation.
Denization: The act of making one a denizen or adopted citizen; naturalization.
dogy: a motherless calf in a range herd of cattle.
Divorceless: Incapable of being divorced or separated; free from divorce.
damaging: causing harm or injury; as, damaging to career and reputation.
Distasture: Something which excites distaste or disgust.
Depolarizer: A substance used to prevent polarization, as upon the negative plate of a voltaic battery.
Damassin: A kind of modified damask or brocade.
Duumvirate: The union of two men in the same office; or the office, dignity, or government of two men thus associated, as in ancient Rome.
Dildo: A columnar cactaceous plant of the West Indies (Cereus Swartzii).
Deep-mouthed: Having a loud and sonorous voice.
Daubery: A daubing; specious coloring; false pretenses.
Dandified: Made up like a dandy; having the dress or manners of a dandy; buckish.
Drillmaster: One who teaches drill, especially in the way of gymnastics.
Dibble: To plant with a dibble; to make holes in (soil) with a dibble, for planting.
dildo: a device shaped like an erect penis, used by some women for sexual stimulation.
Dispeed: To send off with speed; to dispatch.
Depot: A place of deposit for the storing of goods; a warehouse; a storehouse.
Drapery: The occupation of a draper; cloth-making, or dealing in cloth.
Disarmature: The act of divesting of armature.
Deiform: Godlike, or of a godlike form.
Divertive: Tending to divert; diverting; amusing; interesting.
Disquiet: To render unquiet; to deprive of peace, rest, or tranquility; to make uneasy or restless; to disturb.
Dasheen: A tropical aroid (of the genus Caladium, syn. Colocasia) having an edible farinaceous root. It is related to the taro and to the tanier, but is much superior to it in quality and is as easily cooked as the potato. It is a staple food plant of the tropics, being prepared like potatoes, and has been introduced into the Southern United States.
Deflected: Turned aside; deviating from a direct line or course.
Despair: Loss of hope; utter hopelessness; complete despondency.
Dzeren: The Chinese yellow antelope (Procapra gutturosa), a remarkably swift-footed animal, inhabiting the deserts of Central Asia, Tibet, and China.
Decollation: The act of beheading or state of one beheaded; -- especially used of the execution of St. John the Baptist.
Digitiform: Formed like a finger or fingers; finger-shaped; as, a digitiform root.
Dripping: A falling in drops, or the sound so made.
Disrepute: To bring into disreputation; to hold in dishonor.
demoralized: made less hopeful or enthusiastic; rendered pessimistic; as, the demoralized Iraqi ground troops put up little resistance.
Decussation: Act of crossing at an acute angle, or state of being thus crossed; an intersection in the form of an X; as, the decussation of lines, nerves, etc.
deers-ear: any of various tall perennial herbs constituting the genus Frasera; it is widely distributed in warm dry upland areas of the US Pacific states.
Dramatize: To compose in the form of the drama; to represent in a drama; to adapt to dramatic representation; as, to dramatize a novel, or an historical episode.
Distaff: The staff for holding a bunch of flax, tow, or wool, from which the thread is drawn in spinning by hand.
Dorsibranchiate: Having branchiæ along the back; belonging to the Dorsibranchiata.
Despoina: the daughter of Zeus and Demeter; made queen of the underworld by Pluto in ancient mythology; identified with Roman Proserpina.
Dogal: Of or pertaining to a doge.
Dog Star: Sirius, a star of the constellation Canis Major, or the Greater Dog, and the brightest star in the heavens; -- called also Canicula, and, in astronomical charts, α Canis Majoris. See Dog days.
Diatom: One of the Diatomaceæ, a family of minute unicellular Algæ having a siliceous covering of great delicacy, each individual multiplying by spontaneous division. By some authors diatoms are called Bacillariæ, but this word is not in general use.
dactylioglyphy: The art or process of gem engraving.
Demoniacism: The state of being demoniac, or the practices of demoniacs.
Delineatory: That delineates; descriptive; drawing the outline; delineating.
Discontinuation: Breach or interruption of continuity; separation of parts in a connected series; discontinuance.
Dragbolt: A coupling pin. See under Coupling.
Deck: The floorlike covering of the horizontal sections, or compartments, of a ship. Small vessels have only one deck; larger ships have two or three decks.
Dichotomy: A cutting in two; a division.
Dossil: A small ovoid or cylindrical roil or pledget of lint, for keeping a sore, wound, etc., open; a tent.
Duettino: A duet of short extent and concise form.
Disremember: To fail to remember; to forget.
Drollery: The quality of being droll; sportive tricks; buffoonery; droll stories; comical gestures or manners.
dustbin: a bin that holds rubbish until it is collected.
Dialytic: Having the quality of unloosing or separating.
Double-hearted: Having a false heart; deceitful; treacherous.
Distortion: The act of distorting, or twisting out of natural or regular shape; a twisting or writhing motion; as, the distortions of the face or body.
Dramatically: In a dramatic manner; theatrically; vividly.
Ditroite: An igneous rock composed of orthoclase, elæolite, and sodalite.
Daglock: A dirty or clotted lock of wool on a sheep; a taglock.
Dutchmans-pipe: a hardy deciduous American vine (Aristolochia durior) having large, heart-shaped leaves and bearing brownish-purple flowers which have their calyx tubes curved like the bowl of a tobacco pipe.  Formerly classified as Aristolochia Sipho.
Deoxygenation: The act or operation of depriving of oxygen.
Dukeship: The quality or condition of being a duke; also, the personality of a duke.
Decide: To determine; to form a definite opinion; to come to a conclusion; to give decision; as, the court decided in favor of the defendant.
Determinedly: In a determined manner; with determination.
de-iodinase: an enzyme that removes the iodine radical.
Derrick: A mast, spar, or tall frame, supported at the top by stays or guys, and usually pivoted at the base, with suitable tackle for hoisting heavy weights, such as stones in building.
desensitization: the process of reducing or eliminating sensitivity.
Disnatured: Deprived or destitute of natural feelings; unnatural.
Dislodgment: The act or process of dislodging, or the state of being dislodged.
Doris: A genus of nudibranchiate mollusks having a wreath of branchiæ on the back.
Diamagnetic: Any substance, as bismuth, glass, phosphorous, etc., which in a field of magnetic force is differently affected from the ordinary magnetic bodies, as iron; that is, which tends to take a position at right angles to the lines of magnetic force, and is repelled by either pole of the magnet.  Contrasted with paramagnetic and ferromagnetic.
Dour: Hard; inflexible; obstinate; sour in aspect; hardy; bold.
Dotage: Feebleness or imbecility of understanding or mind, particularly in old age; the childishness of old age; senility; as, a venerable man, now in his dotage.
Douc: A monkey (Semnopithecus nemæus), remarkable for its varied and brilliant colors. It is a native of Cochin China.
Dawn: The break of day; the first appearance of light in the morning; show of approaching sunrise.
Dawk: A hollow, crack, or cut, in timber.
Disinterested: Not influenced by regard to personal interest or advantage; free from selfish motive; having no relation of interest or feeling; not biased or prejudiced; as, a disinterested decision or judge.
Dishonorer: One who dishonors or disgraces; one who treats another indignity.
Disputatious: Inclined to dispute; apt to civil or controvert; characterized by dispute; as, a disputatious person or temper.
Dipogon: a genus of plants consisting of one species, the Australian pea.
Droitural: relating to the mere right of property, as distinguished from the right of possession; as, droitural actions.
Doorcheek: The jamb or sidepiece of a door.
Dare-devil: A reckless fellow. Also used adjectively; as, dare-devil excitement.
drafting: writing a first version to be filled out and polished later.
Drown: To overwhelm in water; to submerge; to inundate.
Dedication: The act of setting apart or consecrating to a divine Being, or to a sacred use, often with religious solemnities; solemn appropriation; as, the dedication of Solomon's temple.
Disulphate: A salt of disulphuric or pyrosulphuric acid; a pyrosulphate.
Dried: imp. & p. p. of Dry. Also adj.; as, dried apples.
Denationalize: To divest or deprive of national character or rights.
Deraign: To prove or to refute by proof; to clear (one's self).
Dawsonite: A hydrous carbonate of alumina and soda, occuring in white, bladed crustals.
Didonia: The curve which on a given surface and with a given perimeter contains the greatest area.
Demulce: To soothe; to mollify; to pacify; to soften.
dumped: p. p. of dump, v. t.; as, The money was there, dumped all over the floor.
Dioptase: A hydrous silicate of copper, occurring in emerald-green crystals.
Dolce: Softly; sweetly; with soft, smooth, and delicate execution.
Dihedral: Having two plane faces; as, the dihedral summit of a crystal.
Diverter: One who, or that which, diverts, turns off, or pleases.
Duotype: A print made from two half-tone plates made from the same negative, but etched differently.
disparager: One who disparages or dishonors; one who vilifies or disgraces.
drop cloth: a sheet of material used to cover objects or surfaces while painting a ceiling or wall of a house, so as to protect objects from being marred by drops of paint splashed inadvertantly in the painting process.  Originally such drop cloths were made of cloth, but more recently paper or plastic have also commonly been used.
Distance: To place at a distance or remotely.
Devaporation: The change of vapor into water, as in the formation of rain.
Decretorily: In a decretory or definitive manner; by decree.
Digamma: A letter (&unr_;, &unr_;) of the Greek alphabet, which early fell into disuse.
Dyspeptone: An insoluble albuminous body formed from casein and other proteid substances by the action of gastric juice.
Dihexagonal: Consisting of two hexagonal parts united; thus, a dihexagonal pyramid is composed of two hexagonal pyramids placed base to base.
Distillery: The building and works where distilling, esp. of alcoholic liquors, is carried on.
Dissolvative: Having the power to dissolve anything; solvent.
Diplomate: To invest with a title or privilege by diploma.
Dropwise: After the manner of a drop; in the form of drops.
Duff: To treat or manipulate so as to give a specious appearance to; to fake; hence, to cheat.
Diffusate: Material which, in the process of catalysis, has diffused or passed through the separating membrane.
Deformity: The state of being deformed; want of proper form or symmetry; any unnatural form or shape; distortion; irregularity of shape or features; ugliness.
dignify: To invest with dignity or honor; to make illustrious; to give distinction to; to exalt in rank; to honor.
Dissipate: To separate into parts and disappear; to waste away; to scatter; to disperse; to vanish; as, a fog or cloud gradually dissipates before the rays or heat of the sun; the heat of a body dissipates.
Datolite: A borosilicate of lime commonly occuring in glassy,, greenish crystals.
Deformation: The act of deforming, or state of anything deformed.
Defeasible: Capable of being annulled or made void; as, a defeasible title.
Demobilize: To disorganize, or disband and send home, as troops which have been mobilized.
Dubber: A globular vessel or bottle of leather, used in India to hold ghee, oil, etc.
Diluteness: The quality or state of being dilute.
Deductively: By deduction; by way of inference; by consequence.
Dancett\u00e9: Deeply indented; having large teeth; thus, a fess dancetté has only three teeth in the whole width of the escutcheon.
Demurrage: The detention of a vessel by the freighter beyond the time allowed in her charter party for loading, unloading, or sailing.
DNase: any of numerous enzymes that catalyze the breakdown of DNA into oligonucleotides or mononucleotides.
Distiller: One who distills; esp., one who extracts alcoholic liquors by distillation.
Dilapidate: To get out of repair; to fall into partial ruin; to become decayed; as, the church was suffered to dilapidate.
Dataria: Formerly, a part of the Roman chancery; now, a separate office from which are sent graces or favors, cognizable in foro externo, such as appointments to benefices. The name is derived from the word datum, given or dated (with the indications of the time and place of granting the gift or favor).
Driftage: Deviation from a ship's course due to leeway.
Disworth: To deprive of worth; to degrade.
do-it-yourself: performed or made by an end-user who is without professional training in the relevant techniques; as, their house was a do-it-yourself project.  Contrasted with factory-made and professional.
Dewrot: To rot, as flax or hemp, by exposure to rain, dew, and sun. See Dewretting.
Demonomania: A form of madness in which the patient conceives himself possessed of devils.
Demagogue: A leader of the rabble; one who attempts to control the multitude by specious or deceitful arts; an unprincipled and factious mob orator or political leader.
deflation: the act or process of deflating.
Dispersal: The act or result of dispersing or scattering; dispersion.
Drum winding: A method of armature winding in which the wire is wound upon the outer surface of a cylinder or drum from end to end of the cylinder; -- distinguished from ring winding, etc.
Distressful: Full of distress; causing, indicating, or attended with, distress; as, a distressful situation.
Dovyalis: a small genus of sometimes spiny shrubs or small trees, found in Africa, India, and Sri Lanka.
Disreverence: To treat irreverently or with disrespect.
Della Crusca: A shortened form of Accademia della Crusca, an academy in Florence, Italy, founded in the 16th century, especially for conserving the purity of the Italian language.
Deter: To prevent by fear; hence, to hinder or prevent from action by fear of consequences, or difficulty, risk, etc.
Diluvial: Of or pertaining to a flood or deluge, esp. to the great deluge in the days of Noah; diluvian.
dog-legged: Noting a flight of stairs, consisting of two or more straight portions connected by a platform (landing) or platforms, and running in opposite directions without an intervening wellhole.
Diluvian: Of or pertaining to a deluge, esp. to the Noachian deluge; diluvial; as, of diluvian origin.
Drawboy: A boy who operates the harness cords of a hand loom; also, a part of power loom that performs the same office.
Deploy: The act of deploying; a spreading out of a body of men in order to extend their front.
Dechristianize: To turn from, or divest of, Christianity.
Diamagnetism: The science which treats of diamagnetic phenomena, and of the properties of diamagnetic bodies.
Deathbed: The bed in which a person dies; hence, the closing hours of life of one who dies by sickness or the like; the last sickness.
Demigorge: Half the gorge, or entrance into a bastion, taken from the angle of the flank to the center of the bastion.
dorsibranchiata: A division of chætopod annelids in which the branchiæ are along the back, on each side, or on the parapodia. [See Illusts. under Annelida and Chætopoda.]
Discodactylous: Having sucking disks on the toes, as the tree frogs.
Drumming: The act of beating upon, or as if upon, a drum; also, the noise which the male of the ruffed grouse makes in spring, by beating his wings upon his sides.
Distinguisher: One who, or that which, distinguishes or separates one thing from another by marks of diversity.
Disserviceable: Calculated to do disservice or harm; not serviceable; injurious; harmful; unserviceable.
Deodorizer: He who, or that which, deodorizes; esp., an agent that destroys offensive odors.
Disanoint: To invalidate the consecration of; as, to disanoint a king.
Diswarn: To dissuade from by previous warning.
Dollardee: A species of sunfish (Lepomis pallidus), common in the United States; -- called also blue sunfish, and copper-nosed bream.
detribalize: to cause (members of a tribe) to lose their cultural identity and adopt other customs.
Dry-boned: Having dry bones, or bones without flesh.
Dysentery: A disease attended with inflammation and ulceration of the colon and rectum, and characterized by griping pains, constant desire to evacuate the bowels, and the discharge of mucus and blood.
dacha: a Russian country house, especially a cottage used in the summer.
Disquantity: To diminish the quantity of; to lessen.
Dilatoriness: The quality of being dilatory; lateness; slowness; tardiness; sluggishness.
Disgraceful: Bringing disgrace; causing shame; shameful; dishonorable; unbecoming; as, profaneness is disgraceful to a man.
Daphnetin: A colorless crystalline substance, C9H6O4, extracted from daphnin.
Disemployment: The state of being disemployed, or deprived of employment.
Dura mater: The tough, fibrous membrane, which lines the cavity of the skull and spinal column, and surrounds the brain and spinal cord; -- frequently abbreviated to dura.
Defamatory: Containing defamation; injurious to reputation; calumnious; slanderous; as, defamatory words; defamatory writings.
Disinsure: To render insecure; to put in danger.
Diphyodont: Having two successive sets of teeth (deciduous and permanent), one succeeding the other; as, a diphyodont mammal; diphyodont dentition; -- opposed to monophyodont.
Dysuric: Pertaining to, or afflicted with, dysury.
Degeneracy: The act of becoming degenerate; a growing worse.
Dulia: An inferior kind of veneration or worship, given to the angels and saints as the servants of God.
Deride: To laugh at with contempt; to laugh to scorn; to turn to ridicule or make sport of; to mock; to scoff at.
Dallier: One who fondles; a trifler; as, dalliers with pleasant words.
Diminishable: Capable of being diminished or lessened.
Doxologize: To give glory to God, as in a doxology; to praise God with doxologies.
Dueness: Quality of being due; debt; what is due or becoming.
Discourtesy: Rudeness of behavior or language; ill manners; manifestation of disrespect; incivility.
drop-off: a noticeable decline in performance; as, a drop-off in attendance.
Dandify: To cause to resemble a dandy; to make dandyish.
Disclosed: Represented with wings expanded; -- applied to doves and other birds not of prey.
Deign: To think worthy; to vouchsafe; to condescend; - - followed by an infinitive.
Dragoman: An interpreter; -- so called in the Levant and other parts of the East.
Divertissement: A short ballet, or other entertainment, between the acts of a play.
Delphine: Pertaining to the dolphin, a genus of fishes.
Dominick: an American breed of chicken having barred gray plumage raised for meat and brown eggs.
Dravida: A race of Hindustan, believed to be the original people who occupied the land before the Hindu or Aryan invasion.
Discurrent: Not current or free to circulate; not in use.
Desquamatory: An instrument formerly used in removing the laminæ of exfoliated bones.
Devanagari: The script or characters in which Sanskrit and Hindi are written.
Decrescent: A crescent with the horns directed towards the sinister.
Deface: To destroy or mar the face or external appearance of; to disfigure; to injure, spoil, or mar, by effacing or obliterating important features or portions of; as, to deface a monument; to deface an edifice; to deface writing; to deface a note, deed, or bond; to deface a record.
Danite: A descendant of Dan; an Israelite of the tribe of Dan.
drive-by: accomplished while driving past in a vehicle; as, a drive-by shooting.
Duchess: The wife or widow of a duke; also, a lady who has the sovereignty of a duchy in her own right.
Dirigent: The line of motion along which a describent line or surface is carried in the genesis of any plane or solid figure; a directrix.
Demicadence: An imperfect or half cadence, falling on the dominant instead of on the key note.
Dreinte: p. p. of Drench to drown.
Deave: To stun or stupefy with noise; to deafen.
Diiodide: A compound of a binary type containing two atoms of iodine; -- called also biniodide.
Detestation: The act of detesting; extreme hatred or dislike; abhorrence; loathing.
Dastardliness: The quality of being dastardly; cowardice; base fear.
Delight: To have or take great delight or pleasure; to be greatly pleased or rejoiced; -- followed by an infinitive, or by in.
Dishcloth: A cloth used for washing dishes.
Drupaceous: Producing, or pertaining to, drupes; having the form of drupes; as, drupaceous trees or fruits.
deoxyribonucleotide: an organic molecule consisting of a hereocyclic base attached to the 1-carbon of a deoxyribose ring, with a phosphate group esterified at the 5 position of the deoxyribose.  Deoxyribonuceotides are the monomer units which make up deoxyribonucleic acid, the molecule carrying the hereditary information in most organisms.  The most common forms of deoxyribonuceotide are thymidine-5′-phosphate (abbreviated TMP), deoxyadenosine-5′-phosphate (abbreviated dAMP), deoxyguanosine-5′-phosphate (abbreviated dGMP), and deoxycytidine-5′-phosphate (abbreviated dCMP).
Dictamnus: A suffrutescent herb, Dictamnus Fraxinella (the only species), with strong perfume and showy flowers. The volatile oil of the leaves is highly inflammable.
Debtor: One who owes a debt; one who is indebted; -- correlative to creditor.
Dissilience: The act of leaping or starting asunder.
Daric: A gold coin of ancient Persia, weighing usually a little more than 128 grains, and bearing on one side the figure of an archer.
Debauchedness: The state of being debauched; intemperance.
Delegate: To send as one's representative; to empower as an ambassador; to send with power to transact business; to commission; to depute; to authorize.
Decitizenize: To deprive of the rights of citizenship.
Distribution: The act of distributing or dispensing; the act of dividing or apportioning among several or many; apportionment; as, the distribution of an estate among heirs or children.
Dimorphous: Characterized by dimorphism; occurring under two distinct forms, not dependent on sex; dimorphic.
Dean: A dignitary or presiding officer in certain ecclesiastical and lay bodies; esp., an ecclesiastical dignitary, subordinate to a bishop.
Deal: To make distribution; to share out in portions, as cards to the players.
Dead: To die; to lose life or force.
Dissatisfaction: The state of being dissatisfied, unsatisfied, or discontented; uneasiness proceeding from the want of gratification, or from disappointed wishes and expectations.
Dirge: A piece of music of a mournful character, to accompany funeral rites; a funeral hymn.
Differingly: In a differing or different manner.
Dolium: A genus of large univalve mollusks, including the partridge shell and tun shells.
Dowager: A widow endowed, or having a jointure; a widow who either enjoys a dower from her deceased husband, or has property of her own brought by her to her husband on marriage, and settled on her after his decease.
Dooryard: A yard in front of a house or around the door of a house.
Desilverize: To deprive, or free from, silver; to remove silver from.
Diet: A legislative or administrative assembly in Germany, Poland, and some other countries of Europe; a deliberative convention; a council; as, the Diet of Worms, held in 1521.
Deuterocanonical: Pertaining to a second canon, or ecclesiastical writing of inferior authority; -- said of the Apocrypha, certain Epistles, etc.
Dharma: the basic principles of the cosmos; also: an ancient sage in Hindu mythology worshipped as a god by some lower castes;.
dermatologist: One who discourses on the skin and its diseases; one versed in dermatology
Dauw: The striped quagga, or Burchell's zebra, of South Africa (Asinus Burchellii); -- called also peechi, or peetsi.
Daub: A viscous, sticky application; a spot smeared or daubed; a smear.
disinfection: The act of disinfecting; purification from infecting matter.
Daun: A variant of Dan, a title of honor.
Defray: To pay or discharge; to serve in payment of; to provide for, as a charge, debt, expenses, costs, etc.
dedicated: wholly committed to a purpose or cause; as, a dedicated musician.
Dullness: The state of being dull; slowness; stupidity; heaviness; drowsiness; bluntness; obtuseness; dimness; want of luster; want of vividness, or of brightness.
Diegesis: A narrative or history; a recital or relation.
Diaphysis: An abnormal prolongation of the axis of inflorescence.
Dexterous: Ready and expert in the use of the body and limbs; skillful and active with the hands; handy; ready; as, a dexterous hand; a dexterous workman.
Dungmeer: A pit where dung and weeds rot for manure.
deteriorate: To grow worse; to be impaired in quality; to degenerate.
disgusted: having a strong distaste from surfeit.
Dieter: One who diets; one who prescribes, or who partakes of, food, according to hygienic rules.
Disaffected: Alienated in feeling; not wholly loyal.
Dispersonate: To deprive of personality or individuality.
Disimprovement: Reduction from a better to a worse state; as, disimprovement of the earth; specific features which are worse than former features; disimprovements in the new Windows operating system.
Deaths-head: A naked human skull as the emblem of death; the head of the conventional personification of death.
deconstruction: A philosophical theory of criticism (usually of literature or film) that seeks to expose deep-seated contradictions in a work by delving below its surface meaning.  This method questions the ability of language to represent a fixed reality, and proposes that a text has no stable meaning because words only refer to other words, that metaphysical or ethnocentric assumptions about the meaning of words must be questioned, and words may be redefined in new contexts and new, equally valid and even contradictory meanings may be found.  Such new interpretations may be based on the philosophical, political, or social implications of the words of a text, rather than solely on attempts to determine the author's intentions.
Diesis: A small interval, less than any in actual practice, but used in the mathematical calculation of intervals.
Disseminate: to spread around widely; to sow broadcast or as seed; to scatter for growth and propagation, like seed; to spread abroad; to diffuse; as, principles, ideas, opinions, and errors are disseminated when they are spread abroad for propagation.
Diverb: A saying in which two members of the sentence are contrasted; an antithetical proverb.
Dully: In a dull manner; stupidly; slowly; sluggishly; without life or spirit.
Divers: Different in kind or species; diverse.
Dulcite: A white, sugarlike substance, C6H8.(OH)2, occurring naturally in a manna from Madagascar, and in certain plants, and produced artificially by the reduction of galactose and lactose or milk sugar.
Dictaphone: A form of phonographic recorder and reproducer adapted for use in dictation, as in business.
Devilship: The character or person of a devil or the devil.
Decapod: A crustacean with ten feet or legs, as a crab; one of the Decapoda. Also used adjectively, as a decapod crustacean.
Decomplex: Repeatedly compound; made up of complex constituents.
dickie-seat: A small 3rd seat in the back of an old-fashioned 2-seat car.
Drugget: A coarse woolen cloth dyed of one color or printed on one side; generally used as a covering for carpets.
Diminisher: One who, or that which, diminishes anything.
Deoppilate: To free from obstructions; to clear a passage through.
Datary: An officer in the pope's court, having charge of the Dataria.
degauss: To make a (steel) ship's hull nonmagnetic by applying an opposing magnetic field.
Draft: To draw the outline of; to delineate.
Dimissory: Sending away; dismissing to another jurisdiction; granting leave to depart.
Dipodomys: a genus of rodents of the family Heteromyidae, comprising the genus of kangaroo rats which live in arid regions of Mexico and the western U. S.
Despume: To free from spume or scum.
Dude: A kind of dandy; especially, one characterized by an ultrafashionable style of dress and other affectations.
Devitrify: To deprive of glasslike character; to take away vitreous luster and transparency from.
Duds: Old or inferior clothes; tattered garments.
Deification: The act of deifying; exaltation to divine honors; apotheosis; excessive praise.
Disulphide: A binary compound of sulphur containing two atoms of sulphur in each molecule; -- formerly called disulphuret.  Cf. Bisulphide.
Dermacentor: a genus comprising vectors of important diseases of man and animals.
Dareful: Full of daring or of defiance; adventurous.
Dicer: A player at dice; a dice player; a gamester.
Dearly: In a dear manner; with affection; heartily; earnestly; as, to love one dearly.
Dogsick: Sick as a dog sometimes is very sick.
Demolisher: One who, or that which, demolishes; as, a demolisher of towns.
diestrus: a state or interval of sexual inactivity or quiescence between periods of activity; -- of animals having several estrous cycles in one breeding season.
Drawback: A loss of advantage, or deduction from profit, value, success, etc.; a discouragement or hindrance; objectionable feature.
Disflesh: To reduce the flesh or obesity of.
deadlocked: at a complete standstill because of opposition of two unrelenting forces or factions.
Demoralization: The act of corrupting or subverting morals. Especially: The act of corrupting or subverting discipline, courage, hope, etc., or the state of being corrupted or subverted in discipline, courage, etc.; as, the demoralization of an army or navy.
Defection: Act of abandoning a person or cause to which one is bound by allegiance or duty, or to which one has attached himself; desertion; failure in duty; a falling away; apostasy; backsliding.
Diamond: Resembling a diamond; made of, or abounding in, diamonds; as, a diamond chain; a diamond field.
Disprivilege: To deprive of a privilege or privileges.
-derm: A suffix or terminal formative, much used in anatomical terms, and signifying skin, integument, covering; as, blastoderm, ectoderm, etc.
Denominable: Capable of being denominated or named.
Denudation: The act of stripping off covering, or removing the surface; a making bare.
Designation: The act of designating; a pointing out or showing; indication.
disabuse: To set free from mistakes; to undeceive; to disengage from fallacy or deception; to set right; -- often used with of; as, to disabuse one of his illusions.
Dogtrick: A gentle trot, like that of a dog.
Disprison: To let loose from prison, to set at liberty.
Directness: The quality of being direct; straightness; straightforwardness; immediateness.
Discontent: Want of content; uneasiness and inquietude of mind; dissatisfaction; disquiet.
dinky: small and insignificant; shabby or unimpressive; as, he drove to work in a dinky old Volkswagen; we stayed in a dinky little hotel.
declassification: reduction by the government of restrictions on a classified document or weapon.
Dictation: The act of dictating; the act or practice of prescribing; also that which is dictated.
Degraded: Reduced in rank, character, or reputation; debased; sunken; low; base.
Damaskeen: To decorate, as iron, steel, etc., with a peculiar marking or “water” produced in the process of manufacture, or with designs produced by inlaying or incrusting with another metal, as silver or gold, or by etching, etc., to damask.
Directorial: Having the quality of a director, or authoritative guide; directive.
Drainer: One who, or that which, drains.
decapitated: having had the head cut off.
Dulcorate: To sweeten; to make less acrimonious.
Dramatis person\u00e6: The actors in a drama or play.
Defecate: To become clear, pure, or free.
Derivement: That which is derived; deduction; inference.
Doctrinally: In a doctrinal manner or form; by way of teaching or positive direction.
Drip: A falling or letting fall in drops; a dripping; that which drips, or falls in drops.
Dispossess: To put out of possession; to deprive of the actual occupancy of, particularly of land or real estate; to disseize; to eject; -- usually followed by of before the thing taken away; as, to dispossess a king of his crown.
Digression: The act of digressing or deviating, esp. from the main subject of a discourse; hence, a part of a discourse deviating from its main design or subject.
Draughthouse: A house for the reception of waste matter; a privy.
Dissertational: Relating to dissertations; resembling a dissertation.
Decyl: A hydrocarbon radical, C10H21., never existing alone, but regarded as the characteristic constituent of a number of compounds of the paraffin series.
Dyadic: Pertaining to the number two; of two parts or elements.
Dendriform: Resembling in structure a tree or shrub; having a branching shape.
Diphyllous: Having two leaves, as a calyx, etc.
Denationalization: The act or process of denationalizing.
Disenchanter: One who, or that which, disenchants.
Denotation: The marking off or separation of anything.
Dithionic: Containing two equivalents of sulphur; as, dithionic acid.
Differentiate: To acquire a distinct and separate character.
Draconin: A red resin forming the essential basis of dragon's blood; -- called also dracin.
Draconic: Relating to Draco, the Athenian lawgiver; or to the constellation Draco; or to dragon's blood.
deprecate: To pray against, as an evil; to seek to avert by prayer; to seek deliverance from; to express deep regret for; to desire the removal of.
Dorsoventral: From the dorsal to the ventral side of an animal; as, the dorsoventral axis.
Dogbane: A small genus of perennial herbaceous plants, with poisonous milky juice, bearing slender pods pods in pairs.
Desultorily: In a desultory manner; without method; loosely; immethodically.
decompressing: the process of experiencing decompression; the act or process of relieving or reducing pressure.
Dodecagon: A figure or polygon bounded by twelve sides and containing twelve angles.
Diomedea: A genus of large sea birds, including the albatross. See Albatross.
druggist: One who deals in drugs; especially, one who buys and sells drugs without compounding them; one who owns or operates a drugstore.
Dumpy: Short and thick; of low stature and disproportionately stout.
Divulsive: Tending to pull asunder, tear, or rend; distracting.
dressage: maneuvers of a horse in response to body signals by the rider.
Duelist: One who fights in single combat.
Dispositively: In a dispositive manner; by natural or moral disposition.
dartboard: a circular board of wood or cork used as the target in the game of darts.  It may have any of several patterns on it, such as concentric circles, or a central circle with rays.
Digestibleness: The quality of being digestible; digestibility.
Danburite: A borosilicate of lime, first found at Danbury, Conn. It is near the topaz in form.
Didelphys: Formerly, any marsupial; but the term is now restricted to an American genus which includes the opossums, of which there are many species. See Opossum. [Written also Didelphis.] See Illustration in Appendix.
Demonstrableness: The quality of being demonstrable; demonstrability.
Desmodontidae: a natural family comprisng the true vampire bats.
Deerlet: A chevrotain. See Kanchil, and Napu.
Doorstep: The stone or plank forming a step before an outer door.
Decacerata: The division of Cephalopoda which includes the squids, cuttlefishes, and others having ten arms or tentacles; -- called also Decapoda. [Written also Decacera.] See Dibranchiata.
despond: To give up the will, courage, or spirit; to be thoroughly disheartened; to lose all courage; to become dispirited or depressed; to take an unhopeful view.
Death: The cessation of all vital phenomena without capability of resuscitation, either in animals or plants.
Dalmatica: A vestment with wide sleeves, and with two stripes, worn at Mass by deacons, and by bishops at pontifical Mass; -- imitated from a dress originally worn in Dalmatia.
Ditone: The Greek major third, which comprehend two major tones (the modern major third contains one major and one minor whole tone).
Decumbence: The act or posture of lying down.
Disgorge: To vomit forth what anything contains; to discharge; to make restitution.
Dismettled: Destitute of mettle, that is, or fire or spirit.
Dentist: One whose business it is to clean, extract, or repair natural teeth, and to make and insert artificial ones; a dental surgeon.
Dissolvable: Capable of being dissolved, or separated into component parts; capable of being liquefied; soluble.
down-market: designed for low-income consumers.  Opposite of upmarket.
dead-on: precisely accurate and to the point; as, a dead-on feel for characterization.
Discompany: To free from company; to dissociate.
Degu: A small South American rodent (Octodon Cumingii), of the family Octodontidæ.
developing: the process of treating a photosensitive material with chemicals in order to make a latent image visible.
Deterge: To cleanse; to purge away, as foul or offending matter from the body, or from an ulcer.
Durability: The state or quality of being durable; the power of uninterrupted or long continuance in any condition; the power of resisting agents or influences which tend to cause changes, decay, or dissolution; lastingness.
duplexer: a device which switches electronic circuitry so that a radio antenna can function as either a transmitting or receiving antenna.
Disproperty: To cause to be no longer property; to dispossess of.
Decivilize: To reduce from civilization to a savage state.
Dominican: One of an order of mendicant monks founded by Dominic de Guzman, in 1215. A province of the order was established in England in 1221. The first foundation in the United States was made in 1807. The Master of the Sacred Palace at Rome is always a Dominican friar. The Dominicans are called also preaching friars, friars preachers, black friars (from their black cloak), brothers of St. Mary, and in France, Jacobins.
Doughiness: The quality or state of being doughy.
Dandyize: To make, or to act, like a dandy; to dandify.
Delawares: A tribe of Indians formerly inhabiting the valley of the Delaware River, but now mostly located in the Indian Territory.
document: That which is taught or authoritatively set forth; precept; instruction; dogma.
Diachylon: A plaster originally composed of the juices of several plants (whence its name), but now made of an oxide of lead and oil, and consisting essentially of glycerin mixed with lead salts of the fat acids.
Dormy: Up, or ahead, as many holes as remain to be played; -- said of a player or side.
Dasypus: the type genus of the Dasypodidae.
Declarator: A form of action by which some right or interest is sought to be judicially declared.
Diphthong: To form or pronounce as a diphthong; diphthongize.
desalinate: to remove the salt from, especially from water; as, it is necessary to desalinate sea water to make it fit to drink.
Decachord: An ancient Greek musical instrument of ten strings, resembling the harp.
Ditolyl: A white, crystalline, aromatic hydrocarbon, C14H14, consisting of two radicals or residues of toluene.
Dioxindol: A white, crystalline, nitrogenous substance obtained by the reduction of isatin. It is a member of the indol series; -- hence its name.
Decapoda: The order of Crustacea which includes the shrimps, lobsters, crabs, etc.
Decayed: Fallen, as to physical or social condition; affected with decay; rotten; as, decayed vegetation or vegetables; a decayed fortune or gentleman.
Dune: A low hill of drifting sand usually formed on the coats, but often carried far inland by the prevailing winds.
Distitle: To deprive of title or right.
Drawbench: A machine in which strips of metal are drawn through a drawplate; especially, one in which wire is thus made; -- also called drawing bench.
Dross: The scum or refuse matter which is thrown off, or falls from, metals in smelting the ore, or in the process of melting; recrement.
Deemster: A judge in the Isle of Man who decides controversies without process.
Diffusion: The act of diffusing, or the state of being diffused; a spreading; extension; dissemination; circulation; dispersion.
Dissymmetry: Absence or defect of symmetry; asymmetry.
detoxify: to remove poison from; to rid of the effects of poison.
dust storm: A strong windstorm that lifts particles of dust or dry soil into the air and blows them around, covering land or objects with a thick layer of dust.  Dust storms may occur in arable areas during periods of drought; when a similar storm occurs in a desert area, such a storm is called a sandstorm.
disputant: One who disputes; one who argues in opposition to another; one appointed to dispute; a controvertist; a reasoner in opposition.
Disperse: To separate; to go or move into different parts; to vanish; as, the company dispersed at ten o'clock; the clouds disperse.
Destitute: To leave destitute; to forsake; to abandon.
Debase: To reduce from a higher to a lower state or grade of worth, dignity, purity, station, etc.; to degrade; to lower; to deteriorate; to abase; as, to debase the character by crime; to debase the mind by frivolity; to debase style by vulgar words.
Deflector: That which deflects, as a diaphragm in a furnace, or a cone in a lamp (to deflect and mingle air and gases and help combustion).
Dropsical: Diseased with dropsy; hydropical; tending to dropsy; as, a dropsical patient.
Demersion: The act of plunging into a fluid; a drowning.
Drivebolt: A drift; a tool for setting bolts home.
drawnwork: ornamental needlework done by drawing threads to form lacelike patterns.
Disfranchisement: The act of disfranchising, or the state of being disfranchised; deprivation of privileges of citizenship or of chartered immunities.
desynchronize: to cause a process to occur at times or in cycles independent of another process.
Demonstrativeness: The state or quality of being demonstrative.
Discernible: Capable of being discerned by the eye or the understanding; as, a star is discernible by the eye; the identity of difference of ideas is discernible by the understanding.
Dredge: To sift or sprinkle flour, etc., on, as on roasting meat.
Deoppilation: Removal of whatever stops up the passages.
Drive: The act of driving; a trip or an excursion in a carriage, as for exercise or pleasure; -- distinguished from a ride taken on horseback.
Draw-cut: A single cut with a knife.
Discernibly: In a manner to be discerned; perceptibly; visibly.
Domiculture: The art of house-keeping, cookery, etc.
Diligence: A four-wheeled public stagecoach, used in France.
Demiculverin: A kind of ordnance, carrying a ball weighing from nine to thirteen pounds.
Dipteryx: a genus of tropical American trees which produce a black seed called the tonka bean.
Depressive: Able or tending to depress or cast down.
disinfectant: That which disinfects, especially an agent for killing or removing the microorganisms which cause infection.  Commonly used disinfectants are chlorine, sodium hypochlorite solution, hydrogen peroxide, and alcohol.
Decillionth: The quotient of unity divided by a decillion.
Depolish: To remove the polish or glaze from.
Disexercise: To deprive of exercise; to leave untrained.
Disadvantageous: Attended with disadvantage; unfavorable to success or prosperity; inconvenient; prejudicial; -- opposed to advantageous; as, the situation of an army is disadvantageous for attack or defense.
Dimit: To dismiss, let go, or release.
Definement: The act of defining; definition; description.
Decimalize: to convert the dominant units of measure (e.g. of currency) to a decimal-based system; to reduce to a decimal system; as, to decimalize the currency.
Durableness: Power of lasting, enduring, or resisting; durability.
Dogbolt: The bolt of the cap-square over the trunnion of a cannon.
Dietetic: Of or performance to diet, or to the rules for regulating the kind and quantity of food to be eaten.
decimalization: the act of changing to a decimal system; as, the decimalization of the British currency.
Deed poll: A deed of one part, or executed by only one party, and distinguished from an indenture by having the edge of the parchment or paper cut even, or polled as it was anciently termed, instead of being indented.
Disable: To render unable or incapable; to destroy the force, vigor, or power of action of; to deprive of competent physical or intellectual power; to incapacitate; to disqualify; to make incompetent or unfit for service; to impair.
Dogberry: The berry of the dogwood; -- called also dogcherry.
