drive-through: arranged to allow business to be transacted or sights to be seen while patrons remain in their vehicles; as, a drive-through car wash; a drive-through safari park.
Dwindle: The process of dwindling; dwindlement; decline; degeneracy.
Distrusting: That distrusts; suspicious; lacking confidence in.
Diaconal: Of or pertaining to a deacon.
Decolorize: To deprive of color; to whiten.
Dividual: Divided, shared, or participated in, in common with others.
Damage: To receive damage or harm; to be injured or impaired in soundness or value; as, some colors in cloth damage in sunlight.
Deludable: Capable of being deluded; liable to be imposed on; gullible.
Didynamia: A Linnæan class of plants having four stamens disposed in pairs of unequal length.
Deathblow: A mortal or crushing blow; a stroke or event which kills or destroys.
Disendowment: The act of depriving of an endowment or endowments.
Dismally: In a dismal manner; gloomily; sorrowfully; uncomfortably.
doorknocker: a device (usually metal and ornamental) attached by a hinge to a door, which may be swung by hand against the door to make a loud knocking sound.
Dorsally: On, or toward, the dorsum, or back; on the dorsal side of; dorsad.
Delibrate: To strip off the bark; to peel.
dinnertime: the time when people eat dinner, usually the time for the evening meal.
dominated: controlled or ruled by superior authority or power.
Defacement: The act of defacing, or the condition of being defaced; injury to the surface or exterior; obliteration.
Dedicate: To set apart and consecrate, as to a divinity, or for sacred uses; to devote formally and solemnly; as, to dedicate vessels, treasures, a temple, or a church, to a religious use.
Debased: Turned upside down from its proper position; inverted; reversed.
Debaser: One who, or that which, debases.
Double dealer: One who practices double dealing; a deceitful, trickish person; a person who says one thing and does another.
Danaide: A water wheel having a vertical axis, and an inner and outer tapering shell, between which are vanes or floats attached usually to both shells, but sometimes only to one.
Dressing: Dress; raiment; especially, ornamental habiliment or attire.
Derelict: A thing voluntary abandoned or willfully cast away by its proper owner, especially a ship abandoned at sea.
disorienting: causing disorientation: causing confusion of directions.
Desideratum: Anything desired; that of which the lack is felt; a want generally felt and acknowledge.
Deep-waisted: Having a deep waist, as when, in a ship, the poop and forecastle are much elevated above the deck.
Direptitiously: With plundering violence; by violent injustice.
Ducatoon: A silver coin of several countries of Europe, and of different values.
Disbench: To drive from a bench or seat.
Dead-pay: Pay drawn for soldiers, or others, really dead, whose names are kept on the rolls.
Deducibleness: The quality of being deducible; deducibility.
Dole: To deal out in small portions; to distribute, as a dole; to deal out scantily or grudgingly.
Disillusion: To free from an illusion; to disillusionize.
drippy: persistently dripping even when shut; as, a drippy faucet.
Dipody: Two metrical feet taken together, or included in one measure.
Diesinker: An engraver of dies for stamping coins, medals, etc.
Detonate: To cause to explode; to cause to burn or inflame with a sudden report.
Diocese: The circuit or extent of a bishop's jurisdiction; the district in which a bishop exercises his ecclesiastical authority.
Dimethyl: Ethane; -- sometimes so called because regarded as consisting of two methyl radicals. See Ethane.
Dehumanize: To divest of human qualities, such as pity, tenderness, etc.; as, dehumanizing influences.
Doubtful: Not settled in opinion; undetermined; wavering; hesitating in belief; also used, metaphorically, of the body when its action is affected by such a state of mind; as, we are doubtful of a fact, or of the propriety of a measure.
Dismastment: The act of dismasting; the state of being dismasted.
Dextrin: A translucent, gummy, amorphous substance, nearly tasteless and odorless, used as a substitute for gum, for sizing, etc., and obtained from starch by the action of heat, acids, or diastase. It is of somewhat variable composition, containing several carbohydrates which change easily to their respective varieties of sugar. It is so named from its rotating the plane of polarization to the right; -- called also British gum, Alsace gum, gommelin, leiocome, etc. See Achroödextrin, and Erythrodextrin.
Douay Bible: A translation of the Scriptures into the English language for the use of English-speaking Roman Catholics; -- done from the Latin Vulgate by English scholars resident in France. The New Testament portion was published at Rheims, A. D. 1582, the Old Testament at Douai, A. D. 1609-10. Various revised editions have since been published.
Disusage: Gradual cessation of use or custom; neglect of use; disuse.
Deare: variant of Dere, v. t. & n.
deep-fried: Fried in fat or oil deep enough to cover the object.
Disprovide: Not to provide; to fail to provide.
dendrology: the branch of botany studying trees and shrubs; the natural history of trees.
Diradiation: The emission and diffusion of rays of light.
Dunlin: A species of sandpiper (Tringa alpina); -- called also churr, dorbie, grass bird, and red-backed sandpiper. It is found both in Europe and America.
Decanal: Pertaining to a dean or deanery.
doorlock: a lock on an exterior door.
Damewort: A cruciferrous plant (Hesperis matronalis), remarkable for its fragrance, especially toward the close of the day; -- called also rocket and dame's violet.
Daisy: A genus of low herbs (Bellis), belonging to the family Compositæ. The common English and classical daisy is Bellis perennis, which has a yellow disk and white or pinkish rays.
Determinate: To bring to an end; to determine. See Determine.
Deer: Any animal; especially, a wild animal.
Deep: That which is deep, especially deep water, as the sea or ocean; an abyss; a great depth.
Dictograph: A telephonic instrument for office or other similar use, having a sound-magnifying device enabling the ordinary mouthpiece to be dispensed with. Much use has been made of it for overhearing, or for recording, conversations for the purpose of obtaining evidence for use in litigation.
Devotement: The state of being devoted, or set apart by a vow.
Deed: To convey or transfer by deed; as, he deeded all his estate to his eldest son.
Decine: One of the higher hydrocarbons, C10H15, of the acetylene series; -- called also decenylene.
Dorking fowl: One of a breed of large-bodied domestic fowls, having five toes, or the hind toe double. There are several strains, as the white, gray, and silver-gray. They are highly esteemed for the table.
Divot: A thin, oblong turf used for covering cottages, and also for fuel.
deaccession: to sell (artwork); -- used of sales of art by museums.
Delilah: The mistress of Samson, who betrayed him (Judges xvi.); hence, a harlot; a temptress.
Dessert: A service of pastry, fruits, or sweetmeats, at the close of a feast or entertainment; pastry, fruits, etc., forming the last course at dinner.
Deutoxide: A compound containing in the molecule two atoms of oxygen united with some other element or radical; -- usually called dioxide, or less frequently, binoxide.
disfranchised: deprived of the rights of citizenship especially the right to vote.  Opposite of enfranchised.
denotatum: the actual object referred to by a linguistic expression.
Dia-: A prefix denoting through; also, between, apart, asunder, across. Before a vowel dia- becomes di-; as, diactinic; dielectric, etc.
decollate: To sever from the neck; to behead; to decapitate.
Demurely: In a demure manner; soberly; gravely; -- now, commonly, with a mere show of gravity or modesty.
Dimorphic: Having the property of dimorphism; dimorphous.
Diffuseness: The quality of being diffuse; especially, in writing, the use of a great or excessive number of word to express the meaning; copiousness; verbosity; prolixity.
Deprive: To take away; to put an end; to destroy.
Doveship: The possession of dovelike qualities, harmlessness and innocence.
Disreputation: Loss or want of reputation or good name; dishonor; disrepute; disesteem.
Distinctive: Marking or expressing distinction or difference; distinguishing; characteristic; peculiar.
Deniable: Capable of being, or liable to be, denied.
Dissoluteness: State or quality of being dissolute; looseness of morals and manners; addictedness to sinful pleasures; debauchery; dissipation.
Duteous: Fulfilling duty; dutiful; having the sentiments due to a superior, or to one to whom respect or service is owed; obedient; as, a duteous son or daughter.
Depilatory: Having the quality or power of removing hair.
desexualize: to direct one's libidinous urges into another direction.
Diaper: To draw flowers or figures, as upon cloth.
Dupion: A double cocoon, made by two silkworms.
Disgorgement: The act of disgorging; a vomiting; that which is disgorged.
Daddle: To toddle; to walk unsteadily, like a child or an old man; hence, to do anything slowly or feebly.
Diminuendo: In a gradually diminishing manner; with abatement of tone; decrescendo; -- expressed on the staff by Dim., or Dimin., or the sign.
Delete: To blot out; to erase; to expunge; to dele; to omit.
Dynastidan: One of a group of gigantic, horned beetles, including Dynastus Neptunus, and the Hercules beetle (Dynastus Hercules) of tropical America, which grow to be six inches in length.
Disappropriate: To release from individual ownership or possession.
Dys\u00e6sthesia: Impairment of any of the senses, esp. of touch.
Durable: Able to endure or continue in a particular condition; lasting; not perishable or changeable; not wearing out or decaying soon; enduring; as, durable cloth; durable happiness.
Drover: One who drives cattle or sheep to market; one who makes it his business to purchase cattle, and drive them to market.
dominating: exercising influence or control.  Opposite of subordinate.
Durably: In a lasting manner; with long continuance.
Dacron: a brand of polyester textile fiber, or the wrinkle-resistant fabric prepared from it.
dressed-up: attired in fancy or formal clothing.
diabetes: Any of several diseases which is attended with a persistent, excessive discharge of urine; when used without qualification, the term usually refers to diabetes mellitus. The most common form is diabetes mellitus, in which the urine is not only increased in quantity, but contains saccharine matter, and the condition if untreated is generally fatal.
dustcart: a truck for collecting domestic refuse; as, in England a garbage truck is called a dustcart.
Dentirostral: Having a toothed bill; -- applied to a group of passerine birds, having the bill notched, and feeding chiefly on insects, as the shrikes and vireos. See Illust. (N) under Beak.
Delta: The fourth letter of the Greek alphabet (Δ δ), corresponding to D.
Driveler: A slaverer; a slabberer; an idiot; a fool.
Determinable: Capable of being determined, definitely ascertained, decided upon, or brought to a conclusion.
Dysnomy: Bad legislation; the enactment of bad laws.
Decimeter: A measure of length in the metric system; one tenth of a meter, equal to 3.937 inches.
Decrease: A becoming less; gradual diminution; decay; as, a decrease of revenue or of strength.
dyslectic: having impaired ability to comprehend written words; a condition usually associated with a neurologic disorder.
Disciplinary: Pertaining to discipline; intended for discipline; corrective; belonging to a course of training.
Depend: To hang down; to be sustained by being fastened or attached to something above.
deflationary: of or pertaining to deflation; as, deflationary signs.
Dense: Having the constituent parts massed or crowded together; close; compact; thick; containing much matter in a small space; heavy; opaque; as, a dense crowd; a dense forest; a dense fog.
dustcloth: A piece of cloth used for wiping dust from objects or surfaces.
Deforcement: A keeping out by force or wrong; a wrongful withholding, as of lands or tenements, to which another has a right.
Denotative: Having power to denote; designating or marking off.
Demesmerize: To relieve from mesmeric influence. See Mesmerize.
Denotable: Capable of being denoted or marked.
Dangerous: Attended or beset with danger; full of risk; perilous; hazardous; unsafe.
Disennoble: To deprive of that which ennobles; to degrade.
Droughtiness: A state of dryness of the weather; want of rain.
Depreciative: Tending, or intended, to depreciate; expressing depreciation; undervaluing.
Dysprosium: An element of the rare earth-group. Symbol Dy; at. wt., 162.5.
Dietine: A subordinate or local assembly; a diet of inferior rank.
doohickey: Any object, usually a tool or other device, whose name is forgotten, or not known.
Difform: Irregular in form; -- opposed to uniform; anomalous; hence, unlike; dissimilar; as, to difform corolla, the parts of which do not correspond in size or proportion; difform leaves.
Delphinic: Pertaining to, or derived from, the larkspur; specifically, relating to the stavesacre (Delphinium staphisagria).
de-escalate: to reduce in intensity (a crisis or a war).
Dandy: One who affects special finery or gives undue attention to dress; a fop; a coxcomb.
Detest: To witness against; to denounce; to condemn.
Defensible: Capable of being defended; as, a defensible city, or a defensible cause.
diatomaceous earth: a deposit of fine, usually white, siliceous material, composed mainly of the shells of the microscopic plants called diatoms; also called infusorial earth, kieselguhr, and diatomite. It is used in polishing powder, and in the manufacture of dynamite.
Dreg: Corrupt or defiling matter contained in a liquid, or precipitated from it; refuse; feculence; lees; grounds; sediment; hence, the vilest and most worthless part of anything; as, the dregs of society.
Desolate: To make desolate; to leave alone; to deprive of inhabitants; as, the earth was nearly desolated by the flood.
Demisuit: A suit of light armor covering less than the whole body, as having no protection for the legs below the thighs, no vizor to the helmet, and the like.
Demonstrable: Capable of being demonstrated; that can be proved beyond doubt or question.
Demonstrably: In a demonstrable manner; incontrovertibly; clearly.
Despotism: The power, spirit, or principles of a despot; absolute control over others; tyrannical sway; tyranny.
Dilleniidae: a group of families of more or less advanced trees and shrubs and herbs having either polypetalous or gamopetalous corollas and often with ovules attached to the walls of the ovary; it contains 69 families including Ericaceae and Cruciferae and Malvaceae; it is sometimes classified as a superorder.
Distinguishable: Capable of being distinguished; separable; divisible; discernible; capable of recognition; as, a tree at a distance is distinguishable from a shrub.
Dismail: To divest of coat of mail.
Demonstrability: The quality of being demonstrable; demonstrableness.
Decene: One of the higher hydrocarbons, C10H20, of the ethylene series.
deoxyribose: a pentose (C5H10O4) in which one of the hydroxyl groups of ribose has been replaced by a hydrogen.  In deoxyribonucleic acids, the deoxyribose is D-2-deoxyribose, in which the hydroxyl at the 2 position of ribose is the one which is replaced by hydrogen.
Displeasing: Causing displeasure or dissatisfaction; offensive; disagreeable.
Deliquium: A melting or dissolution in the air, or in a moist place; a liquid condition; as, a salt falls into a deliquium.
Depolarization: The act of depriving of polarity, or the result of such action; reduction to an unpolarized condition.
Dengue: A specific epidemic disease attended with high fever, cutaneous eruption, and severe pains in the head and limbs, resembling those of rheumatism; -- called also breakbone fever. It occurs in India, Egypt, the West Indies, etc., is of short duration, and rarely fatal.
Doughfaceism: The character of a doughface; truckling pliability.
Diaphanometer: An instrument for measuring the transparency of the air.
Dehydration: The act or process of freeing from water; also, the condition of a body from which the water has been removed.
Denticle: A small tooth or projecting point.
Decasyllabic: Having, or consisting of, ten syllables.
Discussion: The act or process of discussing by breaking up, or dispersing, as a tumor, or the like.
Diarrhea: A morbidly frequent and profuse discharge of loose or fluid evacuations from the intestines, without tenesmus; a purging or looseness of the bowels; a flux.
Dyslysin: A resinous substance formed in the decomposition of cholic acid of bile; -- so called because it is difficult to solve.
derivatize: to alter the chemical composition [of a compound] by a chemical reaction which changes some part of the molecule, leaving most of the molecule unchanged; to prepare a derivative{6} from.
D\u00e6dal: Cunningly or ingeniously formed or working; skillful; artistic; ingenious.
Doffer: A revolving cylinder, or a vibrating bar, with teeth, in a carding machine, which doffs, or strips off, the fiber from the cards.
Dreynte: p. p., of Drench to drown.
Dedimus: A writ to commission private persons to do some act in place of a judge, as to examine a witness, etc.
Deanery: The office or the revenue of a dean. See the Note under Benefice, n., 3.
Diocesan: A bishop, viewed in relation to his diocese; as, the diocesan of New York.
Dynamograph: A dynamometer to which is attached a device for automatically registering muscular power.
Donna: A lady; madam; mistress; -- the title given a lady in Italy.
Disroot: To tear up the roots of, or by the roots; hence, to tear from a foundation; to uproot.
D\u00e9nouement: The unraveling or discovery of a plot; the catastrophe, especially of a drama or a romance.
Disparagement: Matching any one in marriage under his or her degree; injurious union with something of inferior excellence; a lowering in rank or estimation.
Dendroaspis: a genus of African snakes comprising the mambas.
Departer: One who refines metals by separation.
Done: Given; executed; issued; made public; -- used chiefly in the clause giving the date of a proclamation or public act.
Doni: A clumsy craft, having one mast with a long sail, used for trading purposes on the coasts of Coromandel and Ceylon.
Defender: One who defends; one who maintains, supports, protects, or vindicates; a champion; an advocate; a vindicator.
Disintegration: The process by which anything is disintegrated; the condition of anything which is disintegrated.
Denunciatory: Characterized by or containing a denunciation; minatory; accusing; threatening; as, severe and denunciatory language.
Directive: Having power to direct; tending to direct, guide, or govern; showing the way.
Displayed: Unfolded; expanded; exhibited conspicuously or ostentatiously.
Dress circle: A gallery or balcony in a theater, generally the first above the floor, in which originally dress clothes were customarily worn.
Decumbiture: Confinement to a sick bed, or time of taking to one's bed from sickness.
Didymium: A rare metallic substance usually associated with the metal cerium; -- hence its name. It was formerly supposed to be an element, but has since been found to consist of two simpler elementary substances, neodymium and praseodymium. See Neodymium, and Praseodymium.
Dictator: One who dictates; one who prescribes rules and maxims authoritatively for the direction of others.
Durst: of Dare. See Dare, v. i.
Densimeter: An instrument for ascertaining the specific gravity or density of a substance.
Diablerie: Devilry; sorcery or incantation; a diabolical deed; mischief.
Duchesse dAngoul\u00eame: A variety of pear of large size and excellent flavor.
Dingle: A narrow dale; a small dell; a small, secluded, and embowered valley.
database: an organized body of related information.
docker: a laborer who loads and unloads vessels in a port.
Dilatory: Inclined to defer or put off what ought to be done at once; given the procrastination; delaying; procrastinating; loitering; as, a dilatory servant.
Davy Jones: The spirit of the sea; sea devil; -- a term used by sailors.
Douse: To put out; to extinguish; as, douse the lights.
dissimulation: The act of dissembling; a hiding under a false appearance; concealment by feigning; false pretension; hypocrisy.
Debtee: One to whom a debt is due; creditor; -- correlative to debtor.
decontamination: The removal of contaminants; as, the decontamination of a room after a spill of radioactive materials.
Disquisitional: Pertaining to disquisition; of the nature of disquisition.
Dagswain: A coarse woolen fabric made of daglocks, or the refuse of wool.
Dehiscent: Characterized by dehiscence; opening in some definite way, as the capsule of a plant.
Deliberative: A discourse in which a question is discussed, or weighed and examined.
Decardinalize: To depose from the rank of cardinal.
dactyl: A poetical foot of three sylables (--- ˘ ˘), one long followed by two short, or one accented followed by two unaccented; as, L. tëgm&ibreve_;n&ebreve_;, E. mer"ciful; -- so called from the similarity of its arrangement to that of the joints of a finger.
day boarder: a schoolchild at a boarding school who has meals at school but sleeps at home.
Deckle edge: The rough, untrimmed edge of paper left by the deckle; also, a rough edge in imitation of this.
Dictate: A statement delivered with authority; an order; a command; an authoritative rule, principle, or maxim; a prescription; as, listen to the dictates of your conscience; the dictates of the gospel.
Distractedness: A state of being distracted; distraction.
Doggerel: A sort of loose or irregular verse; mean or undignified poetry.
Disgarnish: To divest of garniture; to disfurnish; to dismantle.
Disorient: To turn away from the east; to confuse as to which way is east; to cause to lose one's bearings.
Difficult: To render difficult; to impede; to perplex.
Decretive: Having the force of a decree; determining.
Disposition: The act of disposing, arranging, ordering, regulating, or transferring; application; disposal; as, the disposition of a man's property by will.
Draughty: Pertaining to a draught, or current of air; as, a draughtly, comfortless room.
Disingenuous: Not noble; unbecoming true honor or dignity; mean; unworthy; as, disingenuous conduct or schemes.
Declination: The act or state of bending downward; inclination; as, declination of the head.
Dew-point: The temperature at which dew begins to form. It varies with the humidity and temperature of the atmosphere.
Deobstruct: To remove obstructions or impediments in; to clear from anything that hinders the passage of fluids; as, to deobstruct the pores or lacteals.
Despecificate: To discriminate; to separate according to specific signification or qualities; to specificate; to desynonymize.
Distant: Separated; having an intervening space; at a distance; away.
Dartos: A thin layer of peculiar contractile tissue directly beneath the skin of the scrotum.
Droop: A drooping; as, a droop of the eye.
Drool: To drivel, or drop saliva; as, the child drools.
diiodotyrosine: a chemical substance consisting of tyrosine with two hydrogen atoms on the benzene ring replaced by iodine atoms.
Domical: Relating to, or shaped like, a dome.
Denomination: The act of naming or designating.
Defoliate: Deprived of leaves, as by their natural fall.
duplicature: A doubling; a fold, as of a membrane.
Derailment: The act of going off, or the state of being off, the rails of a railroad.
downstairs: Down the stairs; to a lower floor; as, she headed downstairs as soon as she heard the horn.
Displode: To burst with a loud report; to explode.
Distrainor: One who distrains; the party distraining goods or chattels.
Defiant: Full of defiance; bold; insolent; as, a defiant spirit or act.
Deuterozooid: One of the secondary, and usually sexual, zooids produced by budding or fission from the primary zooids, in animals having alternate generations. In the tapeworms, the joints are deuterozooids.
Dwarfish: Like a dwarf; below the common stature or size; very small; petty; as, a dwarfish animal, shrub.
Disannul: To annul completely; to render void or of no effect.
Doubleness: The state of being double or doubled.
Dextrorotatory: Turning, or causing to turn, toward the right hand; esp., turning the plane of polarization of luminous rays toward the right hand; as, dextrorotatory crystals, sugars, etc.  Cf. Levorotatory.
Default: To fail to perform or pay; to be guilty of neglect of; to omit; as, to default a dividend.
Delve: A place dug; a pit; a ditch; a den; a cave.
dasher: That which dashes or agitates; as, the dasher of a churn.
Demiurgic: Pertaining to a demiurge; formative; creative.
draw: To cause to move continuously by force applied in advance of the thing moved; to pull along; to haul; to drag; to cause to follow.
Dynamometric: Relating to a dynamometer, or to the measurement of force doing work; as, dynamometrical instruments.
Discorporate: Deprived of the privileges or form of a body corporate.
Decalogue: The Ten Commandments or precepts given by God to Moses on Mount Sinai, and originally written on two tables of stone.
Documentary: Pertaining to written evidence; contained or certified in writing.
Declaim: To utter in public; to deliver in a rhetorical or set manner.
Discursion: The act of discoursing or reasoning; range, as from thought to thought.
Designable: Capable of being designated or distinctly marked out; distinguishable.
Diandrous: Of or pertaining to the class Diandria; having two stamens.
Disarray: Want of array or regular order; disorder; confusion.
Diagraphics: The art or science of descriptive drawing; especially, the art or science of drawing by mechanical appliances and mathematical rule.
Doublet: Two of the same kind; a pair; a couple.
Dodecatemory: A tern applied to the twelve houses, or parts, of the zodiac of the primum mobile, to distinguish them from the twelve signs; also, any one of the twelve signs of the zodiac.
Digamous: Pertaining to a second marriage, that is, one after the death of the first wife or the first husband.
Diodont: Like or pertaining to the genus Diodon.
dogie: a motherless calf in a range herd of cattle.
Day-net: A net for catching small birds.
Decuman: Large; chief; -- applied to an extraordinary billow, supposed by some to be every tenth in order. [R.] Also used substantively.
Disassociate: To disconnect from things associated; to disunite; to dissociate.
Detortion: The act of detorting, or the state of being detorted; a twisting or warping.
Dravidic: one of the languages native to southern India; a Dravidian language.
Doomsday: A day of sentence or condemnation; day of death.
disherison: The act of disheriting, or debarring from inheritance; disinherison.
Defacer: One who, or that which, defaces or disfigures.
Dipropargyl: A pungent, mobile, volatile liquid, C6H6, produced artificially from certain allyl derivatives. Though isomeric with benzine, it is very different in its chemical relations. Called also dipropinyl.
Deliriant: A poison which occasions a persistent delirium, or mental aberration (as belladonna).
Dulcimer: An instrument, having stretched metallic wires which are beaten with two light hammers held in the hands of the performer.
Datiscin: A white crystalline glucoside extracted from the bastard hemp (Datisca cannabina).
Deferrer: One who defers or puts off.
Debating: The act of discussing or arguing; discussion.
Deplorable: Worthy of being deplored or lamented; lamentable; causing grief; hence, sad; calamitous; grievous; wretched; as, life's evils are deplorable.
Dactyliography: The art of writing or engraving upon gems.
Dichogamy: The condition of certain species of plants, in which the stamens and pistil do not mature simultaneously, so that these plants can never fertilize themselves.
Deterioration: The process of growing worse, or the state of having grown worse.
Diandria: A Linnæan class of plants having two stamens.
Debauchment: The act of corrupting; the act of seducing from virtue or duty.
Discontinue: To lose continuity or cohesion of parts; to be disrupted or broken off.
Dispensatory: A book or medicinal formulary containing a systematic description of drugs, and of preparations made from them. It is usually, but not always, distinguished from a pharmacopœia in that it issued by private parties, and not by an official body or by government.
Disputer: One who disputes, or who is given to disputes; a controvertist.
Dilogy: An ambiguous speech; a figure in which a word is used an equivocal sense.
denigrating: harmful and often untrue; tending to discredit or malign; -- used of statements.
Disorderly: In a disorderly manner; without law or order; irregularly; confusedly.
Decameter: A measure of length in the metric system; ten meters, equal to about 393.7 inches.
Donzel: A young squire, or knight's attendant; a page.
Disburden: To relieve one's self of a burden; to ease the mind.
disabling: causing or having caused disability; rendering disabled; as, disabling injury.
Disfigurement: Act of disfiguring, or state of being disfigured; deformity.
Disworship: A deprivation of honor; a cause of disgrace; a discredit.
December: The twelfth and last month of the year, containing thirty-one days. During this month occurs the winter solstice.
Depicture: To make a picture of; to paint; to picture; to depict.
Diluvialist: One who explains geological phenomena by the Noachian deluge.
Dungeon: To shut up in a dungeon.
Dynastic: Of or relating to a dynasty or line of kings.
Drumbeat: The sound of a beaten drum; drum music.
Deliciousness: The quality of being delicious; as, the deliciousness of a repast.
Dipper: One who, or that which, dips; especially, a vessel used to dip water or other liquid; a ladle.
Discloak: To take off a cloak from; to uncloak.
Draught: To draw out; to call forth. See Draft.
Diduction: The act of drawing apart; separation.
Dipsomaniac: One who has an irrepressible desire for alcoholic drinks.
Drone fly: A dipterous insect (Eristalis tenax), resembling the drone bee. See Eristalis.
Dragonnade: The severe persecution of French Protestants under Louis XIV., by an armed force, usually of dragoons; hence, a rapid and devastating incursion; dragoonade.
Dealfish: A long, thin fish of the arctic seas (Trachypterus arcticus).
Deepen: To become deeper; as, the water deepens at every cast of the lead; the plot deepens.
Disdain: To be filled with scorn; to feel contemptuous anger; to be haughty.
Disguiser: One who, or that which, disguises.
Doorway: The passage of a door; entrance way into a house or a room.
Discoast: To depart; to quit the coast (that is, the side or border) of anything; to be separated.
dolphinfish: either of two large slender food and game fish (Coryphaena equisetis or Coryphaena hippurus) of warm waters.  They are highly esteemed as food fish, especially in Hawaii, where they are usually referred to as mahimahi.  See also dolphin{2}.
Disaster: To blast by the influence of a baleful star.
Diactinic: Capable of transmitting the chemical or actinic rays of light; as, diactinic media.
Disentwine: To free from being entwined or twisted.
dosimeter: a device for measuring doses of radiation, especially ionizing radiation such as X-rays, gamma rays, or ionizing particles.
Druxey: Having decayed spots or streaks of a whitish color; -- said of timber.
Deathly: Deadly; as, deathly pale or sick.
Doura: sorghums of dry regions of Asia and North Africa; A kind of millet. See Durra.
Describable: That can be described; capable of description.
Deistic: Pertaining to, savoring of, or consisting in, deism; as, a deistic writer; a deistical book.
Dissipativity: The rate at which palpable energy is dissipated away into other forms of energy.
dibranch: a cephalopod having two gills; a member of the Dibranchiata.
Diaphemetric: Relating to the measurement of the tactile sensibility of parts; as, diaphemetric compasses.
Dissect: To divide into separate parts; to cut in pieces; to separate and expose the parts of, as an animal or a plant, for examination and to show their structure and relations; to anatomize.
Davyne: A variety of nephelite from Vesuvius.
Donatory: A donee of the crown; one the whom, upon certain condition, escheated property is made over.
Distyle: Having two columns in front; -- said of a temple, portico, or the like.
Disulphuric: Applied to an acid having in each molecule two atoms of sulphur in the higher state of oxidation.
Dishonorable: Wanting in honor; not honorable; bringing or deserving dishonor; staining the character, and lessening the reputation; shameful; disgraceful; base.
Deoxidation: The act or process of reducing from the state of an oxide.
Decoration Day: a day, May 30, originally appointed for decorating with flowers the graves of the Union soldiers and sailors, who fell in the Civil War in the United States; -- now called Memorial Day, and established as the last Monday in May, and designated as a day for commemorating those who died in all wars of the United States.
Dualism: State of being dual or twofold; a twofold division; any system which is founded on a double principle, or a twofold distinction
Dunderhead: A dunce; a numskull; a blockhead.
decimalism: The system of a decimal currency, decimal weights, measures, etc.
Deciliter: A measure of capacity or volume in the metric system; one tenth of a liter, equal to 6.1022 cubic inches, or 3.38 fluid ounces.
drive-in window: a window at a business establishment, such as a bank or restaurant, where patrons may transact business or order goods while staying in their automobiles; as, to cash a check at the drive-in window of the bank.
Drysaltery: The articles kept by a drysalter; also, the business of a drysalter.
Disjunction: The act of disjoining; disunion; separation; a parting; as, the disjunction of soul and body.
Diageotropism: The tendency of organs (as roots) of plants to assume a position oblique or transverse to a direction towards the center of the earth.
Direct nomination: The nomination or designation of candidates for public office by direct popular vote rather than through the action of a convention or body of elected nominating representatives or delegates. The term is applied both to the nomination of candidates without any nominating convention, and, loosely, to the nomination effected, as in the case of candidates for president or senator of the United States, by the election of nominating representatives pledged or instructed to vote for certain candidates dssignated by popular vote.
Dilaniation: A rending or tearing in pieces; dilaceration.
Drawing: The act of pulling, or attracting.
Devilry: Conduct suitable to the devil; extreme wickedness; deviltry.
Depilate: To strip of hair; to husk.
Drumble: To be sluggish or lazy; to be confused.
double standard: a standard or set of principles governing conduct, which is applied more stringently or differently to one group of people than to another; -- used especially of standards of sexual behavior that condemn behavior on the part of women that is condoned or not condemned when exhibited by men.
Disglorify: To deprive of glory; to treat with indignity.
Deletion: Act of deleting, blotting out, or erasing; destruction.
Deific: Making divine; producing a likeness to God; god-making.
Dunker: One of a religious denomination whose tenets and practices are mainly those of the Baptists, but partly those of the Quakers; -- called also Tunkers, Dunkards, Dippers, and, by themselves, Brethren, and German Baptists, and they call their denomination the Church of the Brethren.
deconstruct: To interpret (a text or an artwork) by the method of deconstruction.
Demilancer: A soldier of light cavalry of the 16th century, who carried a demilance.
Dagger: A timber placed diagonally in a ship's frame.
Dagges: An ornamental cutting of the edges of garments, introduced about a. d. 1346, according to the Chronicles of St Albans.
Dyehouse: A building in which dyeing is carried on.
Dearness: The quality or state of being dear; costliness; excess of price.
Davidic: Of or pertaining to David, the king and psalmist of Israel, or to his family.
Denize: To make a denizen; to confer the rights of citizenship upon; to naturalize.
Drummer: One whose office is to best the drum, as in military exercises and marching.
Dinginess: Quality of being dingy; a dusky hue.
Development: The act of developing or disclosing that which is unknown; a gradual unfolding process by which anything is developed, as a plan or method, or an image upon a photographic plate; gradual advancement or growth through a series of progressive changes; also, the result of developing, or a developed state.
Diallyl: A volatile, pungent, liquid hydrocarbon, C6H10, consisting of two allyl radicals.
Dull-eyed: Having eyes wanting brightness, liveliness, or vivacity.
Derivable: That can be derived; obtainable by transmission; capable of being known by inference, as from premises or data; capable of being traced, as from a radical; as, income is derivable from various sources.
deploy: To place (people or other resources) into a position so as to be ready to for action or use.
Difformity: Irregularity of form; diversity of form; want of uniformity.
Domino: A kind of hood worn by the canons of a cathedral church; a sort of amice.
Disconvenient: Not convenient or congruous; unsuitable; ill-adapted.
Dressy: Showy in dress; attentive to dress.
Diseasedness: The state of being diseased; a morbid state; sickness.
Disorb: To throw out of the proper orbit; to unsphere.
Disquiettude: Want of peace or tranquility; uneasiness; disturbance; agitation; anxiety.
deep-mined: taken from an undergrround mine; -- as contrasted with coal obtained from a strip mine; as, deep-mined coal.
Dastardize: To make cowardly; to intimidate; to dispirit; as, to dastardize my courage.
Drummond light: A very intense light, produced by turning two streams of gas, one oxygen and the other hydrogen, or coal gas, in a state of ignition, upon a ball of lime; or a stream of oxygen gas through a flame of alcohol upon a ball or disk of lime; -- called also oxycalcium light, or lime light.
Devastate: To lay waste; to ravage; to desolate.
Dalliance: The act of dallying, trifling, or fondling; interchange of caresses; wanton play.
Dendroc\u0153la: A division of the Turbellaria in which the digestive cavity gives off lateral branches, which are often divided into smaller branchlets.
Delph: The drain on the land side of a sea embankment.
Dissidence: Disagreement; dissent; separation from the established religion.
Desmid: A microscopic plant of the family Desmidiæ, a group of unicellular algæ in which the species have a greenish color, and the cells generally appear as if they consisted of two coalescing halves.
Diaglyphic: Represented or formed by depressions in the general surface; as, diaglyphic sculpture or engraving; -- opposed to anaglyphic.
Deck chair: a folding chair, usually having arms and a full-length leg rest; -- used for relaxing on the deck of a ship, at poolside, etc.  Also called steamer chair
Discoverable: Capable of being discovered, found out, or perceived; as, many minute animals are discoverable only by the help of the microscope; truths discoverable by human industry.
Driving: The act of forcing or urging something along; the act of pressing or moving on furiously.
Demulcent: A substance, usually of a mucilaginous or oily nature, supposed to be capable of soothing an inflamed nervous membrane, or protecting it from irritation. Gum Arabic, glycerin, olive oil, etc., are demulcents.
Denarius: A Roman silver coin of the value of about fourteen cents; the “penny” of the New Testament; -- so called from being worth originally ten of the pieces called as.
Decamp: To break up a camp; to move away from a camping ground, usually by night or secretly.
Digitorium: A small dumb keyboard used by pianists for exercising the fingers; -- called also dumb piano.
Denture: An artificial tooth, block, or set of teeth.
Delightful: Highly pleasing; affording great pleasure and satisfaction.
De jure: By right; of right; by law; -- often opposed to de facto.
Demonstratively: In a manner fitted to demonstrate; clearly; convincingly; forcibly.
Desegmentation: The loss or obliteration of division into segments; as, a desegmentation of the body.
Desirability: The state or quality of being desirable; desirableness.
Dulcify: To sweeten; to free from acidity, saltness, or acrimony.
Dryfoot: The scent of the game, as far as it can be traced.
Deputation: The act of deputing, or of appointing or commissioning a deputy or representative; office of a deputy or delegate; vicegerency.
De facto: Actually; in fact; in reality; as, a king de facto, -- distinguished from a king de jure, or by right.
Dolabriform: Shaped like the head of an ax or hatchet, as some leaves, and also certain organs of some shellfish.
Disgregation: The process of separation, or the condition of being separate, as of the molecules of a body.
Dispurpose: To dissuade; to frustrate; as, to dispurpose plots.
Diamonded: Having figures like a diamond or lozenge.
Discretionally: At discretion; according to one's discretion or judgment.
Dapifer: One who brings meat to the table; hence, in some countries, the official title of the grand master or steward of the king's or a nobleman's household.
Depuratory: Depurating; tending to depurate or cleanse; depurative.
Discus: A quoit; a circular plate of some heavy material intended to be pitched or hurled as a trial of strength and skill.
Derision: The act of deriding, or the state of being derided; mockery; scornful or contemptuous treatment which holds one up to ridicule.
Dehydrogenate: To deprive of, or free from, hydrogen.
Disconsecrate: To deprive of consecration or sacredness.
diagonalize: to transform a matrix to a diagonal matrix.
Detach: To push asunder; to come off or separate from anything; to disengage.
Drawing-room: A room appropriated for the reception of company; a room to which company withdraws from the dining room.
Discide: To divide; to cleave in two.
Divinator: One who practices or pretends to divination; a diviner.
dolostone: a stone or rock entirely composed of the mineral dolomite.
Despot: A master; a lord; especially, an absolute or irresponsible ruler or sovereign.
Disoblige: To do an act which contravenes the will or desires of; to offend by an act of unkindness or incivility; to displease; to refrain from obliging; to be unaccommodating to.
D\u00e6dalous: Having a variously cut or incised margin; -- said of leaves.
Dalles: A rapid, esp. one where the channel is narrowed between rock walls.
doss: to sleep in a convenient place.
Drap d\u00e9t\u00e9: A thin woolen fabric, twilled like merino.
Duality: The quality or condition of being two or twofold; dual character or usage.
Despicably: In a despicable or mean manner; contemptibly; as, despicably stingy.
Dolichotis: a genus of rodents including the maras.
Despicable: Fit or deserving to be despised; contemptible; mean; vile; worthless; as, a despicable man; despicable company; a despicable gift.
Diacaustic: That which burns by refraction, as a double convex lens, or the sun's rays concentrated by such a lens, sometimes used as a cautery.
Degrade: To degenerate; to pass from a higher to a lower type of structure; as, a family of plants or animals degrades through this or that genus or group of genera.
Despite: In spite of; against, or in defiance of; notwithstanding; as, despite his prejudices.
Deprivable: Capable of being, or liable to be, deprived; liable to be deposed.
Disenamor: To free from the captivity of love.
Domesticant: Forming part of the same family.
Dissolubility: The quality of being dissoluble; capacity of being dissoluble; capacity of being dissolved by heat or moisture, and converted into a fluid.
Disentanglement: The act of disentangling or clearing from difficulties.
Depositor: One who makes a deposit, especially of money in a bank; -- the correlative of depository.
Degerminator: A machine for breaking open the kernels of wheat or other grain and removing the germs.
Draper: One who sells cloths; a dealer in cloths; as, a draper and tailor.
Daggle-tail: A slovenly woman; a slattern; a draggle-tail.
Dacrydium: a genus of Australasian evergreen trees or shrubs.
Deviatory: Tending to deviate; devious; as, deviatory motion.
demonstrated: having been proved or verified beyond doubt; proved by demonstration.
disentangle: To free from entanglement; to release from a condition of being intricately and confusedly involved or interlaced; to reduce to orderly arrangement; to straighten out; as, to disentangle a skein of yarn.
Disillusionment: The act of freeing from an illusion, or the state of being freed therefrom.
Diptera: An extensive order of insects having only two functional wings and two balancers, as the house fly, mosquito, etc. They have a suctorial proboscis, often including two pairs of sharp organs (mandibles and maxillæ) with which they pierce the skin of animals. They undergo a complete metamorphosis, their larvæ (called maggots) being usually without feet.
diestrous: in a period of sexual inactivity; -- of animals that have several estrous cycles in one breeding season.
Distringas: A writ commanding the sheriff to distrain a person by his goods or chattels, to compel a compliance with something required of him.
Defecator: That which cleanses or purifies; esp., an apparatus for removing the feculencies of juices and sirups.
Drabble: To fish with a long line and rod; as, to drabble for barbels.
Diaphaneity: The quality of being diaphanous; transparency; pellucidness.
dactylozooid: A kind of zooid of Siphonophora which has an elongated or even vermiform body, with one tentacle, but no mouth. See Siphonophora.
Dendraspis: a genus of African snakes comprising the mambas.
Dulse: A seaweed of a reddish brown color, which is sometimes eaten, as in Scotland. The true dulse is Sarcophyllis edulis; the common is Rhodymenia. [Written also dillisk.]
Daysman: An umpire or arbiter; a mediator.
Duograph: A picture printed from two half-tone plates made with the screen set at different angles, and usually printed in two shades of the same color or in black and one tint.
Dentate-sinuate: Having a form intermediate between dentate and sinuate.
Disdainful: Full of disdain; expressing disdain; scornful; contemptuous; haughty.
Daphne: A genus of diminutive Shrubs, mostly evergreen, and with fragrant blossoms.
Discordance: State or quality of being discordant; disagreement; inconsistency.
Drifty: Full of drifts; tending to form drifts, as snow, and the like.
Decretory: Established by a decree; definitive; settled.
Driller: One who, or that which, drills.
Dogshore: One of several shores used to hold a ship firmly and prevent her moving while the blocks are knocked away before launching.
Dichroite: Iolite; -- so called from its presenting two different colors when viewed in two different directions. See Iolite.
Distinguishingly: With distinction; with some mark of preference.
Distantly: At a distance; remotely; with reserve.
Dumb-waiter: A framework on which dishes, food, etc., are passed from one room or story of a house to another; a lift for dishes, etc.; also, a piece of furniture with movable or revolving shelves.
Dowerless: Destitute of dower; having no marriage portion.
Diatribist: One who makes a diatribe or diatribes.
Divan: A book; esp., a collection of poems written by one author; as, the divan of Hafiz.
Demesne: A lord's chief manor place, with that part of the lands belonging thereto which has not been granted out in tenancy; a house, and the land adjoining, kept for the proprietor's own use.
Dog-rose: A common European wild rose, with single pink or white flowers.
Disqualification: The act of disqualifying, or state of being disqualified; want of qualification; incompetency; disability; as, the disqualification of men for holding certain offices.
Deflect: To turn aside; to deviate from a right or a horizontal line, or from a proper position, course or direction; to swerve.
Delivery: The act of delivering from restraint; rescue; release; liberation; as, the delivery of a captive from his dungeon.
Divorcive: Having power to divorce; tending to divorce.
Decretal: An authoritative order or decree; especially, a letter of the pope, determining some point or question in ecclesiastical law. The decretals form the second part of the canon law.
Domineer: To rule with insolence or arbitrary sway; to play the master; to be overbearing; to tyrannize; to bluster; to swell with conscious superiority or haughtiness; -- often with over; as, to domineer over dependents.
Depreciation: The act of lessening, or seeking to lessen, price, value, or reputation.
Domicillary: Of or pertaining to a domicile, or the residence of a person or family.
Dwale: The deadly nightshade (Atropa Belladonna), having stupefying qualities.
dicephalous: Having two heads on one body; double-headed.
Demy: Pertaining to, or made of, the size of paper called demy; as, a demy book.
Datril: an analgesic derived from acetanolide; also used as an antipyretic; Datril and Tylenol are trademarks of brands of acetaminophen tablets.  See acetaminophen.
Descriptive: Tending to describe; having the quality of representing; containing description; as, a descriptive figure; a descriptive phrase; a descriptive narration; a story descriptive of the age.
disability: State of being disabled; deprivation or want of ability; absence of competent physical, intellectual, or moral power, means, fitness, and the like.
Dartrous: Relating to, or partaking of the nature of, the disease called tetter; herpetic.
Descant: To sing a variation or accomplishment.
Dentiloquist: One who speaks through the teeth, that is, with the teeth closed.
Disaccommodation: A state of being unaccommodated or unsuited.
Dozen: A collection of twelve objects; a tale or set of twelve; with or without of before the substantive which follows.
Distinguishing: Constituting difference, or distinction from everything else; distinctive; peculiar; characteristic.
Diffluent: Flowing apart or off; dissolving; not fixed.
Dicyemid: Like or belonging to the Dicyemata.
Diureticalness: The quality of being diuretical; diuretic property.
Diminish: To become or appear less or smaller; to lessen; as, the apparent size of an object diminishes as we recede from it.
Daydream: A vain fancy speculation; a reverie; a castle in the air; unfounded hope.
Deputable: Fit to be deputed; suitable to act as a deputy.
Decorate: To deck with that which is becoming, ornamental, or honorary; to adorn; to beautify; to embellish; as, to decorate the person; to decorate an edifice; to decorate a lawn with flowers; to decorate the mind with moral beauties; to decorate a hero with honors.
Disthene: Cyanite or kyanite; -- so called in allusion to its unequal hardness in two different directions. See Cyanite.
Dissertator: One who writers a dissertation; one who discourses.
Diapedesis: The passage of the corpuscular elements of the blood from the blood vessels into the surrounding tissues, without rupture of the walls of the blood vessels.
Decigram: A weight in the metric system; one tenth of a gram, equal to 1.5432 grains avoirdupois.
dibutyl: A liquid hydrocarbon, C8H18, of the alkane series, being one of several octanes, and consisting of two butyl radicals.  Cf. Octane.
Discussive: A medicine that discusses or disperses morbid humors; a discutient.
Dripstone: A drip, when made of stone. See Drip, 2.
Despumation: The act of throwing up froth or scum; separation of the scum or impurities from liquids; scumming; clarification.
Debonairness: The quality of being debonair; good humor; gentleness; courtesy.
Dehort: To urge to abstain or refrain; to dissuade.
Dehors: All sorts of outworks in general, at a distance from the main works; any advanced works for protection or cover.
dactylioglyph: An engraver of gems for rings and other ornaments.
dicalcic: Having two atoms or equivalents of calcium to the molecule.
Dentistry: The art or profession of a dentist; dental surgery.
Dehorn: To deprive of horns; to prevent the growth of the horns of (cattle) by burning their ends soon after they start. See Dishorn.
dicotyledon: A plant whose seeds divide into two seed lobes, or cotyledons, in germinating.
Dove plant: A Central American orchid (Peristeria elata), having a flower stem five or six feet high, with numerous globose white fragrant flowers. The column in the center of the flower resembles a dove; -- called also Holy Spirit plant.
Dendranthema: a genus comprising plants often included in the genus Chrysanthemum.
Doob grass: A perennial, creeping grass (Cynodon dactylon), highly prized, in Hindostan, as food for cattle, and acclimated in the United States.
Disciplinable: Capable of being disciplined or improved by instruction and training.
Disinterestedness: The state or quality of being disinterested; impartiality.
Dandruff: A scurf which forms on the head, and comes off in small scales or particles.
D\u00e9collet\u00e9: Leaving the neck and shoulders uncovered; cut low in the neck, or low-necked, as a dress.
Deloul: A special breed of the dromedary used for rapid traveling; the swift camel; -- called also herire, and maharik.
Disbeliever: One who disbelieves, or refuses belief; an unbeliever. Specifically, one who does not believe the Christian religion.
Dinothere: A large extinct proboscidean mammal from the miocene beds of Europe and Asia. It is remarkable for a pair of tusks directed downward from the decurved apex of the lower jaw.
degenerate: a person who has declined from a high standard, especially a sexual deviate; -- usually used disparagingly or opprobriously of persons whose sexual behavior does not conform to the norms of accepted morals.
Decollated: Decapitated; worn or cast off in the process of growth, as the apex of certain univalve shells.
dininghall: a large room at a college or university, used especially for dining.
Dopplerite: A brownish black native hydrocarbon occurring in elastic or jellylike masses.
Dishaunt: To leave; to quit; to cease to haunt.
Dilluing: A process of sorting ore by washing in a hand sieve.
Deer-neck: A deerlike, or thin, ill-formed neck, as of a horse.
Distillatory: Belonging to, or used in, distilling; as, distillatory vessels.
disassemble: to be able to come apart easily; to be converted into constituent parts; as, the rifle disassembles into small pieces for concealment.
Disestablishment: The act or process of unsettling or breaking up that which has been established; specifically, the withdrawal of the support of the state from an established church; as, the disestablishment and disendowment of the Irish Church by Act of Parliament.
discussive: Able or tending to discuss or disperse tumors or coagulated matter; discutient.
Dogmatically: In a dogmatic manner; positively; magisterially.
Dure: To last; to continue; to endure.
Delusion: The act of deluding; deception; a misleading of the mind.
defaced: having the external appearance impaired, usually deliberately.
day-star: The morning star; the star which ushers in the day; -- usually the planet Venus, when seen before and just after sunrise.
dagame: the lemonwood tree (Calycophyllum candidissimum); -- it is a tropical American tree which is source of a tough elastic wood.
Drawling: The act of speaking with a drawl; a drawl.
Diluvium: A deposit of superficial loam, sand, gravel, stones, etc., caused by former action of flowing waters, or the melting of glacial ice.
Dodecandria: A Linnæan class of plants including all that have any number of stamens between twelve and nineteen.
Direct-coupled: Coupled without intermediate connections, as an engine and a dynamo.
doggone: Damn; -- used to express displeasure or annoyance; as, doggone it!.
Diplanar: Of or pertaining to two planes.
Dagan: the Mesopotanian god of agriculture and earth; it is a counterpart of Phoenician and Philistine Dagon.
dockyard: A yard or storage place for all sorts of naval stores and timber for shipbuilding.
Disparates: Things so unequal or unlike that they can not be compared with each other.
Doctrinable: Of the nature of, or constituting, doctrine.
Diffuse: Poured out; widely spread; not restrained; copious; full; esp., of style, opposed to concise or terse; verbose; prolix; as, a diffuse style; a diffuse writer.
Duodenum: The part of the small intestines between the stomach and the jejunum. See Illust. of Digestive apparatus, under Digestive.
demythologize: to remove the mythical elements from; -- of writings, such as the Bible.
Diplex: Pertaining to the sending of two messages in the same direction at the same time. Diplex and contraplex are the two varieties of duplex.
Daint: Something of exquisite taste; a dainty.
Doliolum: A genus of freeswimming oceanic tunicates, allied to Salpa, and having alternate generations.
Derm: The integument of animal; the skin.
Developmental: Pertaining to, or characteristic of, the process of development; as, the developmental power of a germ.
Destiny: That to which any person or thing is destined; predetermined state; condition foreordained by the Divine or by human will; fate; lot; doom.
Destine: To determine the future condition or application of; to set apart by design for a future use or purpose; to fix, as by destiny or by an authoritative decree; to doom; to ordain or preordain; to appoint; -- often with the remoter object preceded by to or for.
Disappendent: Freed from a former connection or dependence; disconnected.
Dispondee: A double spondee; a foot consisting of four long syllables.
defenestrate: to throw (something or someone) out of a window.
Denticete: The division of Cetacea in which the teeth are developed, including the sperm whale, dolphins, etc.
Dissipable: Capable of being scattered or dissipated.
Dodd: To cut off, as wool from sheep's tails; to lop or clip off.
Dicotyledonae: a class of plants comprising those seed plants that produce an embryo with two cotyledons and net-veined leaves; divided into six (not always well distinguished) subclasses (or superorders): Magnoliidae and Hamamelidae (considered primitive); Caryophyllidae (an early and distinctive offshoot); and three more or less advanced groups: Dilleniidae; Rosidae; Asteridae.
Dodo: A large, extinct bird (Didus ineptus), formerly inhabiting the Island of Mauritius. It had short, half-fledged wings, like those of the ostrich, and a short neck and legs; -- called also dronte. It was related to the pigeons.
Dissolvent: That which has the power of dissolving or melting other substances, esp. by mixture with them; a menstruum; a solvent.
Daft: Stupid; foolish; idiotic; also, delirious; insane; as, he has gone daft.
Deobstruent: Removing obstructions; having power to clear or open the natural ducts of the fluids and secretions of the body; aperient.
Disposedness: The state of being disposed or inclined; inclination; propensity.
Disgospel: To be inconsistent with, or act contrary to, the precepts of the gospel; to pervert the gospel.
Demulsion: The act of soothing; that which soothes.
Dive: A plunge headforemost into water, the act of one who dives, literally or figuratively.
Declension: The act or the state of declining; declination; descent; slope.
Discountable: Capable of being, or suitable to be, discounted; as, certain forms are necessary to render notes discountable at a bank.
Dispensary: A place where medicines are prepared and dispensed; esp., a place where the poor can obtain medical advice and medicines gratuitously or at a nominal price.
Disfiguration: The act of disfiguring, or the state of being disfigured; defacement; deformity; disfigurement.
Desert: To abandon a service without leave; to quit military service without permission, before the expiration of one's term; to abscond.
dyskinesia: an abnormality in performing voluntary muscle movements.
Deflorate: Past the flowering state; having shed its pollen.
Dashboard: A board placed on the fore part of a carriage, sleigh, or other vehicle, to intercept water, mud, or snow, thrown up by the heels of the horses; -- in England commonly called splashboard.
Disformity: Discordance or diversity of form; unlikeness in form.
Depose: To bear witness; to testify under oath; to make deposition.
Donatist: A follower of Donatus, the leader of a body of North African schismatics and purists, who greatly disturbed the church in the 4th century. They claimed to be the true church.
deaf-muteness: the condition of being a deaf-mute; a congenital deafness that results in inability to speak.
Deciduate: Possessed of, or characterized by, a decidua.
Deciduata: A group of Mammalia in which a decidua is thrown off with, or after, the fetus, as in the human species.
Doubtance: State of being in doubt; uncertainty; doubt.
Designing: The act of making designs or sketches; the act of forming designs or plans.
Dauber: One who, or that which, daubs; especially, a coarse, unskillful painter.
Delta connection: One of the usual forms or methods for connecting apparatus to a three-phase circuit, the three corners of the delta or triangle, as diagrammatically represented, being connected to the three wires of the supply circuit.
Dextronic: Pertaining to, or derived from, dextrose; as, dextronic acid.
Dismantle: To strip or deprive of dress; to divest.
Dossier: A bundle containing the papers in reference to some matter.
Devon: One of a breed of hardy cattle originating in the country of Devon, England. Those of pure blood have a deep red color. The small, longhorned variety, called North Devons, is distinguished by the superiority of its working oxen.
Demolish: To throw or pull down; to raze; to destroy the fabric of; to pull to pieces; to ruin; as, to demolish an edifice, or a wall.
Desquamate: To peel off in the form of scales; to scale off, as the skin in certain diseases.
doh: the syllable naming the first (tonic) note of any major diatonic scale in solmization, usually written do.
Decipium: A supposed rare element, said to be associated with cerium, yttrium, etc., in the mineral samarskite, and more recently called samarium. Symbol Dp. See Samarium.
Decerptible: That may be plucked off, cropped, or torn away.
Dressmaking: The art, process, or occupation, of making dresses.
Demibastion: A half bastion, or that part of a bastion consisting of one face and one flank.
Downsitting: The act of sitting down; repose; a resting.
dollar bill: A paper note printed by the Treasury, or by one of the Federal Reserve Banks under authority of the treasury, having the value of one dollar.  Also five dollar bill, ten dollar bill, etc.:  notes with the value of five, ten, etc. dollars.  Prior to 1964 such notes could be redeemed for the equivalent dollar value in silver coins, but in that year the backing of the currency with silver was discontinued.  Such notes not convertible into precious metals at a fixed rate are called "fiat money", receiving their value solely from the good faith of the issuing government and the confidence of those using the currency.
demodulator: An electronic device which extracts the modulation from a radio carrier wave, and outputs the original information-bearing signal.
Discourageable: Capable of being discouraged; easily disheartened.
Dolerite: A dark, crystalline, igneous rock, chiefly pyroxene with labradorite.
Decalcify: To deprive of calcareous matter; thus, to decalcify bones is to remove the stony part, and leave only the gelatin.
dampening: the act or process of making something slightly wet.
Detention: The act of detaining or keeping back; a withholding.
Deposition: The act of depositing or deposing; the act of laying down or thrown down; precipitation.
Decarburize: To deprive of carbon; to remove the carbon from.
Doughbird: The Eskimo curlew (Numenius borealis). See Curlew.
Dunnage: Fagots, boughs, or loose materials of any kind, laid on the bottom of the hold for the cargo to rest upon to prevent injury by water, or stowed among casks and other cargo to prevent their motion.
Dyscrasia: An ill habit or state of the constitution; -- formerly regarded as dependent on a morbid condition of the blood and humors.
Dacrymyces: the type genus of the Dacrymycetaceae, consisting of fungi with a bifurcate basidium that lacks septa.
Deep-sea: Of or pertaining to the deeper parts of the sea; as, a deep-sea line (i. e., a line to take soundings at a great depth); deep-sea lead; deep-sea soundings, explorations, etc.
Distributively: By distribution; singly; not collectively; in a distributive manner.
D valve: A kind of slide valve. See Slide valve, under Slide.
Dilapidation: The act of dilapidating, or the state of being dilapidated, reduced to decay, partially ruined, or squandered.
Dispatch: The act of sending a message or messenger in haste or on important business.
Dogger: A sort of stone, found in the mines with the true alum rock, chiefly of silica and iron.
Dag-tailed: Daggle-tailed; having the tail clogged with daglocks.
District: To divide into districts or limited portions of territory; as, legislatures district States for the choice of representatives.
Dinichthys: A genus of large extinct Devonian ganoid fishes. In some parts of Ohio remains of the Dinichthys are abundant, indicating animals twenty feet in length.
Dialect: Means or mode of expressing thoughts; language; tongue; form of speech.
Discalceated: Deprived off shoes or sandals; unshod; discalced.
Dibasic: Having two acid hydrogen atoms capable of replacement by basic atoms or radicals, in forming salts; bibasic; -- said of acids, as oxalic or sulphuric acids.  Cf. Diacid, Bibasic.
Determinability: The quality of being determinable; determinableness.
Desitive: A proposition relating to or expressing an end or conclusion.
Devisor: One who devises, or gives real estate by will; a testator; -- correlative to devisee.
Darbyite: One of the Plymouth Brethren, or of a sect among them; -- so called from John N. Darby, one of the leaders of the Brethren.
Discolith: One of a species of coccoliths, having an oval discoidal body, with a thick strongly refracting rim, and a thinner central portion. One of them measures about 1/50000 of an inch in its longest diameter.
Disloign: To put at a distance; to remove.
Doter: One who dotes; a man whose understanding is enfeebled by age; a dotard.
Dactyliology: That branch of archæology which has to do with gem engraving.
Diazo-: A combining form  (also used adjectively), meaning pertaining to, or derived from, a series of compounds containing a radical of two nitrogen atoms, united usually to an aromatic radical; as, diazo-benzene, C6H5.N2.OH.
Devoted: Consecrated to a purpose; strongly attached; zealous; devout; as, a devoted admirer.
Derisive: Expressing, serving for, or characterized by, derision.
Daring: Bold; fearless; adventurous; as, daring spirits.
Distich: Disposed in two vertical rows; two-ranked.
Dextro-: A prefix, from L. dexter, meaning, pertaining to, or toward, the right
Defalcation: A lopping off; a diminution; abatement; deficit. Specifically: Reduction of a claim by deducting a counterclaim; set- off.
Demandant: One who demands; the plaintiff in a real action; any plaintiff.
Dolus: Evil intent, embracing both malice and fraud. See Culpa.
Dicyemata: An order of worms parasitic in cephalopods. They are remarkable for the extreme simplicity of their structure. The embryo exists in two forms.
Damnification: That which causes damage or loss.
detoxification: a medically supervised treatment for addiction to drugs or alcohol intended to rid the body of the addictive substances.
Definition: The act of defining; determination of the limits; as, a telescope accurate in definition.
Disacknowledge: To refuse to acknowledge; to deny; to disown.
Disembowel: To take or let out the bowels or interior parts of; to eviscerate.
Diphycercal: Having the tail fin divided into two equal parts by the notochord, or end of the vertebral column; protocercal. See Protocercal.
Disciplinarian: One who disciplines; one who excels in training, especially with training, especially with regard to order and obedience; one who enforces rigid discipline; a stickler for the observance of rules and methods of training; as, he is a better disciplinarian than scholar.
demonetization: The act of demonetizing, or the condition of being demonetized;
Droit: A right; law in its aspect of the foundation of rights; also, in old law, the writ of right.
Dowle: Feathery or wool-like down; filament of a feather.
Declass: To remove from a class; to separate or degrade from one's class.
Drill press: A machine for drilling holes in metal, the drill being pressed to the metal by the action of a screw.
Descensory: A vessel used in alchemy to extract oils.
Desecration: The act of desecrating; profanation; condition of anything desecrated.
Dairymaid: A female servant whose business is the care of the dairy.
Dogvane: A small vane of bunting, feathers, or any other light material, carried at the masthead to indicate the direction of the wind.
Dixieland: the 11 southern states that seceded from the U. S. in 1861.
Dodecahedral: Pertaining to, or like, a dodecahedion; consisting of twelve equal sides.
Determiner: One who, or that which, determines or decides.
Deprivation: The act of depriving, dispossessing, or bereaving; the act of deposing or divesting of some dignity.
Dumfound: To strike dumb; to confuse with astonishment.
Drachma: A silver coin among the ancient Greeks, having a different value in different States and at different periods. The average value of the Attic drachma is computed to have been about 19 cents (U. S. currency, ca. 1913).
Duration: The state or quality of lasting; continuance in time; the portion of time during which anything exists.
Dormancy: The state of being dormant; quiescence; abeyance.
Disloyalty: Want of loyalty; lack of fidelity; violation of allegiance.
Defamation: Act of injuring another's reputation by any slanderous communication, written or oral; the wrong of maliciously injuring the good name of another; slander; detraction; calumny; aspersion.
Dreader: One who fears, or lives in fear.
Denitrification: The act or process of freeing from nitrogen; also, the condition resulting from the removal of nitrogen.
Dipterygian: Having two dorsal fins; -- said of certain fishes.
Delacrymation: An involuntary discharge of watery humors from the eyes; wateriness of the eyes.
Declamatory: Pertaining to declamation; treated in the manner of a rhetorician; as, a declamatory theme.
Dentiform: Having the form of a tooth or of teeth; tooth-shaped.
Disencharm: To free from the influence of a charm or spell; to disenchant.
dreamy: Abounding in dreams or given to dreaming; appropriate to, or like, dreams; visionary.
Disappointment: The act of disappointing, or the state of being disappointed; defeat or failure of expectation or hope; miscarriage of design or plan; frustration.
Domett: A kind of baize of which the ward is cotton and the weft woolen.
Debituminization: The act of depriving of bitumen.
Didactyl: An animal having only two digits.
Dupe: To deceive; to trick; to mislead by imposing on one's credulity; to gull; as, dupe one by flattery.
Dermatophyte: A fungus infecting and parasitic on the skin, especially one which causes disease; as, ringworm is caused by a  dermatophyte.
Denseness: The quality of being dense; density.
Dumpling: A roundish mass of dough boiled in soup, or as a sort of pudding; often, a cover of paste inclosing an apple or other fruit, and boiled or baked; as, an apple dumpling.
Decembrist: One of those who conspired for constitutional government against the Emperor Nicholas on his accession to the throne at the death of Alexander I., in December, 1825; -- called also Dekabrist.
Dismalness: The quality of being dismal; gloominess.
Demurity: Demureness; also, one who is demure.
Digitigrade: An animal that walks on its toes, as the cat, lion, wolf, etc.; -- distinguished from a plantigrade, which walks on the palm of the foot.
Digraphic: Of or pertaining to a digraph.
daytime: The time during which there is daylight, as distinguished from the night; same as day, 1; as, during the daytime.
Dabber: That with which one dabs; hence, a pad or other device used by printers, engravers, etc., as for dabbing type or engraved plates with ink.
Drinking: The act of one who drinks; the act of imbibing.
Doctrinarianism: The principles or practices of the Doctrinaires.
Damaliscus: a genus of African antelopes including the sassaby, Damaliscus lunatus.
Daily: Every day; day by day; as, a thing happens daily.
Decoy-duck: A duck used to lure wild ducks into a decoy; hence, a person employed to lure others into danger.
Dyingly: In a dying manner; as if at the point of death.
Dynamometer: An apparatus for measuring force or power; especially, muscular effort of men or animals, or the power developed by a motor, or that required to operate machinery.
Disquisition: A formal or systematic inquiry into, or discussion of, any subject; a full examination or investigation of a matter, with the arguments and facts bearing upon it; elaborate essay; dissertation.
Deity: The collection of attributes which make up the nature of a god; divinity; godhead; as, the deity of the Supreme Being is seen in his works.
dim-witted: mentally retarded; relatively slow in mental function.
Dow-Jones Industrial Average: an index of certain stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange, computed by the Dow Jones publishing company as a weighted average of the prices of the common stocks of 30 specific companies classified as "industrial".   The Dow Jones Industrial Average is often taken as an indicator of the movement of American stock prices generally, though other indices are maintained, averaging the prices of other stocks,  and these often change in opposite directions from those of the DJIA.
Draff: Refuse; lees; dregs; the wash given to swine or cows; hogwash; waste matter.
Drawhead: The flanged outer end of a drawbar; also, a name applied to the drawgear.
Duodecimal: A twelfth part; as, the duodecimals of an inch.
Douroucouli: A small, nocturnal, South American monkey of the genus Aotus (formerly Nyctipithecus trivirgatus), with large owl-like eyes; hence, the common name owl monkey.
Didactics: The art or science of teaching.
deputize: To appoint as one's deputy; to empower to act in one's stead; to appoint as one's substitute; to depute.
Dorsad: Toward the dorsum or back; on the dorsal side; dorsally.
Dribble: A drizzling shower; a falling or leaking in drops.
Dorsal: A hanging, usually of rich stuff, at the back of a throne, or of an altar, or in any similar position.
Dado: That part of a pedestal included between the base and the cornice (or surbase); the die. See Illust. of Column.
DNA: abbreviation for deoxyribonucleic acid; -- more commonly used than the full name.  See also RNA.
Dade: To walk unsteadily, as a child in leading strings, or just learning to walk; to move slowly.
Doff: To put off dress; to take off the hat.
Distorter: One who, or that which, distorts.
Disserve: To fail to serve; to do injury or mischief to; to damage; to hurt; to harm.
Disintegrate: To decompose into integrant parts; as, chalk rapidly disintegrates.
Description: The act of describing; a delineation by marks or signs.
digital: Of or pertaining to the fingers; done with the fingers; as, digital compression; digital examination.
Disreputable: Not reputable; of bad repute; not in esteem; dishonorable; disgracing the reputation; tending to bring into disesteem; as, it is disreputable to associate familiarly with the mean, the lewd, and the profane.
Disme: A tenth; a tenth part; a tithe.
Defibrinate: To deprive of fibrin, as fresh blood or lymph by stirring with twigs.
Donn\u00e9e: Lit., given; hence, in a literary work, as a drama or tale, that which is assumed as to characters, situation, etc., as a basis for the plot or story.
Demonologist: One who writes on, or is versed in, demonology.
Dendrite: A stone or mineral on or in which are branching figures resembling shrubs or trees, produced by a foreign mineral, usually an oxide of manganese, as in the moss agate; also, a crystallized mineral having an arborescent form, e. g., gold or silver; an arborization.
decelerate: to cause to reduce speed.  Opposite of accelerate.
Dittied: Set, sung, or composed as a ditty; -- usually in composition.
Discerpibility: Capability or liableness to be discerped.
Driftweed: Seaweed drifted to the shore by the wind.
Discoblastic: Applied to a form of egg cleavage seen in osseous fishes, which occurs only in a small disk that separates from the rest of the egg.
Disclaim: To disavow or renounce all part, claim, or share.
Draughts: A game, now more commonly called checkers. See Checkers.
Disuniter: One who, or that which, disjoins or causes disunion.
Debeige: A kind of woolen or mixed dress goods.
Diethylamine: A colorless, volatile, alkaline liquid, NH(C2H5)2, having a strong fishy odor resembling that of herring or sardines.  Cf. Methylamine.
Drillstock: A contrivance for holding and turning a drill.
Deodorization: The act of depriving of odor, especially of offensive odors resulting from impurities.
dig: To understand; as, do you dig me?.
Disendow: To deprive of an endowment, as a church.
dis: to treat in a disrespectful manner; to insult, disparage or belittle.
Dobells solution: An aqueous solution of carbolic acid, borax, sodium bicarbonate, and glycerin, used as a spray in diseases of the nose and throat.
Disseizor: One who wrongfully disseizes, or puts another out of possession of a freehold.
Dispauper: To deprive of the claim of a pauper to public support; to deprive of the privilege of suing in forma pauperis.
Deergrass: An American genus (Rhexia) of perennial herbs, with opposite leaves, and showy flowers (usually bright purple), with four petals and eight stamens, -- the only genus of the order Melastomaceæ inhabiting a temperate clime.
Decidedly: In a decided manner; indisputably; clearly; thoroughly.
Dissilient: Starting asunder; bursting and opening with an elastic force; dehiscing explosively; as, a dissilient pericarp.
Devitalize: To deprive of life or vitality.
Disadvance: To draw back, or cause to draw back.
Daylight: The light of day as opposed to the darkness of night; the light of the sun, as opposed to that of the moon or to artificial light.
Deadworks: The parts of a ship above the water when she is laden.
Donate: To give; to bestow; to present; as, to donate fifty thousand dollars to a college.
Demonology: A treatise on demons; a supposititious science which treats of demons and their manifestations.
Dellacruscan: Of or pertaining to the Accademia della Crusca in Florence.
Disrespectful: Wanting in respect; manifesting disesteem or lack of respect; uncivil; as, disrespectful behavior.
Digressional: Pertaining to, or having the character of, a digression; departing from the main purpose or subject.
Dumpage: The act of dumping loads from carts, especially loads of refuse matter; also, a heap of dumped matter.
Despicableness: The quality of being despicable; meanness; vileness; worthlessness.
Diffused: Spread abroad; dispersed; loose; flowing; diffuse.
Disproportionally: In a disproportional manner; unsuitably in form, quantity, or value; unequally.
Dependence: The act or state of depending; state of being dependent; a hanging down or from; suspension from a support.
Dependency: State of being dependent; dependence; state of being subordinate; subordination; concatenation; connection; reliance; trust.
diversionary: likely or designed to confuse or deceive; -- of tactics.
Diffuser: One who, or that which, diffuses.
Discubitory: Leaning; fitted for a reclining posture.
