Dewclaw: In any animal, esp. of the Herbivora, a rudimentary claw or small hoof not reaching the ground.
dollarfish: small food fish (Poronotus triacanthus) of the Atlantic coast.
Dives: The name popularly given to the rich man in our Lord's parable of the “Rich Man and Lazarus” (Luke xvi. 19-31). Hence, a name for a rich worldling.
Diver: One who, or that which, dives.
Diffusiveness: The quality or state of being diffusive or diffuse; extensiveness; expansion; dispersion. Especially of style: Diffuseness; want of conciseness; prolixity.
drawee: The person on whom an order or bill of exchange is drawn; -- the correlative of drawer.
Deserve: To earn by service; to be worthy of (something due, either good or evil); to merit; to be entitled to; as, the laborer deserves his wages; a work of value deserves praise.
drawer: One who, or that which, draws
Drom\u00e6ognathous: Having the structure of the palate like that of the ostrich and emu.
Decentralize: to make less central; to prevent from centralizing; to cause to withdraw from the center or place of concentration; to divide and distribute (what has been united or concentrated); -- esp. said of authority, or the administration of public affairs.
Diisatogen: A red crystalline nitrogenous substance of artificial production, which by reduction passes directly to indigo.
Denounce: To make known in a solemn or official manner; to declare; to proclaim (especially an evil).
Dimera: A division of Coleoptera, having two joints to the tarsi.
Dimidiation: The act of dimidiating or halving; the state of being dimidiate.
Dasyurus: the type genus of the family Dasyuridae: native cats.
Deceptive: Tending to deceive; having power to mislead, or impress with false opinions; as, a deceptive countenance or appearance.
Docility: teachableness; aptness for being taught; docibleness.
degarnish: To strip or deprive of entirely, as of furniture, ornaments, etc.; to disgarnish; as, to degarnish a house, etc.
Doyen: Lit., a dean; the senior member of a body or group; as, the doyen of French physicians.
Demonial: Of or pertaining to a demon.
Demonian: Relating to, or having the nature of, a demon.
Diffusibility: The quality of being diffusible; capability of being poured or spread out.
Downtrod: Trodden down; trampled down; abused by superior power.
Demoniac: A human being possessed by a demon or evil spirit; one whose faculties are directly controlled by a demon.
Defiance: The act of defying, putting in opposition, or provoking to combat; a challenge; a provocation; a summons to combat.
Deutoplasm: The lifeless food matter in the cytoplasm of an ovum or a cell, as distinguished from the active or true protoplasm; yolk substance; yolk.
discoloured: same as discolored; as, discoloured paneling.
Displant: To remove (what is planted or fixed); to unsettle and take away; to displace; to root out; as, to displant inhabitants.
disrate: To reduce to a lower rating or rank; to degrade.
Diphthongic: Of the nature of diphthong; diphthongal.
Delta current: The current flowing through a delta connection.
Day-labor: Labor hired or performed by the day.
Destinist: A believer in destiny; a fatalist.
Dandle: To move up and down on one's knee or in one's arms, in affectionate play, as an infant.
Dry-shod: Without wetting the feet; having or keeping the feet or shoes dry; as, a land bridge over which man and beasts could have crossed dry-shod.
Day-coal: The upper stratum of coal, as nearest the light or surface.
Doomful: Full of condemnation or destructive power.
duck-billed: having a beak resembling that of a duck.
Devils darning-needle: A dragon fly. See Darning needle, under Darn, v. t.
drizzling: raining lightly in a fine mist.
Dutchmans breeches: a delicate perennial spring-flowering herb (Dicentra cucullaria) of eastern U.S., having  peculiar double-spurred white flowers.  See Illust. of Dicentra
Dispender: One who dispends or expends; a steward.
Decortication: The act of stripping off the bark, rind, hull, or outer coat.
Detail: To relate in particulars; to particularize; to report minutely and distinctly; to enumerate; to specify; as, he detailed all the facts in due order.
djinnee: A spirit believed by Muslims to inhabit the earth and influence mankind by appearing in the form of humans or animals.  Same as djinni and Jinnee.  See Jinnee, Jinn.
Dibranchia: comprising all living cephalopods except the family Nautilidae: the orders Octopoda (octopuses) and Decapoda (squids and cuttlefish).
Demilune: A work constructed beyond the main ditch of a fortress, and in front of the curtain between two bastions, intended to defend the curtain; a ravelin. See Ravelin.
Dirty: To foul; to make filthy; to soil; as, to dirty the clothes or hands.
Diclinic: Having two of the intersections between the three axes oblique. See Crystallization.
Dittany: A plant of the Mint family (Origanum Dictamnus), a native of Crete.
Disproof: A proving to be false or erroneous; confutation; refutation; as, to offer evidence in disproof of a statement.
Double-hung: Having both sashes hung with weights and cords; -- said of a window.
Destemper: A kind of painting. See Distemper.
Duckweed: A genus (Lemna) of small plants, seen floating in great quantity on the surface of stagnant pools fresh water, and supposed to furnish food for ducks; -- called also duckmeat.
Domeykite: A massive mineral of tin-white or steel-gray color, an arsenide of copper.
Deluder: One who deludes; a deceiver; an impostor.
Divinely: In a divine or godlike manner; holily; admirably or excellently in a supreme degree.
Deadlatch: A kind of latch whose bolt may be so locked by a detent that it can not be opened from the inside by the handle, or from the outside by the latch key.
Dahoon: An evergreen shrub or small tree (Ilex cassine) of the southern United States, bearing red drupes and having soft, white, close-grained wood; -- called also dahoon holly.
Dy: the chemical symbol for dysprosium, a rare earth element of atomic number 66.
Decrepitation: The act of decrepitating; a crackling noise, such as salt makes when roasting.
Delineate: To indicate by lines drawn in the form or figure of; to represent by sketch, design, or diagram; to sketch out; to portray; to picture; in drawing and engraving, to represent in lines, as with the pen, pencil, or graver; hence, to represent with accuracy and minuteness. See Delineation.
Duncedom: The realm or domain of dunces.
Dissatisfactory: Causing dissatisfaction; unable to give content; unsatisfactory; displeasing.
Diplopia: The act or state of seeing double.
Dabb: A large, spine-tailed lizard (Uromastix spinipes), found in Egypt, Arabia, and Palestine; -- called also dhobb, and dhubb.
Doxy: A loose wench; a disreputable sweetheart.
Domina: Lady; a lady; -- a title formerly given to noble ladies who held a barony in their own right.
Decussatively: Crosswise; in the form of an X.
Dishwater: Water in which dishes have been washed.
Dentate: Toothed; especially, with the teeth projecting straight out, not pointed either forward or backward; as, a dentate leaf.
Denial: The act of gainsaying, refusing, or disowning; negation; -- the contrary of affirmation.
Discoid: Anything having the form of a discus or disk; particularly, a discoid shell.
dice: To cut into small cubes; as, to slice and dice carrots.
Diary: lasting for one day; as, a diary fever.
disconcerting: hard to deal with; causing uncertainty or confusion about how to act or react.
Devastator: One who, or that which, devastates.
Dusky: Partially dark or obscure; not luminous; dusk; as, a dusky valley.
Dismission: The act dismissing or sending away; permission to leave; leave to depart; dismissal; as, the dismission of the grand jury.
Dicoccous: Composed of two coherent, one-seeded carpels; as, a dicoccous capsule.
Diaphragm: A dividing membrane or thin partition, commonly with an opening through it.
declared: made known or openly avowed; as, their declared and their covert objectives; a declared liberal.  Opposite of undeclared.
Divisionor: One who divides or makes division.
Distemper: An undue or unnatural temper, or disproportionate mixture of parts.
Declinator: An instrument for taking the declination or angle which a plane makes with the horizontal plane.
Diaphanoscope: A dark box constructed for viewing transparent pictures, with or without a lens.
Damianist: A follower of Damian, patriarch of Alexandria in the 6th century, who held heretical opinions on the doctrine of the Holy Trinity.
Dog fancier: One who has an unusual fancy for, or interest in, dogs; also, one who deals in dogs.
Disarrange: To unsettle or disturb the order or due arrangement of; to throw out of order.
Disadvantage: To injure the interest of; to be detrimental to.
Discomposure: The state of being discomposed; disturbance; disorder; agitation; perturbation.
D\u00e9colletage: The upper border or part of a low-cut (i.e., décolleté) dress.
Deepness: The state or quality of being deep, profound, mysterious, secretive, etc.; depth; profundity; -- opposed to shallowness.
dated: marked by features of the immediate and usually discounted past.
Dominus: Master; sir; -- a title of respect formerly applied to a knight or a clergyman, and sometimes to the lord of a manor.
Dislike: To regard with dislike or aversion; to disapprove; to disrelish.
Discutient: Serving to disperse morbid matter; discussive; as, a discutient application.
Dichroscope: An instrument for examining the dichroism of crystals.
Dangle: To cause to dangle; to swing, as something suspended loosely; as, to dangle the feet.
Disrober: One who, or that which, disrobes.
dropkicker: a football kicker who drops the ball and kicks it just as it reaches the ground.
Disyoke: To unyoke; to free from a yoke; to disjoin.
disconnected: marked by or composed of disconnected parts or sounds.
Diphthongal: Relating or belonging to a diphthong; having the nature of a diphthong.
Diversification: The act of making various, or of changing form or quality.
Detection: The act of detecting; the laying open what was concealed or hidden; discovery; as, the detection of a thief; the detection of fraud, forgery, or a plot.
dictostylium: any slime mold of the genus Dictostylium.
Disappearing: p. pr. & vb. n. of Disappear.
Dietetics: That part of the medical or hygienic art which relates to diet or food; rules for diet.
Diota: A vase or drinking cup having two handles or ears.
Divisibility: The quality of being divisible; the property of bodies by which their parts are capable of separation.
Demonocracy: The power or government of demons.
Daker: A measure of certain commodities by number, usually ten or twelve, but sometimes twenty; as, a daker of hides consisted of ten skins; a daker of gloves of ten pairs.
Drone bee: The male of the honeybee; a drone.
Ditto: As before, or aforesaid; in the same manner; also.
doctor: A teacher; one skilled in a profession, or branch of knowledge; a learned man.
Disappointed: Defeated of expectation or hope; balked; as, a disappointed person or hope.
Dielectric: Any substance or medium that transmits the electric force by a process different from conduction, as in the phenomena of induction; a nonconductor, separating a body electrified by induction, from the electrifying body.
Destruction: The act of destroying; a tearing down; a bringing to naught; subversion; demolition; ruin; slaying; devastation.
Denary: The number ten; a division into ten.
Disopinion: Want or difference of belief; disbelief.
Decuple: To make tenfold; to multiply by ten.
Dotal: Pertaining to dower, or a woman's marriage portion; constituting dower, or comprised in it.
decompress: to subject to the process of decompression.
Divestiture: The act of stripping, or depriving; the state of being divested; the deprivation, or surrender, of possession of property, rights, etc.
Decorticator: A machine for decorticating wood, hulling grain, etc.; also, an instrument for removing surplus bark or moss from fruit trees.
Dilution: The act of diluting, or the state of being diluted.
Dictyogen: A plant with net-veined leaves, and monocotyledonous embryos, belonging to the class Dictyogenæ, proposed by Lindley for the orders Dioscoreaceæ, Smilaceæ, Trilliaceæ, etc.
D-day: the day designated for the beginning of a planned attack by a military force; in communications the day is often otherwise unspecified for security reasons; as, the day before D-day the troops will move into position.
Defile: To make foul or impure; to make filthy; to dirty; to befoul; to pollute.
Dulciana: A sweet-toned stop of an organ.
Devilfish: A huge ray (Manta birostris or Cephaloptera vampyrus) of the Gulf of Mexico and Southern Atlantic coasts. Several other related species take the same name. See Cephaloptera.
Dominion Day: In Canada, a legal holiday, July lst, being the anniversary of the proclamation of the formation of the Dominion in 1867.
Dolman: A long robe or outer garment, with long sleeves, worn by the Turks.
Droseraceae: a natural family of carnivorous herbs and shrubs.
Discomplexion: To change the complexion or hue of.
Deuteronomy: The fifth book of the Pentateuch, containing the second giving of the law by Moses.
Decursion: A flowing; also, a hostile incursion.
Dualin: An explosive substance consisting essentially of sawdust or wood pulp, saturated with nitroglycerin and other similar nitro compounds. It is inferior to dynamite, and is more liable to explosion.
Doorstead: Entrance or place of a door.
declutch: to disengage the clutch of a car.
dipped: having an abnormal sagging of the spine, especially in horses.
Duchy: The territory or dominions of a duke; a dukedom.
Dyspnoic: Affected with shortness of breath; relating to dyspnœa.
Dissemble: To conceal the real fact, motives, intention, or sentiments, under some pretense; to assume a false appearance; to act the hypocrite.
Dies Ir\u00e6: Day of wrath; -- the name and beginning of a famous mediæval Latin hymn on the Last Judgment.
decentralization: The action of decentralizing, or the state of being decentralized.
Desman: An amphibious, insectivorous mammal found in Russia (Myogale moschata). It is allied to the moles, but is called muskrat by some English writers.
Disassimilative: Having power to disassimilate; of the nature of disassimilation.
Deranged: Disordered; especially, disordered in mind; crazy; insane.
Despiteful: Full of despite; expressing malice or contemptuous hate; malicious.
desensitizing: making less susceptible or sensitive to either physical or emotional stimuli.  Opposite of sensitizing.
demography: The study of vital statistics, such as births, deaths, marriages, mortality, health, etc., in populations and subgroups of populations.
Defluxion: A discharge or flowing of humors or fluid matter, as from the nose in catarrh; -- sometimes used synonymously with inflammation.
Desolater: One who, or that which, desolates or lays waste.
Dress: That which is used as the covering or ornament of the body; clothes; garments; habit; apparel.
Dove-eyed: Having eyes like a dove; meekeyed; as, dove-eyed Peace.
Digest: That which is digested; especially, that which is worked over, classified, and arranged under proper heads or titles
Democracy: Government by the people; a form of government in which the supreme power is retained and directly exercised by the people.
doll: a small, usually flexible figure representing a human being, especially a toy baby for a little girl; a child's puppet.
Degerm: To extract the germs from, as from wheat grains.
Discretional: Left to discretion; unrestrained except by discretion or judgment; as, an ambassador with discretionary powers.
abbreviation for doctor, a title accorded to a person who holds a doctorate degree from an academic institution, such as a Ph.D. degree or M.D. degree.
Disobliging: Not obliging; not disposed to do a favor; unaccommodating; as, a disobliging person or act.
Discumbency: The act of reclining at table according to the manner of the ancients at their meals.
DBMS: a database management system, a software system that facilitates the creation and maintenance and use of an electronic database.
Disinter: To take out of the grave or tomb; to unbury; to exhume; to dig up.
Detonize: To explode, or cause to explode; to burn with an explosion; to detonate.
decentralise: same as decentralize.  Opposite of centralize and concentrate
Dactylonomy: The art of numbering or counting by the fingers.
Dactylopterous: Having the inferior rays of the pectoral fins partially or entirely free, as in the gurnards.
Dry: To grow dry; to become free from wetness, moisture, or juice; as, the road dries rapidly.
Disinclination: The state of being disinclined; want of propensity, desire, or affection; slight aversion or dislike; indisposition.
Detached: Separate; unconnected, or imperfectly connected; as, detached parcels.
Double-ripper: A kind of coasting sled, made of two sleds fastened together with a board, one before the other.
Dishabille: An undress; a loose, negligent dress; deshabille.
Drusy: Covered with a large number of minute crystals.
Disobey: To refuse or neglect to obey; to violate commands; to be disobedient.
Druse: One of a people and religious sect dwelling chiefly in the Lebanon mountains of Syria.
Disaffirmation: The act of disaffirming; negation; refutation.
detente: the easing of tensions or strained relations (especially between nations), as by agreement, negotiation, or tacit understandings.
Dissertation: A formal or elaborate argumentative discourse, oral or written; a disquisition; an essay; a discussion; as, Dissertations on the Prophecies.
Depredate: To take plunder or prey; to commit waste; as, the troops depredated on the country.
Dregginess: Fullness of dregs or lees; foulness; feculence.
Detractory: Defamatory by denial of desert; derogatory; calumnious.
Distoma: A genus of parasitic, trematode worms, having two suckers for attaching themselves to the part they infest. See 1st Fluke, 2.
Divi-divi: A small tree of tropical America (Cæsalpinia coriaria), whose legumes contain a large proportion of tannic and gallic acid, and are used by tanners and dyers.
downer: a drug that reduces excitability and calms a person.
Delundung: An East Indian carnivorous mammal (Prionodon gracilis), resembling the civets, but without scent pouches. It is handsomely spotted.
Dissenterism: The spirit or principles of dissenters.
defoliate: to cause (a plant) to shed its leaves.
Desulphuration: The act or process of depriving of sulphur.
Diplo\u00eb: The soft, spongy, or cancellated substance between the plates of the skull.
Deaf-mute: A person who is deaf and dumb; one who, through deprivation or defect of hearing, has either failed the acquire the power of speech, or has lost it.
Digestedly: In a digested or well-arranged manner; methodically.
Dodecandrian: Of or pertaining to the Dodecandria; having twelve stamens, or from twelve to nineteen.
Direption: The act of plundering, despoiling, or snatching away.
Dermopterygii: A group of fishlike animals including the Marsipobranchiata and Leptocardia.
Discourteous: Uncivil; rude; wanting in courtesy or good manners; uncourteous.
Deaconhood: The state of being a deacon; office of a deacon; deaconship.
deadlock: A lock which is not self-latching, but requires a key to throw the bolt forward.
Disbranch: To divest of a branch or branches; to tear off.
Dowcet: One of the testicles of a hart or stag.
Diadelphian: Of or pertaining to the class Diadelphia; having the stamens united into two bodies by their filaments (said of a plant or flower); grouped into two bundles or sets by coalescence of the filaments (said of stamens).
delimitate: to determine the essential quality of.
dispiriting: causing dejection; discouraging.  Opposite of encouraging.
Duralumin: an aluminum-based alloy which is both light and strong, containing 4 per cent of copper and 0.5 per cent of magnesium and smaller amounts of iron, manganese, and silicon.  It hardens with aging at room temperature.
doctrinal: Pertaining to, or containing, doctrine or something taught and to be believed; as, a doctrinal observation.
Drilling: A heavy, twilled fabric of linen or cotton.
dicebox: A box from which dice are thrown in gaming.
Demilance: A light lance; a short spear; a half pike; also, a demilancer.
Dotery: The acts or speech of a dotard; drivel.
Detriment: To do injury to; to hurt.
Devolve: To pass by transmission or succession; to be handed over or down; -- generally with on or upon, sometimes with to or into; as, after the general fell, the command devolved upon (or on) the next officer in rank.
Defalcate: To commit defalcation; to embezzle money held in trust.
Dweller: An inhabitant; a resident; as, a cave dweller.
Debilitate: To impair the strength of; to weaken; to enfeeble; as, to debilitate the body by intemperance.
Decury: A set or squad of ten men under a decurion.
drugging: the administration of a sedative agent or drug.
Disgustful: Provoking disgust; offensive to the taste; exciting aversion; disgusting.
deluxe: impressively expensive; notably exceeding typical price or quality.
Dispend: To spend; to lay out; to expend.
dollar: A silver coin of the United States containing 371.25 grains of silver and 41.25 grains of alloy, that is, having a total weight of 412.5 grains.
Dragman: A fisherman who uses a dragnet.
Diverticulum: A blind tube branching out of a longer one.
Dietary: A rule of diet; a fixed allowance of food, as in workhouse, prison, etc.
disassembler: a computer program that takes as input a computer program in machine language and produces an equivalent assembly-language file.
Desightment: The act of making unsightly; disfigurement.
Drawnet: A net for catching the larger sorts of birds; also, a dragnet.
Dehorter: A dissuader; an adviser to the contrary.
Drowse: A slight or imperfect sleep; a doze.
deiparous: Bearing or bringing forth a god; -- said of the Virgin Mary.
Devour: To eat up with greediness; to consume ravenously; to feast upon like a wild beast or a glutton; to prey upon.
Drowsy: Inclined to drowse; heavy with sleepiness; lethargic; dozy.
Deathliness: The quality of being deathly; deadliness.
Dozy: Drowsy; inclined to doze; sleepy; sluggish; as, a dozy head.
Dispope: To refuse to consider as pope; to depose from the popedom.
Denouncer: One who denounces, or declares, as a menace.
Disband: To become separated, broken up, dissolved, or scattered; especially, to quit military service by breaking up organization.
Decerp: To pluck off; to crop; to gather.
Dentilave: A wash for cleaning the teeth.
donnish: like a university don; marked by a narrow focus on or display of learning, especially its trivial aspects.
Deoperculate: Having the lid removed; -- said of the capsules of mosses.
Dwindlement: The act or process of dwindling; a dwindling.
Dynactinometer: An instrument for measuring the intensity of the photogenic (light-producing) rays, and computing the power of object glasses.
Decarburization: The act, process, or result of decarburizing.
Denarcotize: To deprive of narcotine; as, to denarcotize opium.
Dormant: A large beam in the roof of a house upon which portions of the other timbers rest or “ sleep.”
Doubloon: A Spanish gold coin, no longer issued, varying in value at different times from over fifteen dollars to about five. See Doblon in Sup.
dustless: Without dust; as a dustless path.
Defatigate: To weary or tire out; to fatigue.
duplication: The act of duplicating, or the state of being duplicated; a doubling; a folding over; a fold.
Disengage: To release one's self; to become detached; to free one's self.
Dimension: Measure in a single line, as length, breadth, height, thickness, or circumference; extension; measurement; -- usually, in the plural, measure in length and breadth, or in length, breadth, and thickness; extent; size; as, the dimensions of a room, or of a ship; the dimensions of a farm, of a kingdom.
Disgradation: Degradation; a stripping of titles and honors.
Diagnose: To ascertain by diagnosis; to diagnosticate. See Diagnosticate.
Devil: The Evil One; Satan, represented as the tempter and spiritual of mankind.
Desquamative: Of, pertaining to, or attended with, desquamation.
Dolly: A child's mane for a doll.
Dichroic: Having the property of dichroism; as, a dichroic crystal.
Dismarshal: To disarrange; to derange; to put in disorder.
Daintify: To render dainty, delicate, or fastidious.
Danaus: the type genus of the Danaidae, including the monarch butterfly, Danaus plexippus.
Duumvir: One of two Roman officers or magistrates united in the same public functions.
Devoutness: Quality or state of being devout.
Disclosure: The act of disclosing, uncovering, or revealing; bringing to light; exposure.
Downright: Plain; direct; forthright; unceremonious; blunt; positive; as, he spoke in his downright way.
del: a differential operator which, operating on a function of several variables, gives the sum of the partial derivatives of the function with respect to the three orthogonal spatial coordinates; -- also called the gradient or grad.  It is represented by an inverted Greek capital delta (∇), and is thus because of its shape also called nabla, meaning harp in Hebrew.
dazed: stupefied; conscious but unable to think clearly; -- usually caused by a blow or other shock.
Dejectory: Having power, or tending, to cast down.
Directorship: The condition or office of a director; directorate.
dee: an electrode with a large interior cavity, shaped like the letter "D", used in opposed pairs to accelerate particles in a cyclotron.
Diureide: One of a series of complex nitrogenous substances regarded as containing two molecules of urea or their radicals, as uric acid or allantoin.  Cf. Ureide.
demasculinize: to remove the testicles of a male animal.
drained: having lost much energy or emotion from vigorous activity; -- of people; as, the day's events left her completely drained of strength.
Dys-: An inseparable prefix, fr. the Greek dys- hard, ill, and signifying ill, bad, hard, difficult, and the like; cf. the prefixes, Skr. dus-, Goth. tuz-, OHG. zur-, G. zer-, AS. to-, Icel. tor-, Ir. do-.
Dragnet: A net to be drawn along the bottom of a body of water, as in fishing.
Declarative: Making declaration, proclamation, or publication; explanatory; assertive; declaratory.
Denitrify: To deprive of, or free from, nitrogen.
Detestable: Worthy of being detested; abominable; extremely hateful; very odious; deserving abhorrence; as, detestable vices.
Don: To put on; to dress in; to invest one's self with.
Drumfish: Any fish of the family Sciænidæ, which makes a loud noise by means of its air bladder; -- called also drum.
Dom: A title anciently given to the pope, and later to other church dignitaries and to some monastic orders. See Don, and Dan.
Dog: To hunt or track like a hound; to follow insidiously or indefatigably; to chase with a dog or dogs; to worry, as if by dogs; to hound with importunity.
Dor: To make a fool of; to deceive.
Dow: shortened form of the Dow-Jones Index or Dow Jones Industrial Average; as, the Dow rose 100 points today.
down-and-out: a person who is destitute; as, he tried to help the down-and-out.
DoD: the United States Department of Defense, the federal department responsible for safeguarding national security; created in 1947.  It includes within its jurisdiction control of the Army, Navy, Air Force, and Marines.
dragon: A fabulous animal, generally represented as a monstrous winged serpent or lizard, with a crested head and enormous claws, and regarded as very powerful and ferocious.
deserted: having no residents; as, deserted villages.
Dough: Paste of bread; a soft mass of moistened flour or meal, kneaded or unkneaded, but not yet baked; as, to knead dough.
DoT: The United States Department of Transportation.
dysgenics: the study of the operation of factors causing degeneration in the type of offspring produced.
Digynia: A Linnæan order of plants having two styles.
Dreibund: A triple alliance; specif., the alliance of Germany, Austria, and Italy, formed in 1882.
Debonair: Characterized by courteousness, affability, or gentleness; of good appearance and manners; graceful; complaisant.
Disallow: To refuse to allow; to deny the force or validity of; to disown and reject; as, the judge disallowed the executor's charge.
Distinctness: The quality or state of being distinct; a separation or difference that prevents confusion of parts or things.
Disquisitive: Relating to disquisition; fond of discussion or investigation; examining; inquisitive.
Destituent: Deficient; wanting; as, a destituent condition.
Detersion: The act of deterging or cleansing, as a sore.
Dandiprat: A little fellow; -- in sport or contempt.
Depredator: One who plunders or pillages; a spoiler; a robber.
Dish: To put in a dish, ready for the table.
Deglazing: The process of giving a dull or ground surface to glass by acid or by mechanical means.
Domino theory: A political theory current in the 1960's, according to which the conversion of one country in South Asia to communism will start a sequential process causing all Asian countries to convert to Communism.
Devata: A deity; a divine being; a good spirit; an idol.
Deference: A yielding of judgment or preference from respect to the wishes or opinion of another; submission in opinion; regard; respect; complaisance.
Diatribe: A prolonged or exhaustive discussion; especially, an acrimonious or invective harangue; a strain of abusive or railing language; a philippic.
Doubting: That is uncertain; that distrusts or hesitates; having doubts.
Desirer: One who desires, asks, or wishes.
Detrital: Pertaining to, or composed of, detritus.
Declaratively: By distinct assertion; not impliedly; in the form of a declaration.
Detrusion: The act of thrusting or driving down or outward; outward thrust.
Dogwatch: A half watch; a watch of two hours, of which there are two, the first dogwatch from 4 to 6 o'clock, p. m., and the second dogwatch from 6 to 8 o'clock, p. m.
Demarcation: The act of marking, or of ascertaining and setting a limit; separation; distinction.
Decimally: By tens; by means of decimals.
Dorsiferous: Bearing, or producing, on the back; -- applied to ferns which produce seeds on the back of the leaf, and to certain Batrachia, the ova of which become attached to the skin of the back of the parent, where they develop; dorsiparous.
Diminutive: Something of very small size or value; an insignificant thing.
dasyure: A carnivorous catlike marsupial quadruped of Australia, belonging to the genus Dasyurus, called also native cat. There are several species.
Daltonism: Inability to perceive or distinguish certain colors, esp. red; color blindness. It has various forms and degrees. So called from the chemist Dalton, who had this infirmity.
Doubleganger: An apparition or double of a living person; a doppelgänger.
Dungaree: A coarse kind of unbleached cotton fabric; blue denim.
Disaffirm: To assert the contrary of; to contradict; to deny; -- said of that which has been asserted.
Drawplate: A hardened steel plate having a hole, or a gradation of conical holes, through which wires are drawn to be reduced and elongated.
Dimya: An order of lamellibranchiate mollusks having an anterior and posterior adductor muscle, as the common clam. See Bivalve.
Despondency: The state of desponding; loss of hope and cessation of effort; discouragement; depression or dejection of the mind.
dogey: a motherless calf in a range herd of cattle.
Debridement: the surgical excision of dead, contaminated, or damaged tissue, and foreign matter, especially from a wound.
Deathwatch: A small beetle (Anobium tessellatum and other allied species). By forcibly striking its head against woodwork it makes a ticking sound, which is a call of the sexes to each other, but has been imagined by superstitious people to presage death.
Drossel: A slut; a hussy; a drazel.
draped: covered with or as if with clothes or a wrap or cloak; as, a beam draped with cobwebs.  Contrasted with uncovered.
dosimetry: Measurement of doses; specif., a system of therapeutics which uses but few remedies, mostly alkaloids, and gives them in doses fixed by certain rules.
Displacency: Want of complacency or gratification; envious displeasure; dislike.
Diminutiveness: The quality of being diminutive; smallness; littleness; minuteness.
Deglutition: The act or process of swallowing food; the power of swallowing.
Divagation: A wandering about or going astray; digression.
Drysalter: A dealer in salted or dried meats, pickles, sauces, etc., and in the materials used in pickling, salting, and preserving various kinds of food Hence drysalters usually sell a number of saline substances and miscellaneous drugs.
Dazzlement: Dazzling flash, glare, or burst of light.
Disship: To dismiss from service on board ship.
Dissert: To discourse or dispute; to discuss.
Double-charge: To load with a double charge, as of gunpowder.
Disbursement: The act of disbursing or paying out.
Dryadella: a genus of plants comprising tropical American species usually placed in the genus Masdevallia; they are very dwarf plants having short tufted and usually unifoliate stems with usually solitary flowers.
Dog-faced: Having a face resembling that of a dog.
Disapprove: To pass unfavorable judgment upon; to condemn by an act of the judgment; to regard as wrong, unsuitable, or inexpedient; to censure; as, to disapprove the conduct of others.
Depone: To testify under oath; to depose; to bear witness.
Dysenteric: Of or pertaining to dysentery; having dysentery; as, a dysenteric patient.
Druery: Courtship; gallantry; love; an object of love.
Daubreelite: A sulphide of chromium observed in some meteoric irons.
Dogfish: A small shark, of many species, of the genera Mustelus, Scyllium, Spinax, etc.
Dead-eye: A round, flattish, wooden block, encircled by a rope, or an iron band, and pierced with three holes to receive the lanyard; -- used to extend the shrouds and stays, and for other purposes. Called also deadman's eye.
Desperately: In a desperate manner; without regard to danger or safety; recklessly; extremely; as, the troops fought desperately.
Diverging: Tending in different directions from a common center; spreading apart; divergent.
Decennial: A tenth year or tenth anniversary.
Dephlegm: To rid of phlegm or water; to dephlegmate.
Dryad: A wood nymph; a nymph whose life was bound up with that of her tree.
Dereligionize: To make irreligious; to turn from religion.
doubled: rendered twice as great or twice as many.
Discina: A genus of Branchiopoda, having a disklike shell, attached by one valve, which is perforated by the peduncle.
Distractile: Tending or serving to draw apart.
Drawbridge: A bridge of which either the whole or a part is made to be raised up, let down, or drawn or turned aside, to admit or hinder communication at pleasure, as before the gate of a town or castle, or over a navigable river or canal.
drainboard: a board beside a kitchen sink having a surface inclined so as to drain into the sink.
Dishorn: To deprive of horns; as, to dishorn cattle.
Daguerreotype: To produce or represent by the daguerreotype process, as a picture.
double-crosser: one who double-crosses another; a person who says one thing and does another.
deactivation: The act or process of deactivating.
Dispersion: The act or process of scattering or dispersing, or the state of being scattered or separated; as, the Jews in their dispersion retained their rites and ceremonies; a great dispersion of the human family took place at the building of Babel.
Daguerreotypy: The art or process of producing pictures by method of Daguerre.
Disinthrall: To free from thralldom; to disenthrall.
Doctorally: In the manner of a doctor.
Dieffenbachia: a genus of evergreen perennial herbs of tropical America with lush foliage and poisonous sap; often cultivated as houseplants.
Dresser: A piece of chamber furniture consisting of a chest of drawers, or bureau, with a mirror.
Deliciously: Delightfully; as, to feed deliciously; to be deliciously entertained.
Disport: To divert or amuse; to make merry.
Delineation: The act of representing, portraying, or describing, as by lines, diagrams, sketches, etc.; drawing an outline; as, the delineation of a scene or face; in drawing and engraving, representation by means of lines, as distinguished from representation by means of tints and shades; accurate and minute representation, as distinguished from art that is careless of details, or subordinates them excessively.
Dryobalanops: The genus to which belongs the single species Dryobalanops Camphora, a lofty resinous tree of Borneo and Sumatra, yielding Borneo camphor and camphor oil.
Donative: Vested or vesting by donation; as, a donative advowson.
Dank: A small silver coin current in Persia.
Domesticate: To make domestic; to habituate to home life; as, to domesticate one's self.
Dane: A native, or a naturalized inhabitant, of Denmark.
Disforestation: The act of clearing land of forests.
Detective: One who business it is so detect criminals or discover matters of secrecy.
Declivitous: Descending gradually; moderately steep; sloping; downhill.
Dianthus: A genus of plants containing some of the most popular of cultivated flowers, including the pink, carnation, and Sweet William.
docudrama: a film or TV program presenting the facts about a person or event.
Disaffectionate: Not disposed to affection; unfriendly; disaffected.
dreamlike: resembling a dream; vague or fantastic; as, night invested the lake with a dreamlike quality.
Discoursive: The state or quality of being discoursive or able to reason.
Denier: A small copper coin of insignificant value.
Drazel: A slut; a vagabond wench. Same as Drossel.
Docoglossa: An order of gastropods, including the true limpets, and having the teeth on the odontophore or lingual ribbon.
Damnably: In a manner to incur severe censure, condemnation, or punishment.
Distort: To twist of natural or regular shape; to twist aside physically; as, to distort the limbs, or the body.
Damnable: Liable to damnation; deserving, or for which one deserves, to be damned; of a damning nature.
Disjointed: Separated at the joints; disconnected; incoherent.
Daughter: The female offspring of the human species; a female child of any age; -- applied also to the lower animals.
Ding: A thump or stroke, especially of a bell.
Dine: To give a dinner to; to furnish with the chief meal; to feed; as, to dine a hundred men.
Diacritic: That separates or distinguishes; -- applied to points or marks used to distinguish letters of similar form, or different sounds of the same letter, as, ā, ă, ä, ō, &obreve_;, etc.
Daguerrean: Pertaining to Daguerre, or to his invention of the daguerreotype.
Dissident: One who disagrees or dissents; one who separates from the established religion.
Dint: To make a mark or cavity on or in, by a blow or by pressure; to dent.
Demijohn: A glass vessel or bottle with a large body and small neck, inclosed in wickerwork.
Drench: A military vassal mentioned in Domesday Book.
Divinity: The state of being divine; the nature or essence of God; deity; godhead.
Dissociation: The act of dissociating or disuniting; a state of separation; disunion.
Decidua: The inner layer of the wall of the uterus, which envelops the embryo, forms a part of the placenta, and is discharged with it.
Discompliance: Failure or refusal to comply; noncompliance.
down-to-earth: facing reality squarely; guided by practical experience and observation rather than theory.  Opposite of idealistic, unrealistic, impractical, and pie-in-the-sky.
decoration: The act of adorning, embellishing, or honoring; ornamentation.
Duebill: A brief written acknowledgment of a debt, not made payable to order, like a promissory note.
disillusioning: freeing from illusion or false belief.
Deforest: To clear of forests; to disforest.
Descending: Of or pertaining to descent; moving downwards.
disestablishmentarianism: The doctrine or political position that advocates abrogating the establishment of a church as the official state religion.
Domestically: In a domestic manner; privately; with reference to domestic affairs.
Daboia: A large and highly venomous Asiatic viper (Daboia xanthica).
Di-: A prefix, signifying twofold, double, twice
Deception: The act of deceiving or misleading.
Doorcase: The surrounding frame into which a door shuts.
Durukuli: A small, nocturnal, South American monkey of the genus Aotus (formerly Nyctipthecus trivirgatus). The owl monkey.  See douroucouli.
D\u00e9bouchure: The outward opening of a river, of a valley, or of a strait.
Departmental: Pertaining to a department or division.
Divergence: A receding from each other in moving from a common center; the state of being divergent; as, an angle is made by the divergence of straight lines.
Divalent: Having two units of combining power; bivalent.  Cf. Valence.
Double first: A degree of the first class both in classics and mathematics.
DPhil: Doctor of Philosophy, a British doctorate.
Din: To sound with a din; a ding.
Die: A small cube, marked on its faces with spots from one to six, and used in playing games by being shaken in a box and thrown from it. See Dice.
Dig: A thrust; a punch; a poke; as, a dig in the side or the ribs. See Dig, v. t., 4.
Dib: One of the small bones in the knee joints of sheep uniting the bones above and below the joints.
Desmomyaria: The division of Tunicata which includes the Salpæ. See Salpa.
Dip: The action of dipping or plunging for a moment into a liquid.
Dis: The god Pluto, god of the underworld; also called Dis Pater.
Deplantation: Act of taking up plants from beds.
Douar: A village composed of Arab tents arranged in streets.
Deuterogamy: A second marriage, after the death of the first husband of wife; -- in distinction from bigamy, as defined in the old canon law. See Bigamy.
downstair: on or of the lower floors of a building, especially the ground floor; as, the downstairs (or downstair phone; the house has no downstairs bathroom.  Opposite of upstairs.
Defective: Anything that is defective or lacking in some respect.
Desperation: The act of despairing or becoming desperate; a giving up of hope.
Deconsecrate: To deprive of sacredness; to secularize.
Dryandra: A genus of shrubs growing in Australia, having beautiful, hard, dry, evergreen leaves.
Diplomatics: The science of diplomas, or the art of deciphering ancient writings, and determining their age, authenticity, etc.; paleography.
Diathermanous: Having the property of transmitting radiant heat; diathermal; -- opposed to athermanous.
Discriminant: The eliminant of the n partial differentials of any homogenous function of n variables. See Eliminant.
Diametrically: In a diametrical manner; directly; as, diametrically opposite.
Dungyard: A yard where dung is collected.
Delapse: To pass down by inheritance; to lapse.
Davit: A spar formerly used on board of ships, as a crane to hoist the flukes of the anchor to the top of the bow, without injuring the sides of the ship; -- called also the fish davit.
Dump: A car or boat for dumping refuse, etc.
Digitate: Having several leaflets arranged, like the fingers of the hand, at the extremity of a stem or petiole. Also, in general, characterized by digitation.
Depucelate: To deflour; to deprive of virginity.
Duramen: The heartwood of an exogenous tree.
Diprotodon: An extinct Quaternary marsupial from Australia, about as large as the hippopotamus; -- so named because of its two large front teeth. See Illustration in Appendix.
Diastase: A soluble enzyme, capable of converting starch and dextrin into sugar.
Desulphurize: To desulphurate; to deprive of sulphur.
Digynian: Of or pertaining to the Digynia; having two styles.
Decurrence: The act of running down; a lapse.
drip-dry: treated so as to be easily or quickly washed and dried and requiring little or no ironing; -- of clothing.
do-si-do: a movement in square-dancing in which two dancers move around each other in a back-to-back position, and return to their original places.
Demonomist: One in subjection to a demon, or to demons.
Domiciliar: A member of a household; a domestic.
directed: having a specified direction; often used in combination; as, goal-directed.
Doing: Anything done; a deed; an action good or bad; hence, in the plural, conduct; behavior. See Do.
Deuto-: A prefix which formerly properly indicated the second in a regular series of compound in the series, and not to its composition, but which is now generally employed in the same sense as bi- or di-, although little used.
Donary: A thing given to a sacred use.
Disembarrass: To free from embarrassment, or perplexity; to clear; to extricate.
Dowdy: An awkward, vulgarly dressed, inelegant woman.
Dynamic: Of or pertaining to dynamics; belonging to energy or power; characterized by energy or production of force.
Devotional: Pertaining to, suited to, or used in, devotion; as, a devotional posture; devotional exercises; a devotional frame of mind.
Disavaunce: To retard; to repel; to do damage to.
dragging: painfully or tediously slow and boring; as, the dragging minutes.
Demency: Dementia; loss of mental powers. See Insanity.
Diploma: A letter or writing, usually under seal, conferring some privilege, honor, or power; a document bearing record of a degree conferred by a literary society or educational institution.
Disruptive: Causing, or tending to cause, disruption; caused by disruption; breaking through; bursting; as, the disruptive discharge of an electrical battery.
Driftwind: A driving wind; a wind that drives snow, sand, etc., into heaps.
Deducible: Capable of being deduced or inferred; derivable by reasoning, as a result or consequence.
Disprofit: To be, or to cause to be, without profit or benefit.
dark-green: similar to the color of fresh grass.
Defedation: The act of making foul; pollution.
de-energize: to deprive of energy, especially electrical energy; the door locks were de-energized and opened manually.
downcast: Cast downward; directed to the ground, from bashfulness, modesty, dejection, or guilt.
Damara: A native of Damaraland, German Southwest Africa. The Damaras include an important and warlike Bantu tribe, and the Hill Damaras, who are Hottentots and mixed breeds hostile to the Bantus.
daikon: a radish of Japan (Raphanus sativus longipinnatus) with a long hard durable root eaten raw or cooked.
Determine: To come to an end; to end; to terminate.
Dogmatizer: One who dogmatizes; a bold asserter; a magisterial teacher.
Detect: To uncover; to discover; to find out; to bring to light; as, to detect a crime or a criminal; to detect a mistake in an account.
Datura: A genus of solanaceous plants, with large funnel-shaped flowers and a four-celled, capsular fruit.
Diencephalon: The interbrain or thalamencephalon; -- sometimes abbreviated to dien.  See Thalamencephalon.
Dialogism: An imaginary speech or discussion between two or more; dialogue.
Dishorse: To dismount; to knock (a person) from a horse.
drive-in: arranged to allow business to be transacted while patrons remain in their vehicles; as, a drive-in window at a bank.
Disinthrallment: A releasing from thralldom or slavery; disenthrallment.
Downlying: The time of retiring to rest; time of repose.
Decisory: Able to decide or determine; having a tendency to decide.
Drosophyllum: a genus of dicotyledonous plants having only one species.
Defense: To furnish with defenses; to fortify.
Dirtily: In a dirty manner; foully; nastily; filthily; meanly; sordidly.
dolmas: plural of dolma; -- sometimes used as a singular form.
Docimology: A treatise on the art of testing, as in assaying metals, etc.
Dentize: To breed or cut new teeth.
Disgage: To free from a gage or pledge; to disengage.
Dipropyl: One of the hexane paraffins, found in petroleum, consisting of two propyl radicals. See Hexane.
Defectionist: One who advocates or encourages defection.
Dauphin: The title of the eldest son of the king of France, and heir to the crown. Since the revolution of 1830, the title has been discontinued.
Danewort: A fetid European species of elder (Sambucus Ebulus); dwarf elder; wallwort; elderwort; -- called also Daneweed, Dane's weed, and Dane's-blood. [Said to grow on spots where battles were fought against the Danes.]
decontaminate: To remove contamination or contaminants from, by a cleansing process; -- usually used of radioactive, infectious, or toxic materials; as, to decontaminate clothing worn by persons with infective disease; decontaminate an area of PCB's after explosion of a transformer.
Dahlin: A variety of starch extracted from the dahlia; -- called also inulin. See Inulin.
Dissipation: The act of dissipating or dispersing; a state of dispersion or separation; dispersion; waste.
Dahlia: A genus of plants native to Mexico and Central America, of the order Compositæ; also, any plant or flower of the genus. The numerous varieties of cultivated dahlias bear conspicuous flowers which differ in color.
Deviator: One who, or that which, deviates.
Distract: To draw apart or away; to divide; to disjoin.
Donkey: An ass; or (less frequently) a mule.
droplight: An electric or gas light suspended from the ceiling by a flexible cord or tube, allowing artificial light to be brought down from a chandelier nearer to a table or desk; a pendant; also, an electric light bulb in a small holder, which can be held in the hand or hung from a hook, and attached to a long electric cord, allowing light to be brought close to work in dark areas of a room.
Drinker: One who drinks; as, the effects of tea on the drinker; also, one who drinks spirituous liquors to excess; a drunkard.
Disquieter: One who, or that which, disquiets, or makes uneasy; a disturber.
diagonalizable: able to be diagonalized; -- of a matrix.
Drank: Wild oats, or darnel grass. See Drake a plant.
Depravity: The state of being depraved or corrupted; a vitiated state of moral character; general badness of character; wickedness of mind or heart; absence of religious feeling and principle.
Dale: A low place between hills; a vale or valley.
Devoir: Duty; service owed; hence, due act of civility or respect; -- now usually in the plural; as, they paid their devoirs to the ladies.
Driver: One who, or that which, drives; the person or thing that urges or compels anything else to move onward.
Defamer: One who defames; a slanderer; a detractor; a calumniator.
Drivel: Slaver; saliva flowing from the mouth.
Declaration: The act of declaring, or publicly announcing; explicit asserting; undisguised token of a ground or side taken on any subject; proclamation; exposition; as, the declaration of an opinion; a declaration of war, etc.
degaussing: the process of making a (steel) ship's hull nonmagnetic by producing an opposing magnetic field.
dispirited: Depressed in spirits; deprived of cheer or enthusiasm; disheartened; discouraged; daunted.
Disponer: One who legally transfers property from himself to another.
deckle: A separate thin wooden frame used to form the border of a hand mold, or a curb of India rubber or other material which rests on, and forms the edge of, the mold in a paper machine and determines the width of the paper.
Double-dye: To dye again or twice over.
Discophora: A division of acalephs or jellyfishes, including most of the large disklike species.
Discommode: To put inconvenience; to incommode; to trouble.
deionized: freed from ions by a process of deionization; as, deionized water.
Disponee: The person to whom any property is legally conveyed.
Deified: Honored or worshiped as a deity; treated with supreme regard; godlike.
Deputator: One who deputes, or makes a deputation.
Drink: Liquid to be swallowed; any fluid to be taken into the stomach for quenching thirst or for other purposes, as water, coffee, or decoctions.
Devest: To be taken away, lost, or alienated, as a title or an estate.
Depreciate: To fall in value; to become of less worth; to sink in estimation; as, a paper currency will depreciate, unless it is convertible into specie.
Diffarreation: A form of divorce, among the ancient Romans, in which a cake was used. See Confarreation.
dropforge: to forge with a drop forge; -- of metals.
Downy woodpecker: A small black and white ladder-backed woodpecker (Picoides pubescens) of Central and Eastern U. S. and Canada.  It strongly resembles the hairy woodpecker, but is smaller (6 1/2"), compared with about 9-1/2" for the hairy.  it is common in suburban backyards.
Dignation: The act of thinking worthy; honor.
Devourer: One who, or that which, devours.
Depositary: One with whom anything is lodged in the trust; one who receives a deposit; -- the correlative of depositor.
Dill: To still; to calm; to soothe, as one in pain.
Dysgenesic: Not procreating or breeding freely; as, one race may be dysgenesic with respect to another.
Darmera: a genus consisting of one species.
Dysgenesis: A condition of not generating or breeding freely; infertility; a form of homogenesis in which the hybrids are sterile among themselves, but are fertile with members of either parent race.
Disburthen: To disburden; to relieve of a load.
deoxyribonucleic acid: a nucleic acid, usually of very high molecular weight, consisting of a linear sequence of monomer units of deoxyribonucleotides, occurring in most organisms in pairs of strands, wound together in the form of a double helix; it is the main component of chromosomes and contains the genetic information which is the basis of heredity, transmitted from parent to progeny, and found in all living organisms except for certain viruses which have RNA as their basic genetic material; -- usually referred to by the acronym DNA.
Dephlegmation: The operation of separating water from spirits and acids, by evaporation or repeated distillation; -- called also concentration, especially when acids are the subject of it.
Displantation: The act of displanting; removal; displacement.
Divinize: To invest with a divine character; to deify.
Decerniture: A decree or sentence of a court.
Disposable: Subject to disposal; free to be used or employed as occasion may require; not assigned to any service or use.
Director: One who, or that which, directs; one who regulates, guides, or orders; a manager or superintendent.
digoxin: a steroid glycoside, one of the cardiotonic chemical substances which is extracted from the foxglove. It is a white, crystalline substance (C41H64O14), and is a 3-substituted triglucoside of a steroid, related structurally to digitalin and digitoxin.  It is used as a cardiotonic for treatment of certain heart conditions, such as congestive heart failure.  Chemically it is (3β,5β,12β)-3-[(O-2,6-Dideoxy-β-D-ribo-hexopyranosyl-(1->4)-O-2,6-dideoxy-β-D-ribo-hexopyranosyl-(1->4)-2,6-dideoxy-β-D-ribo-hexopyranosyl)oxy]-12,14-dihydroxy-card-20(22)-enolide.  The related compounds digitalin and digoxin are also extracted from the foxglove (Digitalis lanata and Digitalis purpurea).  The class of steroid glycosides having cardiotonic properties are refered to as the cardiac glycosides.
Detrude: To thrust down or out; to push down with force.
Debilitation: The act or process of debilitating, or the condition of one who is debilitated; weakness.
descendants: all of the offspring of a given progenitor.
dolioform: Barrel-shaped, or like a cask in form.
Danaidae: a small natural family of usually tropical butterflies, including the monarch butterflies.
Dentition: The development and cutting of teeth; teething.
Dacian: Of or pertaining to Dacia or the Dacians.
Daybreak: The time of the first appearance of light in the morning.
dockhand: a laborer who loads and unloads vessels in a port.
disregard: Not to regard; to pay no heed to; to omit to take notice of; to neglect to observe; to slight as unworthy of regard or notice; as, to disregard the admonitions of conscience.
Denigrator: One who, or that which, blackens.
Decadence: A falling away; decay; deterioration; declension. “The old castle, where the family lived in their decadence.”
Dependable: Worthy of being depended on; trustworthy.
Distensive: Distending, or capable of being distended.
Dietarian: One who lives in accordance with prescribed rules for diet; a dieter.
Dephlogisticcate: To deprive of phlogiston, or the supposed principle of inflammability.
Digammate: Having the digamma or its representative letter or sound; as, the Latin word vis is a digammated form of the Greek 'i`s.
Discodactylia: A division of amphibians having suctorial disks on the toes, as the tree frogs.
Directorate: The office of director; also, a body of directors taken jointly.
downstage: at the front half of the stage; as, the dialog is clearer when conducted downstage.  Opposite of upstage.
Divisional: That divides; pertaining to, making, or noting, a division; as, a divisional line; a divisional general; a divisional surgeon of police.
deprived: marked by deprivation especially of the necessities of life or healthful environmental or social influences; as, a childhood that was unhappy and deprived, the family living off charity; boys from a deprived environment, wherein the family life revealed a pattern of neglect, moral degradation, and disregard for law.
Demolition: The act of overthrowing, pulling down, or destroying a pile or structure; destruction by violence; utter overthrow; -- opposed to construction; as, the demolition of a house, of military works, of a town, or of hopes.
Developer: One who, or that which, develops.
Darrein: Last; as, darrein continuance, the last continuance.
decode: to convert from a coded form into the original form; -- of communications.  Inverse of encode.
Devisee: One to whom a devise is made, or real estate given by will.
Damascene: Same as Damask, or Damaskeen, v. t.
Disinvestiture: The act of depriving of investiture.
Duck-billed: Having a bill like that of a duck; as, a duck-billed dinosaur.
disinfector: One who, or that which, disinfects; an apparatus for applying disinfectants.
Deacon: To read aloud each line of (a psalm or hymn) before singing it, -- usually with off.
Discommunity: A lack of common possessions, properties, or relationship.
Dimeter: Having two poetical measures or meters.
Duct: Any tube or canal by which a fluid or other substance is conducted or conveyed.
Dislimb: To tear limb from limb; to dismember.
Duck: Any bird of the subfamily Anatinæ, family Anatidæ.
Disannex: To disunite; to undo or repeal the annexation of.
Didst: the 2d pers. sing. imp. of Do.
Desperado: A reckless, furious man; a person urged by furious passions, and regardless of consequence; a wild ruffian.
Dewberry: The fruit of certain species of bramble (Rubus); in England, the fruit of Rubus cæsius, which has a glaucous bloom; in America, that of Rubus canadensis and Rubus hispidus, species of low blackberries.
Dilatator: A muscle which dilates any part; a dilator.
Discontinuity: Want of continuity or cohesion; disunion of parts.
Disagreement: The state of disagreeing; a being at variance; dissimilitude; diversity.
Diagram: To put into the form of a diagram.
Decrepit: Broken down with age; wasted and enfeebled by the infirmities of old age; feeble; worn out.
Domiciliate: To establish in a permanent residence; to domicile.
Dapper: Little and active; spruce; trim; smart; neat in dress or appearance; lively.
Dendrolagus: a genus comprising the tree wallabies.
Decalcomania: The art or process of transferring pictures and designs to china, glass, marble, etc., and permanently fixing them thereto.
Disespouse: To release from espousal or plighted faith.
Draggle-tail: A slattern who suffers her gown to trail in the mire; a drabble-tail.
downbeat: the first beat of a musical measure (as the conductor's arm moves downward).
Diastatic: Relating to diastase; having the properties of diastase; effecting the conversion of starch into sugar.
Dysuria: Difficult or painful discharge of urine.
Discomfortable: Causing discomfort; occasioning uneasiness; making sad.
diplotene: the fourth stage of the prophase of meiosis, when the paired chromosomes being to separate.  This stage follows the pachytene.
Divergent: Receding farther and farther from each other, as lines radiating from one point; deviating gradually from a given direction; -- opposed to convergent.
Depolarize: To deprive of polarity; to reduce to an unpolarized condition.
Donee: The person to whom a gift or donation is made.
Decoloration: The removal or absence of color.
Diligent: Prosecuted with careful attention and effort; careful; painstaking; not careless or negligent.
Dannebrog: The ancient battle standard of Denmark, bearing figures of cross and crown.
Dismayedness: A state of being dismayed; dejection of courage; dispiritedness.
defoliation: The separation of ripened leaves from a branch or stem; the falling or shedding of the leaves.
Dear-bought: Bought at a high price; as, dear-bought experience.
Devotor: A worshiper; one given to devotion.
dewfall: The falling of dew; the time when dew begins to fall.
Diction: Choice of words for the expression of ideas; the construction, disposition, and application of words in discourse, with regard to clearness, accuracy, variety, etc.; mode of expression; language; as, the diction of Chaucer's poems.
Double-lock: To lock with two bolts; to fasten with double security.
Decoy-man: A man employed in decoying wild fowl.
Dilettanteism: The state or quality of being a dilettante; the desultory pursuit of art, science, or literature.
Deliquiate: To melt and become liquid by absorbing water from the air; to deliquesce.
Dichromic: Furnishing or giving two colors; -- said of defective vision, in which all the compound colors are resolvable into two elements instead of three.
Discreet: Possessed of discernment, especially in avoiding error or evil, and in the adaptation of means to ends; prudent; sagacious; judicious; not rash or heedless; cautious.
De rigueur: According to strictness (of etiquette, rule, or the like); obligatory; strictly required.
Deoxidize: To deprive of oxygen; to reduce from the state of an oxide.
disrealize: To divest of reality; to make uncertain.
Dimensive: Without dimensions; marking dimensions or the limits.
Dilemma: An argument which presents an antagonist with two or more alternatives, but is equally conclusive against him, whichever alternative he chooses.
Design: A preliminary sketch; an outline or pattern of the main features of something to be executed, as of a picture, a building, or a decoration; a delineation; a plan.
Delicious: Affording exquisite pleasure; delightful; most sweet or grateful to the senses, especially to the taste; charming.
Dislocation: The act of displacing, or the state of being displaced.
Duledge: One of the dowels joining the ends of the fellies which form the circle of the wheel of a gun carriage.
Desquamation: The separation or shedding of the cuticle or epidermis in the form of flakes or scales; exfoliation, as of bones.
diskjockey: to comment on music to be played.
Decolorant: A substance which removes color, or bleaches.
Danalite: A mineral occuring in octahedral crystals, also massive, of a reddish color. It is a silicate of iron, zinc manganese, and glucinum, containing sulphur.
Drabbler: A piece of canvas fastened by lacing to the bonnet of a sail, to give it a greater depth, or more drop.
Deracinate: To pluck up by the roots; to extirpate.
Deny: To answer in &unr_;&unr_;&unr_; negative; to declare an assertion not to be true.
Dent: A tooth, as of a card, a gear wheel, etc.
Daubentonia: the type genus,  coextensive with the family Daubentoniidae.
Dementate: To deprive of reason; to dement.
Dimidiate: To divide into two equal parts.
Demonianism: The state of being possessed by a demon or by demons.
decumary: a woody climber of southeastern US (Decumaria barbara) having white flowers in compound terminal clusters.
Dysphonia: A difficulty in producing vocal sounds; enfeebled or depraved voice.
Dilaniate: To rend in pieces; to tear.
Disproportionate: Not proportioned; unsymmetrical; unsuitable to something else in bulk, form, value, or extent; out of proportion; inadequate; as, in a perfect body none of the limbs are disproportionate; it is wisdom not to undertake a work disproportionate means.
Dismay: Loss of courage and firmness through fear; overwhelming and disabling terror; a sinking of the spirits; consternation.
Disedge: To deprive of an edge; to blunt; to dull.
Dissimilar: Not similar; unlike; heterogeneous; as, the tempers of men are as dissimilar as their features.
Dope: To treat or affect with dope; as, to dope nitroglycerin;
Denizenize: To constitute (one) a denizen; to denizen.
Dismaw: To eject from the maw; to disgorge.
Drayman: A man who attends a dray.
Dorado: A southern constellation, within which is the south pole of the ecliptic; -- called also sometimes Xiphias, or the Swordfish.
Drought: Dryness; want of rain or of water; especially, such dryness of the weather as affects the earth, and prevents the growth of plants; aridity.
demasculinization: the act or process of demasculinizing; the removal of the testicles of a male animal.
Diabolic: Pertaining to the devil; resembling, or appropriate, or appropriate to, the devil; befitting hell or satan; devilish; infernal; impious; as, a diabolic or diabolical temper or act; the diabolical expression on his face; fires lit up a diabolic scene.
disseminating: serving to diffuse, disseminate, or disperse.
dallis grass: a tall tufted perennial tropical American grass (Paspalum dilatatum) naturalized as pasture and forage grass in the southern U.S.
discredited: being brought into disrepute; as, a discredited politician.
Disponge: To sprinkle, as with water from a sponge.
Domify: To divide, as the heavens, into twelve houses. See House, in astrological sense.
disoriented: having lost one's bearings physically or mentally.
drafty: not airtight; allowing in currents of air, especially uncomfortably cold air; -- of buildings.
diskette: a data-storage medium consisting of a small plastic disk coated with a thin layer of magnetizable material on one or both sides, enclosed in a stiff envelope with a radial slit.  It is used in a specially designed disk drive, in which the disk is rotated at high speed, and which stores data on the disk by causing changes in the direction of magnetization of the magnetic layer as the disk spins and as sequential locations on the disk pass under the read-write head of the drive.  Reading of the data occurs in the reverse process, by detection of the patterns of magnetization of the disk.  Such disks are used to store data or programs for a microcomputer.
Dugout: A canoe or boat dug out from a large log.
Dunkerque: the name of a town and a battle fought there, in World War II (1940) when 330,000 Allied troops had to be evacuated from the beaches at Dunkirk in a desperate retreat under enemy fire.  Most of the forces were safely evacuated to England.
Drabbish: Having the character of a drab or low wench.
Defloration: The act of deflouring; as, the defloration of a virgin.
Dilacerate: To rend asunder; to tear to pieces.
Dry-eyed: Not having tears in the eyes.  Opposite of tearful.
discreditable: Not creditable; injurious to reputation; disgraceful; disreputable.
Disembodiment: The act of disembodying, or the state of being disembodied.
demographic: of or pertaining to demography; as, demographic surveys.
Declinable: Capable of being declined; admitting of declension or inflection; as, declinable parts of speech.
D\u0153gling: The beaked whale (Balænoptera rostrata), from which dœgling oil is obtained.
Dearborn: A four-wheeled carriage, with curtained sides.
dry-clean: to clean without the use of water; -- usually by immersing in an organic solvent to remove grease.
Denaturalize: To render unnatural; to alienate from nature.
deployment: the arrangement or distribution (of resources such as people or equipment), in preparation for battle or work.
discombobulated: confused; upset; as, the hecklers pelted the discombobulated speaker with anything that came to hand.
Durham: One or a breed of short-horned cattle, originating in the county of Durham, England. The Durham cattle are noted for their beef-producing quality.
Delusional: Of or pertaining to delusions; as, delusional monomania.
Duplex: To arrange, as a telegraph line, so that two  messages may be transmitted simultaneously; to equip with a duplex telegraphic outfit.
Dakotas: An extensive race or stock of Indians, including many tribes, mostly dwelling west of the Mississippi River; -- also, in part, called Sioux.
dissolvent: Having power to dissolve power to dissolve a solid body; as, the dissolvent juices of the stomach.
Dialogistic: Pertaining to a dialogue; having the form or nature of a dialogue.
Ductile: Easily led; tractable; complying; yielding to motives, persuasion, or instruction; as, a ductile people.
Dry-rub: To rub and cleanse without wetting.
dreidel: a toy shaped somewhat like a top, but having four flat sides, each marked with one of the Hebrew letters nun, gimel, he, or shin.  It is spun like a top, and the letter showing when it stops spinning determines the outcome of a game of chance.
Dissenter: One who dissents; one who differs in opinion, or declares his disagreement.
Dasyproctidae: a natural family including the agoutis and pacas.
Demoiselle: A young lady; a damsel; a lady's maid.
Devexity: A bending downward; a sloping; incurvation downward; declivity.
Diaphanous: Allowing light to pass through, as porcelain; translucent or transparent; pellucid; clear.
Double-minded: Having different minds at different times; unsettled; undetermined.
Dissolubleness: The quality of being dissoluble; dissolubility.
Diselder: To deprive of an elder or elders, or of the office of an elder.
Dexterousness: The quality of being dexterous; dexterity.
Demerge: To plunge down into; to sink; to immerse.
Dioptre: A unit employed by oculists in numbering glasses according to the metric system; a refractive power equal to that of a glass whose principal focal distance is one meter.
damselfly: a slender nonstinging insect similar to but smaller than the dragonfly but having wings folded when at rest.
Darraign: To make ready to fight; to array.
Delenda: Things to be erased or blotted out.
Desiccation: The act of desiccating, or the state of being desiccated.
Disembarrassment: Freedom or relief from impediment or perplexity.
De-: A prefix from Latin de down, from, away; as in debark, decline, decease, deduct, decamp. In words from the French it is equivalent to Latin dis- apart, away; or sometimes to de.  Cf. Dis-. It is negative and opposite in derange, deform, destroy, etc. It is intensive in deprave, despoil, declare, desolate, etc.
Drawspring: The spring to which a drawbar is attached.
denaturized: changed in nature or natural quality.
Dilative: Causing dilation; tending to dilate, on enlarge; expansive.
Diadrom: A complete course or vibration; time of vibration, as of a pendulum.
Drawbore: To make a drawbore in; as, to drawbore a tenon.
Doddart: A game much like hockey, played in an open field; also, the, bent stick for playing the game.
Decipher: To translate from secret characters or ciphers into intelligible terms; as, to decipher a letter written in secret characters.
Dress goods: A term applied to fabrics for the gowns of women and girls; -- most commonly to fabrics of mixed materials, but also applicable to silks, printed linens, and calicoes.
Discuss: To break to pieces; to shatter.
Doe, John: The fictitious lessee acting as plaintiff in the common-law action of ejectment, the fictitious defendant being usually denominated Richard Roe. Hence, a fictitious name for a party, real or fictitious, to any action or proceeding.
Disagreeable: Not agreeable, conformable, or congruous; contrary; unsuitable.
Dey: The governor of Algiers; -- so called before the French conquest in 1830.
Deadhouse: A morgue; a place for the temporary reception and exposure of dead bodies.
Dev: A god; a deity; a divine being; an idol; a king.
Debentured: Entitled to drawback or debenture; as, debentured goods.
Den: To live in, or as in, a den.
Disagreeably: In a disagreeable manner; unsuitably; offensively.
Dormouse: A small European rodent of the genus Myoxus, of several species. They live in trees and feed on nuts, acorns, etc.; -- so called because they are usually torpid in winter.
Discordant: Disagreeing; incongruous; being at variance; clashing; opposing; not harmonious.
domine: A name given to a pastor of the Reformed Church. The word is also applied locally in the United States, in colloquial speech, to any clergyman.
Derecho: A straight wind without apparent cyclonic tendency, usually accompanied with rain and often destructive, common in the prairie regions of the United States.
Desmine: Same as Stilbite. It commonly occurs in bundles or tufts of crystals.
Diverge: To extend from a common point in different directions; to tend from one point and recede from each other; to tend to spread apart; to turn aside or deviate (as from a given direction); -- opposed to converge; as, rays of light diverge as they proceed from the sun.
Depletion: The act of depleting or emptying.
Diaphote: An instrument designed for transmitting pictures by telegraph.
Dunkirk: the name of a town and a battle fought there, in World War II (1940) when 330,000 Allied troops had to be evacuated from the beaches at Dunkirk in a desperate retreat under enemy fire.  Most of the forces were safely evacuated to England.
diatomaceous: consisting of or containing diatoms or their fossils; as, diatomaceous earth (used as a component of dynamite).
Decomposed: Separated or broken up; -- said of the crest of birds when the feathers are divergent.
Dissimilarity: Want of resemblance; unlikeness; dissimilitude; variety; as, the dissimilarity of human faces and forms.
dresser: One who dresses; one who put in order or makes ready for use; one who on clothes or ornaments.
Direful: Dire; dreadful; terrible; calamitous; woeful; as, a direful fiend; a direful day.
Dormer: A window pierced in a roof, and so set as to be vertical while the roof slopes away from it. Also, the gablet, or houselike structure, in which it is contained.
Daphnomancy: Divination by means of the laurel.
Diversify: To make diverse or various in form or quality; to give variety to; to variegate; to distinguish by numerous differences or aspects.
Desoxalic: Made or derived from oxalic acid; as, desoxalic acid.
Deliberation: The act of deliberating, or of weighing and examining the reasons for and against a choice or measure; careful consideration; mature reflection.
Drawrod: A rod which unites the drawgear at opposite ends of the car, and bears the pull required to draw the train.
Duan: A division of a poem corresponding to a canto; a poem or song.
Dual: Expressing, or consisting of, the number two; belonging to two; as, the dual number of nouns, etc. , in Greek.
Discommon: To deprive of the right of common.
Dialyzer: The instrument or medium used to effect chemical dialysis.
Dialyzed: Prepared by diffusion through an animal membrane; as, dialyzed iron.
Doucker: A grebe or diver; -- applied also to the golden-eye, pochard, scoter, and other ducks.
demagnetization: the act or process of removing magnetization.
Diodon: A genus of spinose, plectognath fishes, having the teeth of each jaw united into a single beaklike plate. They are able to inflate the body by taking in air or water, and, hence, are called globefishes, swellfishes, etc. Called also porcupine fishes, and sea hedgehogs.
Despondent: Marked by despondence; given to despondence; low-spirited; as, a despondent manner; a despondent prisoner.
Dissectible: Capable of being dissected, or separated by dissection.
Debility: The state of being weak; weakness; feebleness; languor.
Deluge: To overflow with water; to inundate; to overwhelm.
Diazotize: To subject to such reactions or processes that diazo compounds, or their derivatives, shall be produced by chemical exchange or substitution.
Dreggy: Containing dregs or lees; muddy; foul; feculent.
Diacatholicon: A universal remedy; -- a name formerly given to a purgative electuary.
deflator: a statistical factor designed to remove the effect of inflation; inflation adjusted variables are in constant dollars; as, the GNP deflator..
Dravidian: Of or pertaining to the Dravida.
Delict: An offense or transgression against law; (Scots Law) an offense of a lesser degree; a misdemeanor.
Desiccator: One who, or that which, desiccates.
Draggle: To be dragged on the ground; to become wet or dirty by being dragged or trailed in the mud or wet grass.
Diallage: A dark green or bronze-colored laminated variety of pyroxene, common in certain igneous rocks.
Deteriorate: To make worse; to make inferior in quality or value; to impair; as, to deteriorate the mind.
Devoutly: In a devout and reverent manner; with devout emotions; piously.
Daughterliness: The state of a daughter, or the conduct becoming a daughter.
Diploic: Of or pertaining to the diploë.
Disturber: One who, or that which, disturbs of disquiets; a violator of peace; a troubler.
Dyaus: the Hindu god of the sky.
Disedify: To fail of edifying; to injure.
Diptote: A noun which has only two cases.
Delighter: One who gives or takes delight.
Devisable: Capable of being devised, invented, or contrived.
Desmology: The science which treats of the ligaments.
descale: to remove the scales from; -- e.g. of fish, or water boilers.
Disincorporate: Separated from, or not included in, a corporation; disincorporated.
Dhow: A coasting vessel of Arabia, East Africa, and the Indian Ocean. It has generally but one mast and a lateen sail.
Debatable: Liable to be debated; disputable; subject to controversy or contention; open to question or dispute; as, a debatable question.
deviled egg: a hard-boiled egg, sliced into halves and with the yolk removed and replaced with a paste, usually made from the yolk and mayonnaise, seasoned with salt and/or spices such as paprika.
Disaccustom: To destroy the force of habit in; to wean from a custom.
Digitule: A little finger or toe, or something resembling one.
declassify: to lift the restriction on publication [of documents] by reducing or eliminating the secrecy classification of.
Dead-stroke: Making a stroke without recoil; deadbeat.
Denyingly: In the manner of one denies a request.
Discipline: To educate; to develop by instruction and exercise; to train.
Dynamization: The act of setting free the dynamic powers of a medicine, as by shaking the bottle containing it.
dolphin: A cetacean of the genus Delphinus and allied genera (esp. Delphinus delphis); the true dolphin.
Divedapper: A water fowl; the didapper. See Dabchick.
Decemviral: Pertaining to the decemvirs in Rome.
Dele: To deal; to divide; to distribute.
Delf: A mine; a quarry; a pit dug; a ditch.
Dell: A small, retired valley; a ravine.
Doomage: A penalty or fine for neglect.
Dziggetai: The kiang, a wild horse or wild ass of Tibet (Asinus hemionus).
Disentrail: To disembowel; to let out or draw forth, as the entrails.
Dichotomous: Regularly dividing by pairs from bottom to top; as, a dichotomous stem.
deep-six: to discard in a deep body of water; -- also used figuratively, to discard contemptuously.
Degum: To deprive of, or free from, gum; as, to degum ramie.
de-access: to sell or otherwise give up ownership; -- used mostly of artworks in museums.
Decylic: Allied to, or containing, the radical decyl.
Decrepitate: To crackle, as salt in roasting.
Dorr: To deceive. [Obs.] See Dor, v. t.
Dory: A small, strong, flat-bottomed rowboat, with sharp prow and flaring sides.
Dispart: To make allowance for the dispart in (a gun), when taking aim.
Dispark: To throw (a park or inclosure); to treat (a private park) as a common.
Demiurge: The chief magistrate in some of the Greek states.
Dizzy: To make dizzy or giddy; to give the vertigo to; to confuse.
Doorpost: The jamb or sidepiece of a doorway.
drugged: under the influence of narcotics or hypnotic drugs.
