Dog-headed: Having a head shaped like that of a dog; -- said of certain baboons.
dethrone: To remove or drive from a throne; to depose; to divest of supreme authority and dignity.
Decapodal: Belonging to the decapods; having ten feet; ten-footed.
Delinquent: One who fails or neglects to perform his duty; an offender or transgressor; one who commits a fault or a crime; a culprit.
Derivative: That which is derived; anything obtained or deduced from another.
Digitalis: A genus of plants of the family Schrophulariaceae, including the foxglove.
Dysteleology: The doctrine of purposelessness; a term applied by Haeckel to that branch of physiology which treats of rudimentary organs, in view of their being useless to the life of the organism.
Decennoval: Pertaining to the number nineteen; of nineteen years.
Dispassionate: Free from passion; not warped, prejudiced, swerved, or carried away by passion or feeling; judicial; calm; composed.
Doziness: The state of being dozy; drowsiness; inclination to sleep.
Dotty: Composed of, or characterized by, dots.
Disquietal: The act of disquieting; a state of disquiet.
Discalced: Unshod; barefooted; -- in distinction from calced.
Deipnosophist: One of an ancient sect of philosophers, who cultivated learned conversation at meals.
Dartoid: Like the dartos; dartoic; as, dartoid tissue.
Dartoic: Of or pertaining to the dartos.
Dayfly: A neuropterous insect of the genus Ephemera and related genera, of many species, and inhabiting fresh water in the larval state; the ephemeral fly; -- so called because it commonly lives but one day in the winged or adult state. See Ephemeral fly, under Ephemeral.
Dissociable: Not well associated or assorted; incongruous.
Determination: The act of determining, or the state of being determined.
Dividend: A sum of money to be divided and distributed; the share of a sum divided that falls to each individual; a distribute sum, share, or percentage; -- applied to the profits as appropriated among shareholders, and to assets as apportioned among creditors; as, the dividend of a bank, a railway corporation, or a bankrupt estate.
Dammara: A large tree of the order Coniferæ, indigenous to the East Indies and Australasia; -- called also Agathis. There are several species.
dressed to kill: attired in strikingly attractive clothing; -- usually of women.
Depurate: To free from impurities, heterogeneous matter, or feculence; to purify; to cleanse.
Depriver: One who, or that which, deprives.
Discommend: To mention with disapprobation; to blame; to disapprove.
Disunity: A state of separation or disunion; want of unity.
Deciduousness: The quality or state of being deciduous.
Disunite: To part; to fall asunder; to become separated.
Demote: To reduce to a lower grade or rank, as in the military, one's employment, or in school; to assign to a lower position.
digitate: To point out as with the finger.
Dimly: In a dim or obscure manner; not brightly or clearly; with imperfect sight.
Dying: The act of expiring; passage from life to death; loss of life.
Dovekie: A guillemot (Uria grylle), of the arctic regions. Also applied to the little auk or sea dove. See under Dove.
Dangler: One who dangles about or after others, especially after women; a trifler.
Druidic: Pertaining to, or resembling, the Druids.
Drawbolt: A coupling pin. See under Coupling.
Disruption: The act or rending asunder, or the state of being rent asunder or broken in pieces; breach; rent; dilaceration; rupture; as, the disruption of rocks in an earthquake; disruption of a state.
Dogwood: The Cornus, a genus of large shrubs or small trees, the wood of which is exceedingly hard, and serviceable for many purposes.
Demobilization: The disorganization or disarming of troops which have previously been mobilized or called into active service; the change from a war footing to a peace footing.
Dishumor: To deprive of humor or desire; to put out of humor.
Derringer: A kind of short-barreled pocket pistol, of very large caliber, often carrying a half-ounce ball.
dissimulate: To dissemble; to feign; to pretend.
Deutohydroguret: A compound containing in the molecule two atoms of hydrogen united with some other element or radical.
Drac\u00e6na: A genus of liliaceous plants with woody stems and funnel-shaped flowers.
devastating: highly critical; making light of; as, a devastating portrait of human folly.
Demicircle: An instrument for measuring angles, in surveying, etc. It resembles a protractor, but has an alidade, sights, and a compass.
Declarer: One who makes known or proclaims; that which exhibits.
declaw: to remove the claws from, -- used especially with a cat as an object.
Dyke: See Dike. The spelling dyke is restricted by some to the geological meaning.
Disparity: Inequality; difference in age, rank, condition, or excellence; dissimilitude; -- followed by between, in, of, as to, etc.; as, disparity in, or of, years; a disparity as to color.
Down syndrome: A congenital disorder caused by an extra chromosome 21 in some or all cells.  It causes a variable number and degree of abnormalities, including retarded growth, mental retardation, a short nose, prominent epicanthic folds on the eyelids, a protruding lower lip, and other physical features having varying degrees of deviation from the normal.  Called also mongolism, trisomy-21 and trisomy 21 syndrome.
departed: past; -- used of time; as, departed summers.
Drynaria: a genus of large robust epiphytic ferns of tropical forest and scrub; Africa and Asia and Australia.
Diastole: The rhythmical expansion or dilatation of the heart and arteries; -- correlative to systole, or contraction.
Diphthongize: To change into a diphthong, as by affixing another vowel to a simple vowel.
Disimpark: To free from the barriers or restrictions of a park.
Dasyuridae: a natural family including the dasyures, native cats, pouched mice, banded anteaters, and Tasmanian devils.
Decolor: To deprive of color; to bleach.
dog-eared: Having the corners of the leaves turned down and soiled by careless or long-continued usage; -- said of a book; as, an old book with dog-eared pages.
Democratism: The principles or spirit of a democracy.
Dischurch: To deprive of status as a church, or of membership in a church.
Doughty: Able; strong; valiant; redoubtable; as, a doughty hero.
Dextral: Right, as opposed to sinistral, or left.
Dipteran: An insect of the order Diptera.
Dipteral: Having two wings only; belonging to the order Diptera.
Driftway: A common way, road, or path, for driving cattle.
Doubter: One who doubts; one whose opinion is unsettled; one who scruples.
Dishearten: To discourage; to deprive of courage and hope; to depress the spirits of; to deject.
Deathsman: An executioner; a headsman or hangman.
Diffract: To break or separate into parts; to deflect, or decompose by deflection, a&unr_; rays of light.
Double-tonguing: A peculiar action of the tongue by flute players in articulating staccato notes; also, the rapid repetition of notes in cornet playing.
decathlon: In the modern Olympic Games, a composite contest consisting of a 100-meter run, a broad jump, putting the shot, a running high-jump, a 400-meter run, throwing the discus, a 100-meter hurdle race, pole vaulting, throwing the javelin, and a 1500-meter run.
Demitint: That part of a painting, engraving, or the like, which is neither in full darkness nor full light.
Demagogic: Relating to, or like, a demagogue; factious.
Discountenance: Unfavorable aspect; unfriendly regard; cold treatment; disapprobation; whatever tends to check or discourage.
Domino whist: A game of cards in which the suits are played in sequence, beginning with a 5 or 9, the player who gets rid of his cards first being the winner.
Dance: The leaping, tripping, or measured stepping of one who dances; an amusement, in which the movements of the persons are regulated by art, in figures and in accord with music.
Disenthrall: To release from thralldom or slavery; to give freedom to; to disinthrall.
Datum: Something given or admitted; a fact or principle granted; that upon which an inference or an argument is based; -- used chiefly in the plural.
Dresden ware: A superior kind of decorated porcelain made near Dresden in Saxony.
Determinately: In a determinate manner; definitely; ascertainably.
Deeply: At or to a great depth; far below the surface; as, to sink deeply.
Decagonal: Pertaining to a decagon; having ten sides.
Decagram: A weight of the metric system; ten grams, equal to about 154.32 grains avoirdupois.
Donax: A canelike grass of southern Europe (Arundo Donax), used for fishing rods, etc.
Demotics: The department of knowledge relative to the care and culture of the people; sociology in its broadest sense; -- in library cataloguing.
Decemvir: One of a body of ten magistrates in ancient Rome.
Dingdong theory: The theory which maintains that the primitive elements of language are reflex expressions induced by sensory impressions; that is, as stated by Max Müller, the creative faculty gave to each general conception as it thrilled for the first time through the brain a phonetic expression; -- jocosely so called from the analogy of the sound of a bell induced by the stroke of the clapper.
Donar: the Teutonic god of thunder; counterpart of Norse Thor.
Doit: A small Dutch coin, worth about half a farthing; also, a similar small coin once used in Scotland; hence, any small piece of money.
Disseize: To deprive of seizin or possession; to dispossess or oust wrongfully (one in freehold possession of land); -- followed by of; as, to disseize a tenant of his freehold.
Disquisitory: Of or pertaining to disquisition; disquisitive.
Dyaks: The aboriginal and most numerous inhabitants of Borneo. They are partially civilized, but retain many barbarous practices.
Drosometer: An instrument for measuring the quantity of dew on the surface of a body in the open air. It consists of a balance, having a plate at one end to receive the dew, and at the other a weight protected from the deposit of dew.
Deleterious: Hurtful; noxious; destructive; pernicious; as, a deleterious plant or quality; a deleterious example.
Depressant: An agent or remedy which lowers the vital powers.
Diabolify: To ascribed diabolical qualities to; to change into, or to represent as, a devil.
Drizzly: Characterized by small rain, or snow; moist and disagreeable.
Diatomophyceae: a class of marine and freshwater eukaryotic algae comprising the diatoms.
Dipterocarpus: A genus of trees found in the East Indies, some species of which produce a fragrant resin, other species wood oil. The fruit has two long wings.
Diervilla: small genus of low deciduous shrubs; the bush honeysuckles.
Duenna: The chief lady in waiting on the queen of Spain.
Deponent: Having a passive form with an active meaning, as certain latin and Greek verbs.
Dividing: That divides; separating; marking divisions; graduating.
Dressing table: a table, usually having a vertical back piece containing a mirror, at which a person may sit while dressing or applying makeup, and on which articles for the toilet stand.  It often has drawers for toiletries, clothing, or accessories.  It is also called a vanity or vanity table.
Double-ender: A vessel capable of moving in either direction, having bow and rudder at each end.
Deliberately: With careful consideration, or deliberation; circumspectly; warily; not hastily or rashly; slowly; as, a purpose deliberately formed.
Ditokous: Having two kinds of young, as certain annelids.
Decisive: Having the power or quality of deciding a question or controversy; putting an end to contest or controversy; final; conclusive.
Debellation: The act of conquering or subduing.
Dioscoreaceae: a natural family of tuberous plants including the yams.
Discerption: The act of pulling to pieces, or of separating the parts.
Duck-billed platypus: same as Duck Mole, under Duck.
Dradge: Inferior ore, separated from the better by cobbing.
deflect: To cause to turn aside; to bend; as, rays of light are often deflected; to deflect a punch; to deflect criticism by acknowledging a mistake.
Dibbler: One who, or that which, dibbles, or makes holes in the ground for seed.
Dracanth: A kind of gum; -- called also gum tragacanth, or tragacanth. See Tragacanth.
darned: an intensifying expletive; a eupehmism for damned; as, for no darned reason at all.
darnel: Any grass of the genus Lolium, esp. the Lolium temulentum (bearded darnel), the grains of which have been reputed poisonous. Other species, as Lolium perenne (rye grass or ray grass), and its variety Lolium Italicum (Italian rye grass), are highly esteemed for pasture and for making hay.
Disjuncture: The act of disjoining, or state of being disjoined; separation.
Decharm: To free from a charm; to disenchant.
Darlingtonia: A genus of California pitcher plants consisting of a single species. The long tubular leaves are hooded at the top, and frequently contain many insects drowned in the secretion of the leaves.
Disentrance: To awaken from a trance or an enchantment.
Dagoba: A dome-shaped structure built over relics of Buddha or some Buddhist saint.
Dowser: A divining rod used in searching for water, ore, etc., a dowsing rod.
Distractible: Capable of being drawn aside or distracted.
discussant: a participant in a discussion, especially a member of a panel.
Derbio: A large European food fish (Lichia glauca).
Disrupt: Rent off; torn asunder; severed; disrupted.
Darkness: The absence of light; blackness; obscurity; gloom.
Doggish: Like a dog; having the bad qualities of a dog; churlish; growling; brutal.
damascened: decorated or inlaid with a wavy pattern of different (especially precious) metals; -- of metallic objects; as, a damascened sword.
Desynonymize: To deprive of synonymous character; to discriminate in use; -- applied to words which have been employed as synonyms.
Disillusionize: To disenchant; to free from illusion.
Demotic: Of or pertaining to the people; popular; common.
Debt: That which is due from one person to another, whether money, goods, or services; that which one person is bound to pay to another, or to perform for his benefit; thing owed; obligation; liability.
defroster: A device that removes ice or frost (as from a windshield or a refrigerator or the wings of an airplane).
Decorator: One who decorates, adorns, or embellishes; specifically, an artisan whose business is the decoration of houses, esp. their interior decoration.
D: The fourth letter of the English alphabet, and a vocal consonant. The English letter is from Latin, which is from Greek, which took it from Phœnician, the probable ultimate origin being Egyptian. It is related most nearly to t and th; as, Eng. deep, G. tief; Eng. daughter, G. tochter, Gr. qyga`thr, Skr. duhitr. See Guide to Pronunciation, √178, 179, 229.
Diabetic: Pertaining to diabetes; as, diabetic or diabetical treatment.
Deify: To make a god of; to exalt to the rank of a deity; to enroll among the deities; to apotheosize; as, Julius Cæsar was deified.
Dardanelles: the strait between the Aegean and the Sea of Marmara that separates European from Asian Turkey.
Disconnection: The act of disconnecting, or state of being disconnected; separation; want of union.
Discounter: One who discounts; a discount broker.
Damsel: A young person, either male or female, of noble or gentle extraction; as, Damsel Pepin; Damsel Richard, Prince of Wales.
Daviesia: a genus of Australasian shrubs and subshrubs having small yellow or purple flowers followed by short triangular pods.
damnum: Harm; detriment, either to character or property.
dashpot: a mechanical damping device containing a piston that moves in a fluid-filled chamber to serve as a pneumatic or hydraulic cushion for a falling weight, as in the valve gear of a steam engine, to prevent shock.
Delirament: A wandering of the mind; a crazy fancy.
Diagraph: A drawing instrument, combining a protractor and scale.
Dalbergia: a large genus of tropical trees having pinnate leaves and paniculate flowers and cultivated commercially for their dramatically grained and colored timbers.
Disavow: To refuse strongly and solemnly to own or acknowledge; to deny responsibility for, approbation of, and the like; to disclaim; to disown; as, he was charged with embezzlement, but he disavows the crime.
Divorcer: The person or cause that produces or effects a divorce.
deadly: In a manner resembling, or as if produced by, death; deathly.
Deposit: That which is deposited, or laid or thrown down; as, a deposit in a flue; especially, matter precipitated from a solution (as the siliceous deposits of hot springs), or that which is mechanically deposited (as the mud, gravel, etc., deposits of a river).
Domed: Furnished with a dome; shaped like a dome.
Deductible: Capable of being deducted, taken away, or withdrawn.
Dogcart: A light one-horse carriage, commonly two-wheeled, patterned after a cart. The original dogcarts used in England by sportsmen had a box at the back for carrying dogs.
dinner: The principal meal of the day, eaten in some countries about midday, but in others (especially in the U. S. and in large cities) at a later hour.
Ductility: The property of a metal which allows it to be drawn into wires or filaments.
Diaster: A double star; -- applied to the nucleus of a cell, when, during cell division, the loops of the nuclear network separate into two groups, preparatory to the formation of two daughter nuclei. See Karyokinesis.
Dynam: A unit of measure for dynamical effect or work; a foot pound. See Foot pound.
dreamworld: A pleasing country existing only in dreams or imagination; a fantasy land.
donated: given freely especially to a cause or fund; as, the donated van made their meal-on-wheels venture possible.
Disagreeableness: The state or quality of being; disagreeable; unpleasantness.
Dicentra: A genus of herbaceous plants, with racemes of two-spurred or heart-shaped flowers, including the Dutchman's breeches, and the more showy Bleeding heart (Dicentra spectabilis).
Drudgery: The act of drudging; disagreeable and wearisome labor; ignoble or slavish toil.
Decimal: A number expressed in the scale of tens; specifically, and almost exclusively, used as synonymous with a decimal fraction.
Deathful: Full of death or slaughter; murderous; destructive; bloody.
Decaliter: A measure of capacity in the metric system; a cubic volume of ten liters, equal to about 610.24 cubic inches, that is, 2.642 wine gallons.
Domestic: One who lives in the family of an other, as hired household assistant; a house servant.
Demicannon: A kind of ordnance, carrying a ball weighing from thirty to thirty-six pounds.
Demivill: A half vill, consisting of five freemen or frankpledges.
darky: a negro; an African-American; -- an older term now considered offensive.
Desmodus: the type genus of the Desmodontidae, consisting of vampire bats.
Deduplication: The division of that which is morphologically one organ into two or more, as the division of an organ of a plant into a pair or cluster.
decrypt: to convert from a coded form into the original; -- of communications.  Inverse of encrypt.
Detectable: Capable of being detected or found out; as, parties not detectable.
Dioxide: An oxide containing two atoms of oxygen in each molecule; binoxide.
Daintily: In a dainty manner; nicely; scrupulously; fastidiously; deliciously; prettily.
Daddock: The rotten body of a tree.
dioestrous: in a period of sexual inactivity; -- of animals that have several estrous cycles in one breeding season.
Divider: One who, or that which, divides; that which separates anything into parts.
Disfavor: To withhold or withdraw favor from; to regard with disesteem; to show disapprobation of; to discountenance.
Double: Twice as much; twice the number, sum, quantity, length, value, and the like.
Doubly: In twice the quantity; to twice the degree; as, doubly wise or good; to be doubly sensible of an obligation.
Ducal: Of or pertaining to a duke.
Distributary: Tending to distribute or be distributed; that distributes; distributive.
Dumal: Pertaining to, or set with, briers or bushes; brambly.
Drove: To drive, as cattle or sheep, esp. on long journeys; to follow the occupation of a drover.
Diphenyl: A white crystalline substance, C6H5.C6H5, obtained by leading benzene through a heated iron tube. It consists of two benzene or phenyl radicals united.
Dietetist: A physician who applies the rules of dietetics to the cure of diseases.
Decoct: To prepare by boiling; to digest in hot or boiling water; to extract the strength or flavor of by boiling; to make an infusion of.
Dad: Father; -- a word sometimes used by children.
Dab: A gentle blow with the hand or some soft substance; a sudden blow or hit; a peck.
Dal: Split pulse, esp. of Cajanus Indicus.
Dam: To obstruct or restrain the flow of, by a dam; to confine by constructing a dam, as a stream of water; -- generally used with in or up.
Dan: A small truck or sledge used in coal mines.
Dak: Post; mail; also, the mail or postal arrangements; -- spelt also dawk, and dauk.
Dap: To drop the bait gently on the surface of the water.
Disbar: To expel from the bar, or the legal profession; to deprive (an attorney, barrister, or counselor) of his status and privileges as such.
Dipyridyl: A crystalline nitrogenous base, C10H8N2, obtained by the reduction of pyridine.
Disconcertion: The act of disconcerting, or state of being disconcerted; discomposure; perturbation.
Diarrheal: Of or pertaining to diarrhea; like diarrhea.
Disheritance: The act of disinheriting or state of being disinherited; disinheritance.
Double-decker: A man-of-war having two gun decks.
Debate: A fight or fighting; contest; strife.
Doryphoros: A spear bearer; a statue of a man holding a spear or in the attitude of a spear bearer. Several important sculptures of this subject existed in antiquity, copies of which remain to us.
degrading: causing humiliation or degradation; as, a degrading surrender.
de-escalation: a reduction in intensity (of a crisis or a war).
Disembogue: To become discharged; to flow out; to find vent; to pour out contents.
dirigisme: The practice or inclination to direct (activities) by a central authority; as, the linguistic dirigisme of prescriptivists clashes with the modern tendency toward acceptance of multiculturalism.  See also dirigiste.
Detonation: An explosion or sudden report made by the instantaneous decomposition or combustion of unstable substances; as, the detonation of gun cotton.
Depurative: Purifying the blood or the humors; depuratory.
dayspring: The beginning of the day, or first appearance of light; the dawn; hence, the beginning.
Desideration: Act of desiderating; also, the thing desired.
Diathermanism: The doctrine or the phenomena of the transmission of radiant heat.
Duet: A composition for two performers, whether vocal or instrumental.
Diatryma: An extinct eocene bird from New Mexico, larger than the ostrich.
Drumlin: A hill of compact, unstratified, glacial drift or till, usually elongate or oval, with the larger axis parallel to the former local glacial motion.
Dichotomize: To separate into two parts; to branch dichotomously; to become dichotomous.
Dissected: Cut into several parts; divided into sections; as, a dissected map.
Darkly: With imperfect light, clearness, or knowledge; obscurely; dimly; blindly; uncertainly.
Darkle: To grow dark; to show indistinctly.
Diplostemonous: Having twice as many stamens as petals, as the geranium.
Dopant: a foreign substance added to a material to alter its properties; -- a process used. e.g., in making semiconductors from pure silicon in the manufacture of semiconductor chips and integrated circuits.
Disseizee: A person disseized, or put out of possession of an estate unlawfully; -- correlative to disseizor.
Diffluence: A flowing off on all sides; fluidity.
Delsarte: A system of calisthenics patterned on the theories of François Delsarte (1811 -- 71), a French teacher of dramatic and musical expression.
Diapensiales: an order of plants, used in some classifications as coextensive with the family Diapensiaceae.
disc jockey: a person who plays records or compact disks of recorded music;
Driftbolt: A bolt for driving out other bolts.
deservedly: According to desert (whether good or evil); justly.
dropper: One who, or that which, drops.
Duchesse lace: A beautiful variety of Brussels pillow lace made originally in Belgium and resembling Honiton guipure. It is worked with fine thread in large sprays, usually of the primrose pattern, with much raised work.
Dronepipe: One of the low-toned tubes of a bagpipe.
demagoguery: impassioned appeals to the prejudices and emotions of the populace.
dropped: born; -- used of an animal.  Opposite of  unborn.
Dictatorial: Pertaining or suited to a dictator; absolute.
decolonize: to release one's colonies and free them to become independednt nations; -- of nations.
Dionysia: Any of the festivals held in honor of the Olympian god Dionysus. They correspond to the Roman Bacchanalia; the greater Dionysia were held at Athens in March or April, and were celebrated with elaborate performances of both tragedies and comedies.
Dastardly: Meanly timid; cowardly; base; as, a dastardly outrage.
Demand: The act of demanding; an asking with authority; a peremptory urging of a claim; a claiming or challenging as due; requisition; as, the demand of a creditor; a note payable on demand.
Diopside: A crystallized variety of pyroxene, of a clear, grayish green color; mussite.
disheartening: Causing loss of hope or enthusiasm.
Dunner: One employed in soliciting the payment of debts.
Durian: The fruit of the durio.  It is oval or globular, and eight or ten inches long.  It has a hard prickly rind, containing a soft, cream-colored pulp, of a most delicious flavor and a very offensive odor.  The seeds are roasted and eaten like chestnuts.
Daman: A small herbivorous mammal of the genus Hyrax. The species found in Palestine and Syria is Hyrax Syriacus; that of Northern Africa is Hyrax Brucei; -- called also ashkoko, dassy, and rock rabbit. See Cony, and Hyrax.
Dermic: Relating to the derm or skin.
Dermis: The deep sensitive layer of the skin beneath the scarfskin or epidermis; -- called also true skin, derm, derma, corium, cutis, and enderon. See Skin, and Illust. in Appendix.
Ditty-box: A small box to hold a sailor's thread, needless, comb, etc.
Drumstick: A stick with which a drum is beaten.
duplex: something which is duplex; -- used mostly in reference to a living unit, such as an apartment, in a building having two similar living units.
Disastrous: Full of unpropitious stellar influences; unpropitious; ill-boding.
Dirige: A service for the dead, in the Roman Catholic Church, being the first antiphon of Matins for the dead, of which Dirige is the first word; a dirge.
Dumple: To make dumpy; to fold, or bend, as one part over another.
Diviner: One who professes divination; one who pretends to predict events, or to reveal occult things, by supernatural means.
Drabbet: A coarse linen fabric, or duck.
Didactic: A treatise on teaching or education.
Disparage: Inequality in marriage; marriage with an inferior.
Deprehensible: That may be caught or discovered; apprehensible.
Dirempt: To separate by force; to tear apart.
Dervish: A Turkish or Persian monk, especially one who professes extreme poverty and leads an austere life.
Disprove: To prove to be false or erroneous; to confute; to refute.
Demesnial: Of or pertaining to a demesne; of the nature of a demesne.
Ditheism: The doctrine of those who maintain the existence of two gods or of two original principles (as in Manicheism), one good and one evil; dualism.
Ditheist: One who holds the doctrine of ditheism; a dualist.
Dipolar: Having two poles, as a magnetic bar.
Debride: to remove (e. g., dead tissue) surgically from a wound.
Dufrenite: A mineral of a blackish green color, commonly massive or in nodules. It is a hydrous phosphate of iron.
Disfranchise: To deprive of a franchise or chartered right; to dispossess of the rights of a citizen, or of a particular privilege, as of voting, holding office, etc.
Deutzia: A genus of shrubs with pretty white flowers, much cultivated.
Despumate: To throw off impurities in spume; to work off in foam or scum; to foam.
Decorticate: To divest of the bark, husk, or exterior coating; to husk; to peel; to hull.
Dispeople: To deprive of inhabitants; to depopulate.
Drengage: The tenure by which a drench held land.
Defeasanced: Liable to defeasance; capable of being made void or forfeited.
Dianoetic: Pertaining to the discursive faculty, its acts or products.
Digestion: The act or process of digesting; reduction to order; classification; thoughtful consideration.
Disunion: The termination of union; separation; disjunction; as, the disunion of the body and the soul.
During: In the time of; as long as the action or existence of; as, during life; during the space of a year.
Discriminative: Marking a difference; distinguishing; distinctive; characteristic.
dybbuk: the wandering soul of a dead person, or a demon, that enters the body of a living person and controls that body's behavior.  It may be exorcised by religious rites.
Dorhawk: The European goatsucker; -- so called because it eats the dor beetle. See Goatsucker.
Defaulter: One who makes default; one who fails to appear in court when court when called.
Dyingness: The state of dying or the stimulation of such a state; extreme languor; languishment.
dinoflagellate: a member of the Dinoflagellata, chiefly marine protozoa having two flagella.  The dinoflagellates form a chief constituent of plankton.
Date: To have beginning; to begin; to be dated or reckoned; -- with from.
Depolishing: The process of removing the vitreous glaze from porcelain, leaving the dull luster of the surface of ivory porcelain.
Delphic: Of or relating to Delphi, or to the famous oracle of that place.
Dynamo-electric: Pertaining to the development of electricity, especially electrical currents, by power; producing electricity or electrical currents by mechanical power.
Delphin: A fatty substance contained in the oil of the dolphin and the porpoise; -- called also phocenin.
Deltidium: The triangular space under the beak of many brachiopod shells.
deceleration: a decrease in velocity.  Opposite of acceleration
defrock: To divest of the frock, i. e. to deprive (a priest, minister, etc.) of official ecclesiastical authority; -- of church officials.
dirt-cheap: costing much less than standard price; as, the store went out of business and sold their remaining stock for dirt-cheap prices.
Disburse: To pay out; to expend; -- usually from a public fund or treasury.
Disembowered: Deprived of, or removed from, a bower.
Deontology: The science which relates to duty or moral obligation.
Demonstration: The act of demonstrating; an exhibition; proof; especially, proof beyond the possibility of doubt; indubitable evidence, to the senses or reason.
Disacquaintance: Neglect of disuse of familiarity, or familiar acquaintance.
Decoction: The act or process of boiling anything in a watery fluid to extract its virtues.
dicarbonic: Containing two carbon residues, or two carboxyl groups or radicals; as, oxalic acid is the simplest dicarbonic acid.  In the latter sense, synonymous with dicarboxylic; as, succinic acid is a dicarboxylic acid.
Drymoglossum: a genus of epiphytic ferns of Madagascar to tropical Asia and New Guinea.
Derbyshire spar: A massive variety of fluor spar, found in Derbyshire, England, and wrought into vases and other ornamental work.
Diaphanie: The art of imitating stained glass with translucent paper.
Decorous: Suitable to a character, or to the time, place, and occasion; marked with decorum; becoming; proper; seemly; befitting; as, a decorous speech; decorous behavior; a decorous dress for a judge.
Drift: That causes drifting or that is drifted; movable by wind or currents; as, drift currents; drift ice; drift mud.
Diaphanic: Having power to transmit light; transparent; diaphanous.
Depasture: To pasture; to feed; to graze; also, to use for pasture.
Diarchy: A form of government in which the supreme power is vested in two persons.
Dido: A shrewd trick; an antic; a caper.
Dialyze: To separate, prepare, or obtain, by dialysis or osmose; to pass through an animal membrane; to subject to dialysis.
de-iodination: the removal of iodine atoms from organic compounds.
Dowable: Capable of being endowed; entitled to dower.
Dentilabial: Formed by the teeth and the lips, or representing a sound so formed.
Didrachm: A two-drachma piece; an ancient Greek silver coin, worth nearly forty cents.
Dovelike: Mild as a dove; gentle; pure and lovable.
Determinant: That which serves to determine; that which causes determination.
desex: to make infertile, especially by removing or incapacitating the sexual organs; -- used of both males and females.
Deliciate: To delight one's self; to indulge in feasting; to revel.
Double-surfaced: Having two surfaces; -- said specif. of aëroplane wings or aërocurves which are covered on both sides with fabric, etc., thus completely inclosing their frames.
Drunkenness: The state of being drunken with, or as with, alcoholic liquor; intoxication; inebriety; -- used of the casual state or the habit.
Delimitation: The act or process of fixing limits or boundaries; limitation.
Dimerous: Composed of, or having, two parts of each kind.
Dubbing: The act of dubbing, as a knight, etc.
Defraudation: The act of defrauding; a taking by fraud.
Dilettante: An admirer or lover of the fine arts; popularly, an amateur; especially, one who follows an art or a branch of knowledge, desultorily, or for amusement only.
Dedicatee: One to whom a thing is dedicated; -- correlative to dedicator.
Dipsomania: A morbid an uncontrollable craving (often periodic) for drink, esp. for alcoholic liquors; also improperly used to denote acute and chronic alcoholism.
desalinization: the removal of salt (especially from sea water); the act or process of desalinating.
disarranged: having the arrangement disturbed; not put in order; as, her disarranged hair.  Opposite of arranged.
Destructible: Liable to destruction; capable of being destroyed.
Dextrally: Towards the right; as, the hands of a watch rotate dextrally.
Displace: To change the place of; to remove from the usual or proper place; to put out of place; to place in another situation; as, the books in the library are all displaced.
Demisemiquaver: A short note, equal in time to the half of a semiquaver, or the thirty-second part of a whole note.
Dunnock: The hedge sparrow or hedge accentor.
Dictatorship: The office, or the term of office, of a dictator; hence, absolute power.
Debark: To go ashore from a ship or boat; to disembark; to put ashore.
Divest: To unclothe; to strip, as of clothes, arms, or equipage; -- opposed to invest.
Disincline: To incline away the affections of; to excite a slight aversion in; to indispose; to make unwilling; to alienate.
Delibration: The act of stripping off the bark.
Deperdit: That which is lost or destroyed.
Delamination: Formation and separation of laminæ or layers; one of the methods by which the various blastodermic layers of the ovum are differentiated.
deportee: a person who was expelled from home or country by governmental authority; one who has been deported.
Doorplane: A plane on a door, giving the name, and sometimes the employment, of the occupant.
Decline: A falling off; a tendency to a worse state; diminution or decay; deterioration; also, the period when a thing is tending toward extinction or a less perfect state; as, the decline of life; the decline of strength; the decline of virtue and religion.
Disconsolate: Destitute of consolation; deeply dejected and dispirited; hopelessly sad; comfortless; filled with grief; as, a bereaved and disconsolate parent.
Dimple: To mark with dimples or dimplelike depressions.
Decision: Cutting off; division; detachment of a part.
Denali: The native name for Mount McKinley in Alaska, translated as the great one.
Dimply: Full of dimples, or small depressions; dimpled; as, the dimply pool.
Dodipate: A stupid person; a fool; a blockhead.
Distensible: Capable of being distended or dilated.
Doornail: The nail or knob on which in ancient doors the knocker struck; -- hence the old saying, “As dead as a doornail.”
Delaine: A kind of fabric for women's dresses.
Deesis: An invocation of, or address to, the Supreme Being.
Darkener: One who, or that which, darkens.
downwind: on the side or in the direction away from the direction from which the wind is blowing; in the direction toward which the wind is blowing; as, good hunters stay downwind of their prey.  Opposite of upwind, and windward.
Deodar: A kind of cedar (Cedrus Deodara), growing in India, highly valued for its size and beauty as well as for its timber, and also grown in England as an ornamental tree.
Dilatometer: An instrument for measuring the dilatation or expansion of a substance, especially of a fluid.
Delirium: A state in which the thoughts, expressions, and actions are wild, irregular, and incoherent; mental aberration; a roving or wandering of the mind, -- usually dependent on a fever or some other disease, and so distinguished from mania, or madness.
Divide: A dividing ridge of land between the tributaries of two streams; also called watershed and water parting.  A divide on either side of which the waters drain into two different oceans is called a continental divide.
Ducks-bill: Having the form of a duck's bill.
Drawcansir: A blustering, bullying fellow; a pot-valiant braggart; a bully.
Dispel: To drive away by scattering, or so to cause to vanish; to clear away; to banish; to dissipate; as, to dispel a cloud, vapors, cares, doubts, illusions.
Dezincification: The act or process of freeing from zinc; also, the condition resulting from the removal of zinc.
Delectus: A name given to an elementary book for learners of Latin or Greek.
Dry goods: A commercial name for textile fabrics, cottons, woolens, linen, silks, laces, etc., -- in distinction from groceries.
Dionysiac: Of or pertaining to Dionysus or to the Dionysia; Bacchic; as, a Dionysiac festival; the Dionysiac theater at Athens.
Dionysian: Relating to Dionysius, a monk of the 6th century; as, the Dionysian, or Christian, era.
Downgyved: Hanging down like gyves or fetters.
Division: The act or process of diving anything into parts, or the state of being so divided; separation.
Deliberatively: In a deliberative manner; circumspectly; considerately.
disposable income: that portion of income which is available for spending on discretionary purchases; for individuals, it is usually calculated as total income less taxes.  National disposable income, which is the disposable income of all individuals and businesses, is calculated as total national income minus taxes plus transfer payments.
Dynamometry: The art or process of measuring forces doing work.
Deceiver: One who deceives; one who leads into error; a cheat; an impostor.
Dread: Exciting great fear or apprehension; causing terror; frightful; dreadful.
daiquiri: an alcoholic beverage containing rum and lime or lemon juice, usually mixed with a fruit juice or fruit extract and often blended with crushed ice; as, a strawberry daiquiri.
Disfellowship: To exclude from fellowship; to refuse intercourse with, as an associate.
Dream: To have a dream of; to see, or have a vision of, in sleep, or in idle fancy; -- often followed by an objective clause.
Dynamics: That branch of mechanics which treats of the motion of bodies (Kinematics) and the action of forces in producing or changing their motion (kinetics). Dynamics is held by some recent writers to include statics and not kinematics.
Drunken: Overcome by strong drink; intoxicated by, or as by, spirituous liquor; inebriated.
Downstroke: A stroke made with a downward motion of the pen or pencil.
Dutiable: Subject to the payment of a duty; as dutiable goods.
dingdong: The sound of, or as of, repeated strokes on a metallic body, as a bell; a repeated and monotonous sound.
Diversifiability: The quality or capacity of being diversifiable.
dauntless: Incapable of being daunted; undaunted; bold; fearless; intrepid.
Dematerialize: To deprive of material or physical qualities or characteristics.
Dome: Decision; judgment; opinion; a court decision.
Diacoustic: Pertaining to the science or doctrine of refracted sounds.
Doorga: A Hindoo divinity, the consort of Siva, represented with ten arms.
decompression: the process of experiencing decompression; the act or process of relieving or reducing pressure.
Destructiveness: The quality of destroying or ruining.
Disrobe: To divest of a robe; to undress; figuratively, to strip of covering; to divest of that which clothes or decorates; as, autumn disrobes the fields of verdure.
Debuscope: A modification of the kaleidoscope; -- used to reflect images so as to form beautiful designs.
Djereed: A blunt javelin used in military games in Moslem countries.
Deserving: Meritorious; worthy; as, a deserving person or act.
Diatomous: Having a single, distinct, diagonal cleavage; -- said of crystals.
Diplocardiac: Having the heart completely divided or double, one side systemic, the other pulmonary.
Daphnia: A genus of the genus Daphnia.
Dezincify: To deprive of, or free from, zinc.
double cross: teh act of double-crossing; the betrayal or swindling of a collaborator or colleague.
Daphnin: A dark green bitter resin extracted from the mezereon (Daphne mezereum) and regarded as the essential principle of the plant.
Decameron: A celebrated collection of tales, supposed to be related in ten days; -- written in the 14th century, by Boccaccio, an Italian.
Davyum: A rare metallic element found in platinum ore. It is a white malleable substance. Symbol Da. Atomic weight 154.
Dactyloscopidae: a natural family of Atlantic fishes comprising the sand stargazers.
Destroy: To unbuild; to pull or tear down; to separate virulently into its constituent parts; to break up the structure and organic existence of; to demolish.
Dashy: Calculated to arrest attention; ostentatiously fashionable; showy.
Danish: Belonging to the Danes, or to their language or country.
Dinocerata: a small order of primitive ungulates of the Paleocene and Eocene.
Deedless: Not performing, or not having performed, deeds or exploits; inactive.
divvy: divide up among a group; distribute; -- often followed by up; as, divvy up the proceeds; divvy up the loot.
defenceless: same as defenseless; as, a defenceless child.
Drunkenship: The state of being drunk; drunkenness.
Downthrow: The sudden drop or depression of the strata of rocks on one side of a fault. See Throw, n.
Disconformity: Want of conformity or correspondence; inconsistency; disagreement.
Despise: To look down upon with disfavor or contempt; to contemn; to scorn; to disdain; to have a low opinion or contemptuous dislike of.
Discourser: One who discourse; a narrator; a speaker; an haranguer.
Diphyozooid: One of the free-swimming sexual zooids of Siphonophora.
Dramshop: A shop or barroom where spirits are sold by the dram.
Dispensation: The act of dispensing or dealing out; distribution; often used of the distribution of good and evil by God to man, or more generically, of the acts and modes of his administration.
Double-breasted: Folding or lapping over on the breast, with a row of buttons and buttonholes on each side; as, a double-breasted coat.
Dairy: The place, room, or house where milk is kept, and converted into butter or cheese.
Distrainable: Capable of being, or liable to be, distrained.
Discount: A counting off or deduction made from a gross sum on any account whatever; an allowance upon an account, debt, demand, price asked, and the like; something taken or deducted.
Disagree: To fail to accord; not to agree; to lack harmony; to differ; to be unlike; to be at variance.
Deuteropathia: A sympathetic affection of any part of the body, as headache from an overloaded stomach.
Deuteropathic: Pertaining to deuteropathy; of the nature of deuteropathy.
dislocated: separated at the joint; -- used especially of limbs; as, a dislocated knee.
Delinquently: So as to fail in duty.
Diathermometer: An instrument for examining the thermal resistance or heat-conducting power of liquids.
Dishful: As much as a dish holds when full.
Dolichocephaly: The quality or condition of being dolichocephalic.
Diopter: An optical instrument, invented by Hipparchus, for taking altitudes, leveling, etc.
Dephlegmator: An instrument or apparatus in which water is separated by evaporation or distillation; the part of a distilling apparatus in which the separation of the vapors is effected.
Dismember: To tear limb from limb; to dilacerate; to disjoin member from member; to tear or cut in pieces; to break up.
Denizen: To constitute (one) a denizen; to admit to residence, with certain rights and privileges.
Desecrate: To divest of a sacred character or office; to divert from a sacred purpose; to violate the sanctity of; to profane; to put to an unworthy use; -- the opposite of consecrate.
Deliverer: One who delivers or rescues; a preserver.
deserve: To be worthy of recompense; -- usually with ill or with well.
disseminative: Tending to disseminate, or to become disseminated.
Dart: To fly or pass swiftly, as a dart.
Darg: A day's work; also, a fixed amount of work, whether more or less than that of a day.
deviation: The act of deviating; a wandering from the way; variation from the common way, from an established rule, etc.; departure, as from the right course or the path of duty.
Dunfish: Codfish cured in a particular manner, so as to be of a superior quality.
Dispathy: Lack of sympathy; want of passion; apathy.
Dipnoi: A group of ganoid fishes, including the living genera Ceratodus and Lepidosiren, which present the closest approximation to the Amphibia. The air bladder acts as a lung, and the nostrils open inside the mouth. See Ceratodus, and Illustration in Appendix.
Disaffect: To alienate or diminish the affection of; to make unfriendly or less friendly; to fill with discontent and unfriendliness.
Distain: To tinge with a different color from the natural or proper one; to stain; to discolor; to sully; to tarnish; to defile; -- used chiefly in poetry.
Disafforest: To reduce from the privileges of a forest to the state of common ground; to exempt from forest laws.
Drofland: An ancient yearly payment made by some tenants to the king, or to their landlords, for the privilege of driving their cattle through a manor to fairs or markets.
Declivity: Deviation from a horizontal line; gradual descent of surface; inclination downward; slope; -- opposed to acclivity, or ascent; the same slope, considered as descending, being a declivity, which, considered as ascending, is an acclivity.
Disoxygenate: To deprive of oxygen; to deoxidize.
Debit card: a small usually plastic card with a magnetic coded number, similar to a credit card, which is used to pay for purchases by the electronic deduction of a sum of money (a debit) directly from the card-holder's bank account.  Such cards do not require the establishment of a credit line, and such transactions do not incur any interest payments.
Disputation: The act of disputing; a reasoning or argumentation in opposition to something, or on opposite sides; controversy in words; verbal contest respecting the truth of some fact, opinion, proposition, or argument.
Decrement: The state of becoming gradually less; decrease; diminution; waste; loss.
Disputable: Capable of being disputed; liable to be called in question, controverted, or contested; or doubtful certainty or propriety; controvertible; as, disputable opinions, propositions, points, or questions.
disa: any orchid of the genus Disa, a genus of beautiful orchids with dark green leaves and usually hooded flowers; -- they are much prized as emblematic flowers in their native regions.
Deltaic: Relating to, or like, a delta.
Disembrangle: To free from wrangling or litigation.
Disfeature: To deprive of features; to mar the features of.
Denominationally: In a denominational manner; by denomination or sect.
Diapensiaceae: a natural family of northern temperate low evergreen plants; in some classifications placed in its own order Diapensiales.
Duumviral: Of or belonging to the duumviri or the duumvirate.
drypis: a spiny-leaved perennial herb of southern Europe having terminal clusters of small flowers.
Doleritic: Of the nature of dolerite; as, much lava is doleritic lava.
Durene: A colorless, crystalline, aromatic hydrocarbon, C6H2(CH3)4, off artificial production, with an odor like camphor.
dis-: A prefix from the Latin, whence F. dés, or sometimes dé-, dis-. The Latin dis-appears as di-before b, d, g, l, m, n, r, v, becomes dif-before f, and either dis-or di- before j. It is from the same root as bis twice, and duo, E. two. See Two, and cf. Bi-, Di-, Dia-. Dis- denotes separation, a parting from, as in distribute, disconnect; hence it often has the force of a privative and negative, as in disarm, disoblige, disagree. Also intensive, as in dissever.
Deconcentrate: To withdraw from concentration; to decentralize.
Diameter: Any right line passing through the center of a figure or body, as a circle, conic section, sphere, cube, etc., and terminated by the opposite boundaries; a straight line which bisects a system of parallel chords drawn in a curve.
Dickey: A false detachable shirt front or bosom.
Dicker: To negotiate a dicker; to barter.
Disprofess: To renounce the profession or pursuit of.
Dupery: The act or practice of duping.
Dicynodont: One of a group of extinct reptiles having the jaws armed with a horny beak, as in turtles, and in the genus Dicynodon, supporting also a pair of powerful tusks. Their remains are found in triassic strata of South Africa and India.
Disconnect: To dissolve the union or connection of; to disunite; to sever; to separate; to disperse.
Dilapidated: Decayed; fallen into partial ruin; injured by bad usage or neglect.
Discourse: To treat of; to expose or set forth in language.
Definitive: A word used to define or limit the extent of the signification of a common noun, such as the definite article, and some pronouns.
Dabchick: A small water bird (Podilymbus podiceps), allied to the grebes, remarkable for its quickness in diving; -- called also dapchick, dobchick, dipchick, didapper, dobber, devil-diver, hell-diver, and pied-billed grebe.
desegregate: to eliminate laws, regulations, or customs which prohibit members of a specific racial or national group from using (certain locations, organizations, or facilities); to introduce members of a racial or religious group into (a community, facility, or organization from which they had been barred).
Dally: To delay unnecessarily; to while away.
Drynurse: To feed, attend, and bring up without breastfeeding it.
Disshadow: To free from shadow or shade.
Deuterogamist: One who marries the second time.
Drama: A composition, in prose or poetry, accommodated to action, and intended to exhibit a picture of human life, or to depict a series of grave or humorous actions of more than ordinary interest, tending toward some striking result. It is commonly designed to be spoken and represented by actors on the stage.
Deflexure: A bending or turning aside; deflection.
dibstone: A pebble used in a child's game called dibstones.
Demit: The act of demitting; also, a letter, certificate, or the like, certifying that a person has (honorably) demitted, as from a Masonic lodge.
Disappendency: A detachment or separation from a former connection.
Desolation: The act of desolating or laying waste; destruction of inhabitants; depopulation.
Defiler: One who defiles; one who corrupts or violates; that which pollutes.
Demonize: To convert into a demon; to infuse the principles or fury of a demon into.
Duoliteral: Consisting of two letters only; biliteral.
Doublure: The lining of a book cover, esp. one of unusual sort, as of tooled leather, painted vellum, rich brocade, or the like.
Dion\u00e6a: An insectivorous plant. See Venus's flytrap.
Dodded: Without horns; as, dodded cattle; without beards; as, dodded corn.
Docet\u00e6: Ancient heretics who held that Christ's body was merely a phantom or appearance.
Decurion: A head or chief over ten; especially, an officer who commanded a division of ten soldiers.
dissatisfied: in a state of sulky dissatisfaction.
Doctorly: Like a doctor or learned man.
Disrepair: A state of being in bad condition, and needing repair.
Disgraduate: To degrade; to reduce in rank.
Deliquescence: The act of deliquescing or liquefying; process by which anything deliquesces; tendency to melt.
deconstructionist: Of or pertaining to deconstruction or deconstructionism; as, deconstructionist criticism.
Dyer: One whose occupation is to dye cloth and the like.
Daintiness: The quality of being dainty; nicety; niceness; elegance; delicacy; deliciousness; fastidiousness; squeamishness.
dickeybird: Any small bird; as, adults talking to children sometimes call small birds dickeybirds.
Dubious: Doubtful or not settled in opinion; being in doubt; wavering or fluctuating; undetermined.
Day: The time of light, or interval between one night and the next; the time between sunrise and sunset, or from dawn to darkness; hence, the light; sunshine; -- also called daytime.
dump truck: a truck, usually with an open top, the carrying bopdy of which can be tilted so as to emptied its contents without handling.
Different: Distinct; separate; not the same; other.
Deportation: The act of deporting or exiling, or the state of being deported; banishment; transportation.
Duffel: A kind of coarse woolen cloth, having a thick nap or frieze.
defensative: That which serves to protect or defend.
Dotation: The act of endowing, or bestowing a marriage portion on a woman.
Dispeopler: One who, or that which, dispeoples; a depopulator.
Dornick: A coarse sort of damask, originally made at Tournay (in Flemish, Doornick), Belgium, and used for hangings, carpets, etc. Also, a stout figured linen manufactured in Scotland.
Detachment: The act of detaching or separating, or the state of being detached.
Discerptive: Tending to separate or disunite parts.
Desire: The natural longing that is excited by the enjoyment or the thought of any good, and impels to action or effort its continuance or possession; an eager wish to obtain or enjoy.
Deodorize: To deprive of odor, especially of such as results from impurities.
Dissembler: One who dissembles; one who conceals his opinions or dispositions under a false appearance; a hypocrite.
Declamation: The act or art of declaiming; rhetorical delivery; haranguing; loud speaking in public; especially, the public recitation of speeches as an exercise in schools and colleges; as, the practice declamation by students.
Dreamland: An unreal, delightful country such as in sometimes pictured in dreams; region of fancies; fairyland.
Deambulatory: A covered place in which to walk; an ambulatory.
Dissolution: The act of dissolving, sundering, or separating into component parts; separation.
Double-quick: To move, or cause to move, in double-quick time.
developed: being changed over time so as to be e.g. stronger or more complete or more useful; as, the developed qualities of the Hellenic outlook; the state's well-developed industries.  Oppositre of undeveloped.
Dukhobors: A Russian religious sect founded about the middle of the 18th century at Kharkov. They believe that Christ was wholly human, but that his soul reappears from time to time in mortals. They accept the Ten Commandments and the “useful” portions of the Bible, but deny the need of rulers, priests, or churches, and have no confessions, icons, or marriage ceremonies. They are communistic, opposed to any violence, and unwilling to use the labor of animals. Driven out of Russia proper, many have emigrated to Cyprus and Canada. See Raskolnik, below.
Detour: A turning; a circuitous route; a deviation from a direct course; as, the detours of the Mississippi.
disabled: injured so as to be unable to function; as, disabled veterans.
Dioptrics: The science of the refraction of light; that part of geometrical optics which treats of the laws of the refraction of light in passing from one medium into another, or through different mediums, as air, water, or glass, and esp. through different lenses; -- distinguished from catoptrics, which refers to reflected light.
Decarbonizer: He who, or that which, decarbonizes a substance.
Devil-diver: A small water bird. See Dabchick.
Disappearance: The act of disappearing; cessation of appearance; removal from sight; vanishing.
Dental: An articulation or letter formed by the aid of the teeth.
Diamond State: Delaware; -- a nickname alluding to its small size.
Dominical: The Lord's day or Sunday; also, the Lord's prayer.
Disseizin: The act of disseizing; an unlawful dispossessing and ouster of a person actually seized of the freehold.
Damning: That damns; damnable; as, damning evidence of guilt.
Dispenser: One who, or that which, dispenses; a distributer; as, a dispenser of favors.
dark-haired: same as brunet; as, a dark-haired beauty.
Deliberateness: The quality of being deliberate; calm consideration; circumspection.
Dimorphism: Difference of form between members of the same species, as when a plant has two kinds of flowers, both hermaphrodite (as in the partridge berry), or when there are two forms of one or both sexes of the same species of butterfly.
Dorse: The Baltic or variable cod (Gadus callarias), by some believed to be the young of the common codfish.
Discapacitate: To deprive of capacity; to incapacitate.
Donor: One who gives or bestows; one who confers anything gratuitously; a benefactor.  Inverse of recipient.
Doubling: The act of one that doubles; a making double; reduplication; also, that which is doubled.
Distracter: One who, or that which, distracts away.
Dignified: Marked with dignity; stately; as, a dignified judge.
Door: An opening in the wall of a house or of an apartment, by which to go in and out; an entrance way.
Distinguish: To make distinctions; to perceive the difference; to exercise discrimination; -- with between; as, a judge distinguishes between cases apparently similar, but differing in principle.
Doom: To judge; to estimate or determine as a judge.
Deciare: A measure of area, the tenth part of an are; ten square meters.
Diatonic: Pertaining to the scale of eight tones, the eighth of which is the octave of the first.
Despend: To spend; to squander. See Dispend.
dipstick: a graduated rod dipped into a container to indicate the fluid level; as, to check the oil level in a car with a dipstick.
dexamethasone: a corticosteroid drug used to treat allergies or inflammation.
disqualify: To deprive of the qualities or properties necessary for any purpose; to render unfit; to incapacitate; -- with for or from before the purpose, state, or act.
Diaphane: A woven silk stuff with transparent and colored figures; diaper work.
Disgregate: To disperse; to scatter; -- opposite of congregate.
Dumdum bullet: A kind of man-stopping bullet, designed to fragment inside the body and thus inflict a severed and painful wound; -- so named from Dumdum, in India, where bullets are manufactured for the Indian army.
Dotted: Marked with, or made of, dots or small spots; diversified with small, detached objects.
Dithecal: Having two thecæ, cells, or compartments.
dink: an Asian person, especially a Vietnamese; -- used contemptuously, considered disparaging and offensive.
Demephitize: To purify from mephitic or foul air.
Disenchant: To free from enchantment; to deliver from the power of charms or spells.
densitometry: measuring the optical density of a substance by shining light through it and measuring the intensity of the transmitted light.
Donjon: The chief tower, also called the keep; a massive tower in ancient castles, forming the strongest part of the fortifications. See Illust. of Castle.
double-dealing: given to deception especially by pretending one set of feelings and acting under the influence of another; as, they accused each other of double-dealing behavior.
Distillate: The product of distillation; as, the distillate from molasses.
disklike: resembling a disk in shape; circular and having a height considerably smaller than the diameter.
Dictionary: A book containing the words of a language, arranged alphabetically, with explanations of their meanings; a lexicon; a vocabulary; a wordbook.
dayboy: a day boarder who is a boy.
Dress coat: A coat with skirts behind only, as distinct from the frock coat, of which the skirts surround the body. It is worn on occasions of ceremony. The dress coat of officers of the United States army is a full-skirted frock coat.
Duodenary: Containing twelve; twelvefold; increasing by twelves; duodecimal.
Demise: To transfer or transmit by succession or inheritance; to grant or bestow by will; to bequeath.
Dispatchful: Bent on haste; intent on speedy execution of business or any task; indicating haste; quick; as, dispatchful looks.
Diadem: To adorn with a diadem; to crown.
Diclinous: Having the stamens and pistils in separate flowers.
Diaheliotropism: A tendency of leaves or other organs of plants to have their dorsal surface faced towards the rays of light.
Disempower: To deprive of power; to divest of strength.
Diapnoic: Slightly increasing an insensible perspiration; mildly diaphoretic.
dispensed: distributed or weighed out in carefully determined portions; as, medicines dispensed to the sick.
Deaconship: The office or ministry of a deacon or deaconess.
Diogenes: A Greek Cynic philosopher (412?-323 B. C.) who lived much in Athens and was distinguished for contempt of the common aims and conditions of life, and for sharp, caustic sayings.
Domicile: To establish in a fixed residence, or a residence that constitutes habitancy; to domiciliate.
Dichroism: The property of presenting different colors by transmitted light, when viewed in two different directions, the colors being unlike in the direction of unlike or unequal axes.
depleted: no longer sufficient; as, our funds are depleted.
Dialectal: Relating to a dialect; dialectical; as, a dialectical variant.
Duodecimo: A book consisting of sheets each of which is folded into twelve leaves; hence, indicating, more or less definitely, a size of a book; -- usually written 12mo or 12°.
Decency: The quality or state of being decent, suitable, or becoming, in words or behavior; propriety of form in social intercourse, in actions, or in discourse; proper formality; becoming ceremony; seemliness; hence, freedom from obscenity or indecorum; modesty.
Downiness: The quality or state of being downy.
Downlooked: Having a downcast countenance; dejected; gloomy; sullen.
Difference: To cause to differ; to make different; to mark as different; to distinguish.
Depth: The quality of being deep; deepness; perpendicular measurement downward from the surface, or horizontal measurement backward from the front; as, the depth of a river; the depth of a body of troops.
Diagnosis: The art or act of recognizing the presence of disease from its signs or symptoms, and deciding as to its character; also, the decision arrived at.
Degustation: Tasting; the appreciation of sapid qualities by the taste organs.
Deadness: The state of being destitute of life, vigor, spirit, activity, etc.; dullness; inertness; languor; coldness; vapidness; indifference; as, the deadness of a limb, a body, or a tree; the deadness of an eye; deadness of the affections; the deadness of beer or cider; deadness to the world, and the like.
Donable: Capable of being donated or given.
Dropsy: An unnatural collection of serous fluid in any serous cavity of the body, or in the subcutaneous cellular tissue.
Discord: To disagree; to be discordant; to jar; to clash; not to suit.
Damson: A small oval plum of a blue color, the fruit of a variety of the Prunus domestica; -- called also damask plum.
dissolved: changed from a solid to a liquid state by increase of temperature; melted.  Opposite of unmelted.
Desistance: The act or state of desisting; cessation.
doorstop: The block or strip of wood or similar material which stops, at the right place, the shutting of a door; any object used to stop open doors from moving.
Demission: The act of demitting, or the state of being demitted; a letting down; a lowering; dejection.
Dodecagynian: Of or pertaining to the Dodecagynia; having twelve styles.
Dartle: To pierce or shoot through; to dart repeatedly: -- frequentative of dart.
Disembody: To divest of the body or corporeal existence.
Duckbill: See Duck mole, under Duck, n.
Dry nurse: A nurse who attends and feeds a child by hand; -- in distinction from a wet nurse, who suckles it.
Displat: To untwist; to uncurl; to unplat.
Dentaria: a genus usually included in genus Cardamine; in some classifications considered a separate genus.
dissimulating: concealing under a false appearance with the intent to deceive.
Deaden: To make as dead; to impair in vigor, force, activity, or sensation; to lessen the force or acuteness of; to blunt; as, to deaden the natural powers or feelings; to deaden a sound.
Display: An opening or unfolding; exhibition; manifestation.
Damnific: Procuring or causing loss; mischievous; injurious.
Digger: One who, or that which, digs.
Dishonorary: Bringing dishonor on; tending to disgrace; lessening reputation.
Diabolo: An old game or sport (revived under this name) consisting in whirling on a string, fastened to two sticks, a small somewhat spool-shaped object (called the diabolo) so as to balance it on a string, toss it in the air and catch it, etc.
Dunbird: The pochard; -- called also dunair, and dunker, or dun-curre.
Delphinine: A poisonous alkaloid extracted from the stavesacre (Delphinium staphisagria), as a colorless amorphous powder.
Dormitory: A sleeping room, or a building containing a series of sleeping rooms; a sleeping apartment capable of containing many beds; esp., one connected with a college or boarding school.
D\u00e9culassement: An accidental blowing off of, or other serious damage to, the breechblock of a gun; also, a removal of the breechblock for the purpose of disabling the gun.
Defeudalize: To deprive of the feudal character or form.
D\u00e9blai: The cavity from which the earth for parapets, etc. (remblai), is taken.
Domination: The act of dominating; exercise of power in ruling; dominion; supremacy; authority; often, arbitrary or insolent sway.
Disburgeon: To strip of burgeons or buds; to disbud.
Dostoevskian: of or pertaining to Fyodor Dostoevski.
Dearth: Scarcity which renders dear; want; lack; specifically, lack of food on account of failure of crops; famine.
Deictic: Direct; proving directly; -- applied to reasoning, and opposed to elenchtic or refutative.
Dishonor: To deprive of honor; to disgrace; to bring reproach or shame on; to treat with indignity, or as unworthy in the sight of others; to stain the character of; to lessen the reputation of; as, the duelist dishonors himself to maintain his honor.
Doctoral: Of or relating to a doctor, or to the degree of doctor.
Dandyling: A little or insignificant dandy; a contemptible fop.
Disculpate: To free from blame or the imputation of a fault; to exculpate.
Drudge: One who drudges; one who works hard in servile employment; a mental servant.
deprecatory: Tending to remove or avert evil by prayer; apologetic.
Difficulty: The state of being difficult, or hard to do; hardness; arduousness; -- opposed to easiness or facility; as, the difficulty of a task or enterprise; a work of difficulty.
Dead-hearted: Having a dull, faint heart; spiritless; listless.
Dinaphthyl: A colorless, crystalline hydrocarbon, C20H14, obtained from naphthylene, and consisting of a doubled naphthylene radical.
Dissemblance: The act or art of dissembling; dissimulation.
deice: to remove ice or frost from.
Diversifiable: Capable of being diversified or varied.
Decimate: To take the tenth part of; to tithe.
Disregard: The act of disregarding, or the state of being disregarded; intentional neglect; omission of notice; want of attention; slight.
Doctrinaire: One who would apply to political or other practical concerns the abstract doctrines or the theories of his own philosophical system; a propounder of a new set of opinions; a dogmatic theorist. Used also adjectively; as, doctrinaire notions.
Dropt: imp. & p. p. of Drop, v.
Differentiator: One who, or that which, differentiates.
Diffusible: Capable of flowing or spreading in all directions; that may be diffused.
Demon: A spirit, or immaterial being, holding a middle place between men and deities in pagan mythology.
Dispansion: Act of dispanding, or state of being dispanded.
Dreadful: Full of dread or terror; fearful.
Date line: The hypothetical line on the surface of the earth fixed by international or general agreement as a boundary on one side of which the same day shall have a different name and date in the calendar from its name and date on the other side.  Also called International Date Line.
Disinterment: The act of disinterring, or taking out of the earth; exhumation.
Diamylene: A liquid hydrocarbon, C10H20, of the ethylene series, regarded as a polymeric form of amylene.
Dropwort: An Old World species of Spiræa (Spiræa filipendula), with finely cut leaves.
Dropworm: The larva of any geometrid moth, which drops from trees by means of a thread of silk, as the cankerworm or inchworm.  See inchworm and geometrid.
Double-barreled: Having two barrels; -- applied to a gun.
Deflagrability: The state or quality of being deflagrable.
Dyewood: Any wood from which coloring matter is extracted for dyeing.
Driftwood: Wood drifted or floated by water.
Disorganizer: One who disorganizes or causes disorder and confusion.
Disunionist: An advocate of disunion, specifically, of disunion of the United States.
Downcomer: A pipe to conduct something downwards;
Describe: To use the faculty of describing; to give a description; as, Milton describes with uncommon force and beauty.
Dowagerism: The rank or condition of a dowager; formality, as that of a dowager. Also used figuratively.
Decemvirate: The office or term of office of the decemvirs in Rome.
Distend: To become expanded or inflated; to swell.
Deerstalking: The hunting of deer on foot, by stealing upon them unawares.
Drying: Adapted or tending to exhaust moisture; as, a drying wind or day; a drying room.
Druid: One of an order of priests which in ancient times existed among certain branches of the Celtic race, especially among the Gauls and Britons.
Diversified: Distinguished by various forms, or by a variety of aspects or objects; variegated; as, diversified scenery or landscape.
Diversifier: One who, or that which, diversifies.
Driftpin: A smooth drift. See Drift, n., 9.
doorbell: a bell or other sounding device, actuated by a push button at an outer door; the push button activating the bell; alos, the ringing of such a bell; as, I was in the shower and didn't hear the doorbell.
Durra: A kind of millet, cultivated throughout Asia, and introduced into the south of Europe; a variety of Sorghum vulgare; -- called also Indian millet, and Guinea corn.
Diaspora: Lit., “Dispersion.” -- applied collectively: (a) To those Jews who, after the Exile, were scattered through the Old World, and afterwards to Jewish Christians living among heathen. Cf. James i. 1. (b) By extension, to Christians isolated from their own communion, as among the Moravians to those living, usually as missionaries, outside of the parent congregation.
Definitely: In a definite manner; with precision; precisely; determinately.
Diaspore: A hydrate of alumina, often occurring in white lamellar masses with brilliant pearly luster; -- so named on account of its decrepitating when heated before the blowpipe.
Deceptiveness: The power or habit of deceiving; tendency or aptness to deceive.
Dimplement: The state of being dimpled, or marked with gentle depressions.
distrust: Doubt of sufficiency, reality, or sincerity; lack of confidence, faith, or reliance; as, distrust of one's power, authority, will, purposes, schemes, etc.
Deltafication: The formation of a delta or of deltas.
Dramseller: One who sells distilled liquors by the dram or glass.
differentia: The formal or distinguishing part of the essence of a species, by which it is distinguished from other members of its genus; the characteristic attribute of a species; specific difference; as, a proper definition must have both genus and differentia.
Dermatogen: Nascent epidermis, or external cuticle of plants in a forming condition.
Downpour: A pouring or streaming downwards; esp., a heavy or continuous shower.
Devenustate: To deprive of beauty or grace.
Discommission: To deprive of a commission or trust.
Displenish: To deprive or strip, as a house of furniture, or a barn of stock.
Di\u0153cia: A Linnæan class of plants having the stamens and pistils on different plants.
Dhole: A fierce, wild dog (Canis Dukhunensis), found in the mountains of India. It is remarkable for its propensity to hunt the tiger and other wild animals in packs.
Distemperature: Bad temperature; intemperateness; excess of heat or cold, or of other qualities; as, the distemperature of the air.
Declinatory: Containing or involving a declination or refusal, as of submission to a charge or sentence.
Damned: Sentenced to punishment in a future state; condemned; consigned to perdition.
Demureness: The state of being demure; gravity; the show of gravity or modesty.
Deflection: The act of turning aside, or state of being turned aside; a turning from a right line or proper course; a bending, esp. downward; deviation.
doltish: Doltlike; dull in intellect; stupid; blockish; as, a doltish clown.
Deceitful: Full of, or characterized by, deceit; serving to mislead or insnare; trickish; fraudulent; cheating; insincere.
Dogdraw: The act of drawing after, or pursuing, deer with a dog.
Discumber: To free from that which cumbers or impedes; to disencumber.
Disappoint: To defeat of expectation or hope; to hinder from the attainment of that which was expected, hoped, or desired; to balk; as, a man is disappointed of his hopes or expectations, or his hopes, desires, intentions, expectations, or plans are disappointed; a bad season disappoints the farmer of his crops; a defeat disappoints an enemy of his spoil.
disinflation: a reduction in the rate of price increases; a lessening of inflationary pressure.
Dowlas: A coarse linen cloth made in the north of England and in Scotland, now nearly replaced by calico.
Doab: A tongue or tract of land included between two rivers; as, the doab between the Ganges and the Jumna.
delts: The deltoid muscles; -- a contraction used by body-building and health enthusiasts.   Used similarly to abs and pecs.  See deltoid muscle.
Dualistic: Consisting of two; pertaining to dualism or duality.
Decrown: To deprive of a crown; to discrown.
Dispropriate: To cancel the appropriation of; to disappropriate.
Diastema: A vacant space, or gap, esp. between teeth in a jaw.
Diamond-back: The salt-marsh terrapin of the Atlantic coast (Malacoclemmys palustris).
Dioscorea: A genus of plants, the roots of which are eaten as yams. See Yam.
Digging: The act or the place of digging or excavating.
Dynast: A ruler; a governor; a prince.
Duelo: A duel; also, the rules of dueling.
Di\u0153ciousness: The state or quality of being diœcious.
dalo: a herb of the Pacific islands (Colocasia esculenta) grown throughout the tropics for its edible root and in temperate areas as an ornamental for its large glossy leaves.
Deliverable: Capable of being, or about to be, delivered; necessary to be delivered.
Ductless: Having to duct or outlet; as, a ductless gland.
Divaricator: One of the muscles which open the shell of brachiopods; a cardinal muscle. See Illust. of Brachiopoda.
Dejecta: Excrements; as, the dejecta of the sick.
Dare-deviltry: Reckless mischief; the action of a dare-devil.
Digamy: Act, or state, of being twice married; deuterogamy.
Decantation: The act of pouring off a clear liquor gently from its lees or sediment, or from one vessel into another.
Darby: A plasterer's float, having two handles; -- used in smoothing ceilings, etc.
Dunder: The lees or dregs of cane juice, used in the distillation of rum.
Dorian: A native or inhabitant of Doris in Greece.
dumbbell: An exercising weight, consisting of two spheres or spheroids, connected by a short bar for a handle; used (often in pairs) for gymnastic exercise.
Dodge: The act of evading by some skillful movement; a sudden starting aside; hence, an artful device to evade, deceive, or cheat; a cunning trick; an artifice.
deterministic: of or pertaining to determinism; as, deterministic theories.
Digestive: That which aids digestion, as a food or medicine.
Dilater: One who, or that which, dilates, expands, or enlarges.
Dissuade: To advise or exhort against; to try to persuade (one from a course).
Defenseless: Destitute of defense; unprepared to resist attack; unable to oppose; unprotected.
Desertion: The act of deserting or forsaking; abandonment of a service, a cause, a party, a friend, or any post of duty; the quitting of one's duties willfully and without right; esp., an absconding from military or naval service.
Doom palm: A species of palm tree (Hyphæne Thebaica), highly valued for the fibrous pulp of its fruit, which has the flavor of gingerbread, and is largely eaten in Egypt and Abyssinia.
Dipneumona: A group of spiders having only two lunglike organs.
Disguise: A dress or exterior put on for purposes of concealment or of deception; as, persons doing unlawful acts in disguise are subject to heavy penalties.
Disposure: The act of disposing; power to dispose of; disposal; direction.
Discrimination: The act of discriminating, distinguishing, or noting and marking differences.
Diphthongization: The act of changing into a diphthong.
Decomposition: The act or process of resolving the constituent parts of a compound body or substance into its elementary parts; separation into constituent part; analysis; the decay or dissolution consequent on the removal or alteration of some of the ingredients of a compound; disintegration; as, the decomposition of wood, rocks, etc.
Dysodile: An impure earthy or coaly bitumen, which emits a highly fetid odor when burning.
disenchanting: freeing from illusion, credulity, overoptimism, or false belief.
deep-eyed: having eyes set well behind the brow; characteristic of the bony face of a cadaver.
Dissension: Disagreement in opinion, usually of a violent character, producing warm debates or angry words; contention in words; partisan and contentious divisions; breach of friendship and union; strife; discord; quarrel.
Doughnut: A small cake (usually sweetened) fried in a kettle of boiling lard.
Dramatist: The author of a dramatic composition; a writer of plays.
Daimio: The title of the feudal nobles of Japan.
Deadish: Somewhat dead, dull, or lifeless; deathlike.
Dudish: Like, or characterized of, a dude.
Deposal: The act of deposing from office; a removal from the throne.
Dauk: See Dawk, v. t., to cut or gush.
Disorder: To disturb the order of; to derange or disarrange; to throw into confusion; to confuse.
Dulcamarin: A glucoside extracted from the bittersweet (Solanum Dulcamara), as a yellow amorphous substance. It probably occasions the compound taste. See Bittersweet, 3(a).
distressed: facing or experiencing financial trouble or difficulty; as, distressed companies need loans and technical advice.
Dephase: To put out of phase, as two parts of a single alternating current.
Do-little: One who performs little though professing much.
deputy: One appointed as the substitute of another, and empowered to act for him, in his name or his behalf; a substitute in office; a lieutenant; a representative; a delegate; a vicegerent; as, the deputy of a prince, of a sheriff, of a township, etc.
