distributed: spread from a central location to multiple points or recipients.  Opposite of concentrated.
dark-blue: of a color similar to that of a clear unclouded sky.
Dithyramb: A kind of lyric poetry in honor of Bacchus, usually sung by a band of revelers to a flute accompaniment; hence, in general, a poem written in a wild irregular strain.
Demi-tasse: A small cup for, or of, black coffee.
droopy: bending downward due to lack of tautness; -- of lines.
depicted: represented graphically by sketch or design or lines.
Domesticity: The state of being domestic; domestic character; household life.
dysfunctional: impaired in function; especially of a bodily system or organ.
Dendrometer: An instrument to measure the height and diameter of trees.
Dizziness: Giddiness; a whirling sensation in the head; vertigo.
Dolly Varden: A character in Dickens's novel “Barnaby Rudge,” a beautiful, lively, and coquettish girl who wore a cherry-colored mantle and cherry-colored ribbons.
Decatoic: Pertaining to, or derived from, decane.
duster: One who, or that which, dusts; a utensil that frees from dust.
Double-banked: Applied to a kind of rowing in which the rowers sit side by side in twos, a pair of oars being worked from each bank or thwart.
Dahabeah: A Nile boat constructed on the model of a floating house, having large lateen sails.
Diiambus: A double iambus; a foot consisting of two iambuses (&unr_; &unr_; &unr_; &unr_;).
Demountable: Capable of being dismounted; -- said of a form of rim, for an automobile wheel, which can be removed with its tire from the wheel.
Dialectology: That branch of philology which is devoted to the consideration of dialects.
disaccommodate: To put to inconvenience; to incommode.
Devastavit: Waste or misapplication of the assets of a deceased person by an executor or an administrator.
Deodate: A gift or offering to God.
Drone: To utter or make a low, dull, monotonous, humming or murmuring sound.
Depredation: The act of depredating, or the state of being depredated; the act of despoiling or making inroads; as, the sea often makes depredation on the land.
Diuretic: Tending to increase the secretion and discharge of urine.
Dostoevski: Russian author Fyodor Mikhailovich Dostoevski; born 1821, died 1881.
Dracontic: Belonging to that space of time in which the moon performs one revolution, from ascending node to ascending node. See Dragon's head, under Dragon.
Depopulation: The act of depopulating, or condition of being depopulated; destruction or explusion of inhabitants.
doubleheader: two events, usually entertainment or sports performances, occurring immediately in succession or within a short time of each other; especially, two sports games played by the same teams on the same day, one right after another.
Docibility: Aptness for being taught; teachableness; docility.
Diadelphia: A Linnæan class of plants whose stamens are united into two bodies or bundles by their filaments.
Dasyurine: Pertaining to, or like, the dasyures.
Decant: To pour off gently, as liquor, so as not to disturb the sediment; or to pour from one vessel into another; as, to decant wine.
Decani: Used of the side of the choir on which the dean's stall is placed; decanal; -- correlative to cantoris; as, the decanal, or decani, side.
Decane: A liquid hydrocarbon, C10H22, of the paraffin series, including several isomeric modifications.
Domebook: A book said to have been compiled under the direction of King Alfred. It is supposed to have contained the principal maxims of the common law, the penalties for misdemeanors, and the forms of judicial proceedings. Domebook was probably a general name for book of judgments.
Dizzard: A blockhead. [Obs.] [Written also dizard, and disard.]
Dyas: A name applied in Germany to the Permian formation, there consisting of two principal groups.
Double-bank: To row by rowers sitting side by side in twos on a bank or thwart.
Disenfranchise: To disfranchise; to deprive of the rights of a citizen.
Dyad: Having a valence or combining power of two; capable of being substituted for, combined with, or replaced by, two atoms of hydrogen; as, oxygen and calcium are dyad elements. See Valence.
Dight: To prepare; to put in order; hence, to dress, or put on; to array; to adorn.
Do\u00f1a: Lady; mistress; madam; -- a title of respect used in Spain, prefixed to the Christian name of a lady.
Disanchor: To raise the anchor of, as a ship; to weigh anchor.
Deadlight: A strong shutter, made to fit open ports and keep out water in a storm.
Daubentoniidae: a natural family comprising solely the aye-aye.
Decided: Free from ambiguity; unequivocal; unmistakable; unquestionable; clear; evident; as, a decided advantage.
dogmatic: Pertaining to a dogma, or to an established and authorized doctrine or tenet.
Dandie Dinmont: In Scott's “Guy Mannering”, a Border farmer of eccentric but fine character, who owns two terriers claimed to be the progenitors of the Dandie Dinmont terriers.
Doughy: Like dough; soft and heavy; pasty; crude; flabby and pale; as, a doughy complexion.
Dispensatorily: In the way of dispensation; dispensatively.
Doctrinal: A matter of doctrine; also, a system of doctrines.
Dinoflagellata: and order of plankton, in some classifications it is considered a phylum of the kingdom Protista; in others it is included in the plant phylum Pyrrophyta.  Its members usually have two flagella, one of which extends from its center.
Dairyman: A man who keeps or takes care of a dairy.
Desiderate: To desire; to feel the want of; to lack; to miss; to want.
Declaratory: Making declaration, explanation, or exhibition; making clear or manifest; affirmative; expressive; as, a clause declaratory of the will of the legislature.
Dilatable: Capable of expansion; that may be dilated; -- opposed to contractible; as, the lungs are dilatable by the force of air; air is dilatable by heat.
Diamondize: To set with diamonds; to adorn; to enrich.
dustmop: a dry mop for dusting floors.
Deflectionization: The act of freeing from inflections.
digitalin: Any one of several extracts of foxglove (Digitalis), as the “French extract,” the “German extract,” etc., which differ among themselves in composition and properties.  Both Digitalis lanata and Digitalis purpurea have been used to prepare such extracts.
doubles: badminton played with two players on each side.
Deka-: A prefix signifying ten. See Deca-.
Denouncement: Solemn, official, or menacing announcement; denunciation.
Durante: During; as, durante vita, during life; durante bene placito, during pleasure.
Dasyp\u00e6des: Those birds whose young are covered with down when hatched.
Diving: That dives or is used or diving.
Divine: To use or practice divination; to foretell by divination; to utter prognostications.
Defraud: To deprive of some right, interest, or property, by a deceitful device; to withhold from wrongfully; to injure by embezzlement; to cheat; to overreach; as, to defraud a servant, or a creditor, or the state; -- with of before the thing taken or withheld.
dickie: A small 3rd seat in the back of an old-fashioned 2-seat car.
Dwine: To waste away; to pine; to languish.
D\u00e9butante: A young woman making her first appearance in society, especially one who is one of the honorees at a debutante cotillion.  See cotillion{4}.
Dowral: Of or relating to a dower.
Dentex: An edible European marine fish (Sparus dentex, or Dentex vulgaris) of the family Percidæ.
Digressive: Departing from the main subject; partaking of the nature of digression.
dateable: that can be given a date.  Opposite of undatable.
Dishwasher: One who, or that which, washes dishes.
Denticulate: Furnished with denticles; notched into little toothlike projections; as, a denticulate leaf of calyx.
Detractor: One who detracts; a derogator; a defamer.
Drumhead: The parchment or skin stretched over one end of a drum.
Duboisine: An alkaloid obtained from the leaves of an Australian tree (Duboisia myoporoides), and regarded as identical with hyoscyamine. It produces dilation of the pupil of the eye.
Dismemberment: The act of dismembering, or the state of being dismembered; cutting in piece; m&unr_;tilation; division; separation.
Dovers Powder: A powder of ipecac and opium, compounded, in the United States, with sugar of milk, but in England (as formerly in the United States) with sulphate of potash, and in France (as in Dr. Dover's original prescription) with nitrate and sulphate of potash and licorice. It is an anodyne diaphoretic.
Disheritor: One who puts another out of his inheritance.
Diallel: Meeting and intersecting, as lines; not parallel; -- opposed to parallel.
Disengagement: The act of disengaging or setting free, or the state of being disengaged.
Diplomatist: A person employed in, or skilled in, diplomacy; a diplomat.
Deposable: Capable of being deposed or deprived of office.
deckle-edged: having a rough edge; having a deckle edge; -- used of handmade paper or paper resembling handmade; as, deckle-edged paper; a deckle-edged book.
Devitrification: The act or process of devitrifying, or the state of being devitrified. Specifically, the conversion of molten glassy matter into a stony mass by slow cooling, the result being the formation of crystallites, microbites, etc., in the glassy base, which are then called devitrification products.
Discipleship: The state of being a disciple or follower in doctrines and precepts.
Dog-fox: A male fox. See the Note under Dog, n., 6.
Dock: To draw, law, or place (a ship) in a dock, for repairing, cleaning the bottom, etc.
Depressomotor: Depressing or diminishing the capacity for movement, as depressomotor nerves, which lower or inhibit muscular activity.
Diffraction: The deflection and decomposition of light in passing by the edges of opaque bodies or through narrow slits, causing the appearance of parallel bands or fringes of prismatic colors, as by the action of a grating of fine lines or bars.
Diapason: The octave, or interval which includes all the tones of the diatonic scale.  Compare disdiapason.
Dodger: a member of the professional baseball team called the Dodgers.  At one time the team was headquartered in Brooklyn, New York, when it was called the Borrooklyn Dodgers, but the franchise was transferred to Los Angeles.
Dementia: Insanity; madness; esp. that form which consists in weakness or total loss of thought and reason; mental imbecility; idiocy.
Diazeuctic: Disjoining two fourths; as, the diazeutic tone, which, like that from F to G in modern music, lay between two fourths, and, being joined to either, made a fifth.
Disrelish: Not to relish; to regard as unpalatable or offensive; to feel a degree of disgust at.
Dandelion: A well-known plant of the genus Taraxacum (Taraxacum officinale, formerly called Taraxacum Dens-leonis and Leontodos Taraxacum) bearing large, yellow, compound flowers, and deeply notched leaves.
Diurna: A division of Lepidoptera, including the butterflies; -- so called because they fly only in the daytime.
Deflagrator: A form of the voltaic battery having large plates, used for producing rapid and powerful combustion.
Disesteem: To feel an absence of esteem for; to regard with disfavor or slight contempt; to slight.
Deciduous: Falling off, or subject to fall or be shed, at a certain season, or a certain stage or interval of growth, as leaves (except of evergreens) in autumn, or as parts of animals, such as hair, teeth, antlers, etc.; also, shedding leaves or parts at certain seasons, stages, or intervals; as, deciduous trees; the deciduous membrane.
Digladiate: To fight like gladiators; to contend fiercely; to dispute violently.
diagnosing: the act or process of identifying the nature or cause of some phenomenon.
dishpan: a large pan for washing dishes.
Demurral: Demur; delay in acting or deciding.
differential: Relating to or indicating a difference; creating a difference; discriminating; special; as, differential characteristics; differential duties; a differential rate.
Draco: The Dragon, a northern constellation within which is the north pole of the ecliptic.
Domestication: The act of domesticating, or accustoming to home; the action of taming wild animals.
Disintegrable: Capable of being disintegrated, or reduced to fragments or powder.
Desuetude: The cessation of use; disuse; discontinuance of practice, custom, or fashion.
Disbelief: The act of disbelieving;; a state of the mind in which one is fully persuaded that an opinion, assertion, or doctrine is not true; refusal of assent, credit, or credence; denial of belief.
Diamide: Any compound containing two amido groups united with one or more acid or negative radicals, -- as distinguished from a diamine.  Cf. Amido acid, under Amido, and Acid amide, under Amide.
Disinterestedly: In a disinterested manner; without bias or prejudice.
despoiled: having been robbed and destroyed by force and violence.
Detrimentalness: The quality of being detrimental; injuriousness.
Denominator: One who, or that which, gives a name; origin or source of a name.
Dismount: To throw or bring down from an elevation, place of honor and authority, or the like.
Dendritic: Pertaining to a dendrite, or to arborescent crystallization; having a form resembling a shrub or tree; arborescent.
Disoccupation: The state of being unemployed; want of occupation.
dateless: Without date; having no fixed time.
Demagnetize: To deprive of magnetic properties; to render nonmagnetic. See Magnetize.
Differential: An increment, usually an indefinitely small one, which is given to a variable quantity.
Democrat: One who is an adherent or advocate of democracy, or government by the people.
Desudation: A sweating; a profuse or morbid sweating, often succeeded by an eruption of small pimples.
diehard: stubbornly and vigorously resisting in the face of seemingly hopeless odds; as, diehard opposition.
Decanter: A vessel used to decant liquors, or for receiving decanted liquors; a kind of glass bottle used for holding wine or other liquors, from which drinking glasses are filled.
Drogher: A small craft used in the West India Islands to take off sugars, rum, etc., to the merchantmen; also, a vessel for transporting lumber, cotton, etc., coastwise; as, a lumber drogher.
Debruised: Surmounted by an ordinary; as, a lion is debruised when a bend or other ordinary is placed over it, as in the cut.
Dealer: One who deals; one who has to do, or has concern, with others; esp., a trader, a trafficker, a shopkeeper, a broker, or a merchant; as, a dealer in dry goods; a dealer in stocks; a retail dealer.
disenfranchised: deprived of the rights of citizenship, especially the right to vote.  Opposite of enfranchised.
Dissyllable: A word of two syllables; as, pa-per.
Dotard: One whose mind is impaired by age; one in second childhood.
Disbark: To strip of bark; to bark.
decent: Suitable in words, behavior, dress, or ceremony; becoming; fit; decorous; proper; seemly; as, decent conduct; decent language.
down-bow: a downward stroke from the heel to the tip of the bow, in bowing a stringed instrument.  Contrasted with up-bow, when the bow is moved in the opposite direction.
Dogma: That which is held as an opinion; a tenet; a doctrine.
Distillable: Capable of being distilled; especially, capable of being distilled without chemical change or decomposition; as, alcohol is distillable; olive oil is not distillable.
Doncella: A handsome fish of Florida and the West Indies (Platyglossus radiatus). The name is applied also to the ladyfish (Harpe rufa) of the same region.
Double dealing: False or deceitful dealing; acting in bad faith; deception by pretending to entertain one set of intentions while acting under the influence of another. See Double dealing, under Dealing.
Desmoid: Resembling, or having the characteristics of, a ligament; ligamentous.
Denude: To divest of all covering; to make bare or naked; to strip; to divest; as, to denude one of clothing, or lands; the hurricane denuded the trees.
Disallowance: The act of disallowing; refusal to admit or permit; rejection.
Devious: Out of a straight line; winding; varying from directness; as, a devious path or way.
Depart: Division; separation, as of compound substances into their ingredients.
Doghole: A place fit only for dogs; a vile, mean habitation or apartment.
Demersed: Situated or growing under water, as leaves; submersed.
Dispossession: The act of putting out of possession; the state of being dispossessed.
directionality: the property of a microphone or antenna of being more sensitive to signal arriving from one direction than from another.
Dehydrogenation: The act or process of freeing from hydrogen; also, the condition resulting from the removal of hydrogen.
Digraph: Two signs or characters combined to express a single articulated sound; as ea in head, or th in bath.
Distributive: A distributive adjective or pronoun; also, a distributive numeral.
decolonization: the action of changing from colonial to independent status.
Di\u00e6resis: The separation or resolution of one syllable into two; -- the opposite of synæresis.
Discede: To yield or give up; to depart.
Diffusive: Having the quality of diffusing; capable of spreading every way by flowing; spreading widely; widely reaching; copious; diffuse.
Doppelg\u00e4nger: A spiritual or ghostly double or counterpart; esp., an apparitional double of a living person; a cowalker.
Diocesener: One who belongs to a diocese.
dicotyledonous: Having two cotyledons or seed lobes; as, a dicotyledonous plant.
Drevil: A fool; a drudge. See Drivel.
deep-fry: to cook by immersing in hot fat or oil.
Drabber: One who associates with drabs; a wencher.
Delinquency: Failure or omission of duty; a fault; a misdeed; an offense; a misdemeanor; a crime.
Dogship: The character, or individuality, of a dog.
Dandyism: The manners and dress of a dandy; foppishness.
Didynamous: Of or pertaining to the Didynamia; containing four stamens disposed in pairs of unequal length.
dignitary: One who possesses exalted rank or holds a position of dignity or honor; especially, one who holds an ecclesiastical rank above that of a parochial priest or clergyman.
daisybush: any of various mostly Australian attractively shaped shrubs of the genus Olearia grown for their handsome and sometimes fragrant evergreen foliage and profusion of daisy flowers with white or purple or blue rays.
Day-laborer: One who works by the day; -- usually applied to a farm laborer, or to a workman who does not work at any particular trade.
Derangement: The act of deranging or putting out of order, or the state of being deranged; disarrangement; disorder; confusion; especially, mental disorder; insanity.
Diagnostic: The mark or symptom by which one disease is known or distinguished from others.
Disinflame: To divest of flame or ardor.
Daubing: The act of one who daubs; that which is daubed.
Disassimilation: The decomposition of complex substances, within the organism, into simpler ones suitable only for excretion, with evolution of energy, -- a normal nutritional process the reverse of assimilation; downward metabolism; -- now more commonly called catabolism.
Drum: To execute on a drum, as a tune.
Defilement: The act of defiling, or state of being defiled, whether physically or morally; pollution; foulness; dirtiness; uncleanness.
Drub: A blow with a cudgel; a thump.
Drug: To affect or season with drugs or ingredients; esp., to stupefy by a narcotic drug. Also Fig.
Droll: To lead or influence by jest or trick; to banter or jest; to cajole.
Deportment: Manner of deporting or demeaning one's self; manner of acting; conduct; carriage; especially, manner of acting with respect to the courtesies and duties of life; behavior; demeanor; bearing.
De bene esse: Of well being; of formal sufficiency for the time; conditionally; provisionally.
Dialyzation: The act or process of dialysis.
Defer: To yield deference to the wishes of another; to submit to the opinion of another, or to authority; -- with to.
Down-share: A breastplow used in paring off turf on downs.
Discoverer: One who discovers; one who first comes to the knowledge of something; one who discovers an unknown country, or a new principle, truth, or fact.
Dealing: The act of one who deals; distribution of anything, as of cards to the players; method of business; traffic; intercourse; transaction; as, to have dealings with a person.
Directoire style: A style of dress prevalent at the time of the French Directory, characterized by great extravagance of design and imitating the Greek and Roman costumes.
Deliverance: The act of delivering or freeing from restraint, captivity, peril, and the like; rescue; as, the deliverance of a captive.
Dasewe: To become dim-sighted; to become dazed or dazzled.
Drossy: Of, pertaining to, resembling, dross; full of dross; impure; worthless.
Deafen: To make deaf; to deprive of the power of hearing; to render incapable of perceiving sounds distinctly.
Derive: To flow; to have origin; to descend; to proceed; to be deduced.
Deplumation: The stripping or falling off of plumes or feathers.
Dentiscalp: An instrument for scraping the teeth.
Disarticulate: To sunder; to separate, as joints.
Debit: To charge with debt; -- the opposite of, and correlative to, credit; as, to debit a purchaser for the goods sold.
Dissentaneous: Disagreeing; contrary; differing; -- opposed to consentaneous.
Denominational: Pertaining to a denomination, especially to a sect or society.
Deliquesce: To dissolve gradually and become liquid by attracting and absorbing moisture from the air, as certain salts, acids, and alkalies.
Dolcino: A small bassoon, formerly much used.
Draintile: A hollow tile used in making drains; -- called also draining tile.
Delirious: Having a delirium; wandering in mind; light-headed; insane; raving; wild; as, a delirious patient; delirious fancies.
Doggerman: A sailor belonging to a dogger.
Dereliction: The act of leaving with an intention not to reclaim or resume; an utter forsaking abandonment.
Dredger: A box with holes in its lid; -- used for sprinkling flour, as on meat or a breadboard; -- called also dredging box, drudger, and drudging box.
dispossessed: physically or spiritually homeless or deprived of security.
Detumescence: Diminution of swelling; subsidence of anything swollen.
Diorthotic: Relating to the correcting or straightening out of something; corrective.
Daybook: A journal of accounts; a primary record book in which are recorded the debts and credits, or accounts of the day, in their order, and from which they are transferred to the journal.
Diversity: A state of difference; dissimilitude; unlikeness.
Decadist: A writer of a book divided into decades; as, Livy was a decadist.
Duse: A demon or spirit. See Deuce.
Dust: To free from dust; to brush, wipe, or sweep away dust from; as, to dust a table or a floor.
Delthyris: A name formerly given to certain Silurian brachiopod shells of the genus Spirifer.
Dilatability: The quality of being dilatable, or admitting expansion; -- opposed to contractibility.
deionization: the act or process of removing ions.
Digenesis: The faculty of multiplying in two ways; -- by ova fecundated by spermatic fluid, and asexually, as by buds. See Parthenogenesis.
Depress: Having the middle lower than the border; concave.
Descent: The act of descending, or passing downward; change of place from higher to lower.
Decandrian: Belonging to the Decandria; having ten stamens.
Discover: To discover or show one's self.
Decry: To cry down; to censure as faulty, mean, or worthless; to clamor against; to blame clamorously; to discredit; to disparage.
Descend: To go down upon or along; to pass from a higher to a lower part of; as, they descended the river in boats; to descend a ladder.
duplicative: Having the quality of duplicating or doubling.
domesticated: tame, tamed; -- of animals.  Opposite of wild.
Dinornis: A genus of extinct, ostrichlike birds of gigantic size, which formerly inhabited New Zealand. See Moa.
Desk: To shut up, as in a desk; to treasure.
Disenthrone: To dethrone; to depose from sovereign authority.
Denominate: Having a specific name or denomination; specified in the concrete as opposed to abstract; thus, 7 feet is a denominate quantity, while 7 is mere abstract quantity or number. See Compound number, under Compound.
Draconian: Pertaining to Draco, a famous lawgiver of Athens, 621 b. c.  Used especially in the phrase Draconian punishment.
Devulgarize: To free from what is vulgar, common, or narrow.
Durylic: Pertaining to, allied to, or derived from, durene; as, durylic acid.
Dioptric: Of or pertaining to dioptrics; assisting vision by means of the refraction of light; refractive; as, the dioptric system; a dioptric glass or telescope.
dumpcart: a cart that can be tilted to empty the contents without handling them.
Decrial: A crying down; a clamorous censure; condemnation by censure.
Ditch: To dig a ditch or ditches.
Destructibility: The quality of being capable of destruction; destructibleness.
